Section Title: EXCHANGE RATE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Group adopted IFRS 16 Leases from January 1, 2019. IFRS 16 introduces a single, on-balance sheet lease accounting model for lessees. A lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the ----- underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make lease payments. There are recognition exemptions for short-term leases and leases of low-value items. Lessor accounting remains similar to the current standard (i.e., lessors continue to classify leases as finance or operating leases). The Group applied IFRS 16 using the modified retrospective approach, under which the cumulative effect of initial application is recognized in retained earnings at January 1, 2019. Accordingly, the comparative information presented for the year ended December 31, 2018 was not restated. On transition to IFRS 16, the Group recognized additional right-of-use assets and additional lease liabilities. The initial adjustment on financial liabilities as of January 1, 2019 was €16.5 million, while the effect on other financial liabilities as of December 31, 2019 was €12.2 million. Our 2019 results were decreased by €106,000, as a result of the adoption of IFRS 16. -----

Section Title: EXCHANGE RATE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In this Offering Memorandum, we rely on and refer to information regarding our business and the market in which we operate and compete. The market data and certain economic and industry data and forecasts used in this Offering Memorandum were obtained from publicly available information, independent industry publications and reports prepared by trade associations and industry consultants. In addition to the foregoing, certain information regarding markets, market size, market share, market position, growth rates and other industry data pertaining to our business contained in this Offering Memorandum was estimated or derived based on assumptions we deem reasonable and from our own research, surveys or studies conducted by third parties, including trade associations, and other industry or general publications. Industry publications and forecasts generally state that the information they contain has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but that the accuracy and completeness of such information is not guaranteed and in some instances state that they do not assume liability for such information. While we believe that each of these studies and publications is reliable, neither we, the Group nor the Initial Purchasers have independently verified such data and cannot make any representation or warranty as to their accuracy or completeness. In many cases, there is no readily available external information (whether from trade associations, government bodies or other organizations) to validate market related analyses and estimates, requiring us to rely on our own internally developed estimates regarding the industry in which we operate, our position in the industry, our market share and the market shares of various industry participants based on our experience, our own investigation of market conditions and our review of industry publications, including information made available to the public by our competitors. None of the Issuers, the Group or the Initial Purchasers make any representation or warranty as to the accuracy and completeness of, or take any responsibility for, such data. Similarly, while we believe our internal estimates to be reasonable, these estimates have not been verified by any independent sources and neither we nor the Initial Purchasers make any representation or warranty as to as to their accuracy or the accuracy of the underlying assumptions used to estimate such data. Unless otherwise indicated, data on our market position and market share is based on revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020. Our estimates involve risks and uncertainties and are subject to change based on various factors. See “Risk Factors”, “Industry” and “Business” for further discussion.

Section Title: EXCHANGE RATE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Group owns or has rights to certain trademarks or trade names that it uses in conjunction with the operation of its businesses. We assert, to the fullest extent under applicable law, our rights to our trademarks, trade names and service marks. Each trademark, trade name or service mark of any other company appearing in this Offering Memorandum belongs to its respective holder. Solely for convenience, the trademarks, trade names and copyrights referred to in this Offering Memorandum are listed without the [TM], [®] and [©] symbols. -----

Section Title: EXCHANGE RATE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: We have set forth in the table below, for the periods and dates indicated, certain information regarding the exchange rates between euro and U.S. dollars based on the market rates at 6:00 p.m. London time. We have provided this exchange rate information solely for your convenience. We do not make any representation that any amount of currencies specified in the table below has been, or could be, converted into the applicable currency at the rates indicated or any other rate. The average rate for a year means the average of the Bloomberg Composite Rates on the last day of each month during a year. The average monthly rate for a month, or any shorter period, is based on the average Bloomberg Composite Rate for each business day of such month, or shorter period, as the case may be. The rate for the period end represents the exchange rate on the last business day of the applicable period. These rates may differ from the actual rates used in the preparation of other financial information appearing in this Offering Memorandum. Fluctuations in the exchange rate in the past are not necessarily indicative of fluctuations that may occur in the future.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: We are a global specialty chemicals group focusing on intermediates, composites and specialties sectors, headquartered in Italy. Our business began in the mid 1950s and through a series of acquisitions and organic growth we have grown into one of the leading global composites and coatings technology producers in the world, with unparalleled footprint and reach. Since 2008, we have grown to become a European Leader in Specialty and Composites, by acquiring, PCCR, the composites and resins business of Momentive Specialty Chemicals Inc. in 2011, and CCP, the composites business of the Total Group in 2014. The acquisitions of PCCR and CCP significantly increased our presence in the composites sector, particularly in the production of UPRs and gelcoat, and expanded our geographic footprint in North America, South America, Asia and Australia. In 2017, we combined with Reichhold to form a global group in the intermediates, composites and specialties sectors, benefitting from Reichhold’s technical know-how in the field of unsaturated polyester resins and gelcoat. See “Business—History.” We divide our products into three classes: Composites, Specialties and Intermediates. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, we generated €1,618 million, €329 million, and €81 million of our revenue from Composites, Specialties and Intermediates, respectively, representing 79.8%, 16.2%, and 4.0% of our revenue for the same period, respectively. Composites include UPRs, coating resins and compound products (such as gelcoats). Composites, which are produced in batches, are made from two or more constituent materials with different physical or chemical properties which, when combined, produce a material with characteristics different from the individual components to match specific customer requirements. Specialties include plasticizers and other derivative products such as malic and fumaric acid as well as special anhydrides and special esters made using internally produced anhydrides that satisfy specific, highperformance requirements of the end applications in which they are used. Intermediates are produced on a continuous basis (i.e., not in batches) and include the anhydrides which we use internally to produce higher-margin Composites and Specialties. Intermediates not used internally are sold to third parties for use in their own Specialty and Composite production. See “Business—Our Business _Lines.”_ Each class comprises several individual products which, in turn, have multiple applications for various end user, including building and construction (approximately 38% of our revenue in 2020 based on management estimates), transportation (approximately 13% of our revenue in 2020 based on management estimates), house appliances (approximately 11% of our revenue in 2020 based on management estimates), electrical (approximately 10% of our revenue in 2020 based on management estimates), marine (approximately 5% of our revenue in 2020 based on management estimates), wind energy (approximately 5% of our revenue in 2020 based on management estimates), and other, including food & feed (approximately 18% of our revenue in 2020 based on management estimates). In addition, many of our products, particularly our Intermediates, are used internally in the production of other, higher-margin products in different classes. We usually target niche segments of our end applications, which offer higher growth opportunities due to the more favorable penetration opportunities and a greater focus on innovation compared to the broader segments of such end applications. We sell our products to over 5,000 customers worldwide. Over the years, we have built many strong and stable relationships with our customers, many of whom we have been supplying for over 20 years, primarily through our experienced, international internal sales staff who market our products in over 100 countries. We operate 36 production and distribution facilities and 13 R&D laboratories, spanning across Europe, the ----- Americas and Asia. Our operations consist of: (i) research and development; (ii) sourcing and purchase of raw materials; (iii) production, energy sourcing and quality control; and (iv) product sales, technical assistance and distribution. We are committed to the research and development of new and innovative products. R&D is fully integrated into our business model, with our research and development operations being focused on two main areas: (i) product research, and (ii) technology research. See “Business—Our Operations—Research and _Development.”_ For the year ended December 31, 2020, we had total revenue, GVA and Average Unit Margin of €1,745.8 million, €585.0 million and €595 per ton, respectively (€2,043.0 million, €584.5 million and €557 per ton in 2019, respectively), selling 983,966 tons of our products. Our profit for the same period and Adjusted EBITDA were €43.2 million and €261.1 million, respectively (€107.4 million and €241.4 million in 2019). For the year ended December 31, 2020, 44.5% of our total revenue were generated in the Americas, while 44.4% were generated in Europe, with the remaining 11.1% of our total revenue generated in Asia, respectively. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, we had total revenue, GVA and Average Unit Margin of €2,028 million,[1] €674.5 million and €/ton 640, respectively, selling 1,053,336 tons of our products with 42.2% of our total revenue generated in the Americas, 47.8% in Europe, with the remaining 10% of our total revenue generated in Asia. Our profit and Adjusted EBITDA for the same period were €125.8 million and €341.2 million, respectively.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the following are our key competitive strengths: _Leading position in an industry with an improved structure_ We are a leading manufacturer of Composites in both Europe and the US according to our estimates based on 2019 data. Furthermore, we are a leader by volumes for Compounds in Europe and in the US for Alkyd Coating Resins. The Composites industry has undertaken a significant process of consolidation over the past decade, which has resulted in the creation of a number of global players, e.g., AOC Aliancys, INEOS as well as ourselves. We have expanded our footprint and capabilities and contributed to such consolidation by acquiring PCCR, the composites and resins business of Momentive Specialty Chemicals Inc., and CCP, the composites business of the Total Group, in 2011 and 2014, respectively, and, more recently, by combining with Reichhold in 2017, as a result of which our market share in UPRs (representing capacity by producer) increased from 8% and 7% in Europe and America, respectively, in 2011 to 40% and 30%, respectively, based on 2019 data. Traditionally, the Composite industry has pursued a volumes based approach to sales, which often contributed to a mismatch between offer and demand. In recent years, partly as a result of greater focus on value-added products (which carry greater margins), we have experienced a realignment between supply and demand. Competition within the industry remains strong, both on a global scale, among industry leaders, and in specific areas due to the presence of several, well established, regional manufacturers. 1 This based on management accounts and excludes approximately €5.3 million of income realized from March 2021 through the sales of the remaining stock on hand of Polynt Chemical (Changzhou) co. ltd., whose production was discontinued in February 2021 following the mandatory closure request received from the Chinese Government. ----- A key measure of our profitability is GVA/ton. We have increased our GVA/ton profile through a continuous evolution of our portfolio towards higher-margin specialty applications and an improvement in the industry landscape. Our contractual framework both with suppliers and customers allows for price renegotiation on a monthly or quarterly basis or provides for automatic price adjustment based on the average price of the relevant commodity according to various price indices, which allows us to largely pass through volatility in raw materials, limiting the impact of raw material price movements on margins. The table below shows the increase in the GVA/ton profile of the Group from 2018. Source: Management data _Customer focused and innovation driven business model consisting of strong formulation know-how and development initiatives with customers_ Over the past decade, we have evolved from a local producer of Intermediates to a global composite specialty producer. Our strong focus on innovation has driven the transformation of our portfolio, with 79.8% of our revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 being attributable to Composites, from approximately 43% in 2008. The Group is supported by its approximately 100-person technical sales team, which focuses on local customer requirements and specifications, tying in with the Group’s strong focus on direct sales to customers, which represented approximately 90% of the Group’s revenues in the first six months of 2021. Moreover, the Group provides high quality, bespoke formulations and delivers products with identical specifications out of our different facilities to meet the needs of global customers which require consistency across their various locations. Our strong formulation know-how gained over the years has allowed the Group to innovate in application development, delivering over 1,000 SKUs, and we estimate that approximately 15-20% of our product portfolio is renewed each year. The chart below shows the percentage of the Group’s turnover from Composites new products by year of introduction for EMEA: Source: Management data Our business is innovation-driven, with R&D centers strategically located across our worldwide operations. We focus our R&D efforts on anticipating market developments and meeting our customers’ ever evolving needs. Our R&D activities are fully integrated into our business model thereby reducing time to market for new products and enhancements and improving our ability to respond promptly to customer ----- demand, as well as reducing costs and risks relating to new products and increasing environmental safety, all of which have a positive input on margins. We have developed regulatory expertise in highly regulated markets such as the EU and the US, with approximately 350 specialists working in our Research centers, Development labs, Quality Control labs and Technical support teams worldwide. Our R&D centers collaborate closely with our customers to identify, develop and market innovative products that meet our customers’ evolving requirements and competitive challenges. In some instances, we collaborate with clients to go through regulatory approval processes and/or we undergo internal vetting and approval processes. One of the key factors to our success is our ability to provide high quality, bespoke formulations with identical specifications for global customers on a local basis. We have a strong formulation know-how, with a portfolio of over 2,200 formulations, developed over the years, which has allowed us to innovate in application development, delivering over 1,000+ SKUs in 2020. Recent successful innovations include a new formulation for engineering stone to obtain outstanding glossing and scratch resistant kitchen slabs, and new vinyl ester resins for carbon fiber reinforced spar caps for wind blades. The below chart shows a selection of our strategic R&D projects with successful end use applications. We also collaborate with highly specialized universities for specific projects, such as the Universities of Bologna, Munich, the University of Ferrara, and the Politecnico of Milan. In 2020, our research and development expenses were €18.6 million. See “Business—Our Operations—Research and Development.’’ _Diversified customer base_ We have a diversified customer base that includes large multinational companies, with our top 10 customers representing 30.2% of our revenue for the twelve month period ended June 30, 2021, and our largest customer accounting for 8% of our revenue in the same period. Our customer relationships are based on our experience in offering bespoke technological solutions and ongoing local support. In 2020, our top 10 customers by revenue had been customers for more than 20 years on average. Our customer base is diversified across product categories, with our top ten customers by revenue operating across different industries, including distribution, wind energy, paint and coatings, artificial stone and cables and wires. The below table shows out top ten customers by revenue for the period ended June 30, 2021. -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: 1 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 161,891 Wind energy 8% 2 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 156,043 Distribution 8% 3 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 79,386 Paints and coatings 4% 4 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 50,787 Distribution 3% 5 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 34,489 Artificial stone 2% 6 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 32,588 Paints and coatings 2% 7 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 25,652 Paints and coatings 1% 8 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 22,069 Distribution 1% 9 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 21,152 Paints and coatings 1% 10 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 18,210 Pools 1% We approach every customer relationship with the goal of partnering and adding value over a long time horizon, leveraging our technical and regulatory expertise together with our R&D efforts to fully understand our customers’ objectives, needs and limitations. Approximately 90% of our sales volumes are conducted directly by our internal sales force. Composites are often borne out of significant collective efforts with customers to develop the optimal product for their end and use applications. The customized solutions we provide vary depending on the characteristics and chemical composition of the end and use applications, logistical needs (for example, ease of transport and shelf-life) and specific regulatory requirements. Providing high-quality products with specificity, sensitivity and consistency, coupled with extensive product validation data are key to fostering customer retention. In addition, the quality and dependability of our products are sometimes critical to obtaining commercialization and marketing approval from regulatory agencies. _Global footprint allowing proximity to our customers base_ Marketing and distribution of UPRs is a complex process due to their limited shelf life (approximately 1 month) and the limited range available for transportation from the relevant production sites (approximately up to 2,000 km). Our manufacturing footprint is strategically located to ensure access to key logistic routes and manufacturing clusters. As a result, our global footprint and proximity to our clients is a key competitive strength as it allows us to service a larger number of clients in different geographies, with lower logistical costs and shorter lead times to provide just-in-time service. With 36 production sites and distribution facilities worldwide, we are typically close to our customers. This proximity to our customers, together with our highly experienced and well trained sales and support staff enables us to efficiently deliver our products to over 5,000 customers across more than 100 countries. Our geographical reach and penetration enables us to respond rapidly and effectively to our customers’ demands, and is a key factor in our ability to develop and maintain customer relationships. _Diverse product portfolio enables us to focus on attractive market niches, benefitting from strong organic growth trends in end industries_ Our diverse portfolio of products enables us to focus on a number of highly attractive and diverse end applications, most of which offer significant structural growth potential. The variety of end uses for our products enables us to mitigate the impact on our business of cyclicality or seasonality that some of these markets from time-to-time experience. As a result of our diverse product portfolio, we are well positioned and equipped to take advantage of new trends in customer demand that may develop, naturally or in response to macro events such as the Covid-19 pandemic. For example, we have experienced growing demand for our products that are used in professional hygiene, home and personal care and wood protection market end uses both in the US and Europe, as customers have placed greater focus on health protection and well-being during the Covid-19 pandemic, which is a trend we believe will continue as a “new normal”. In addition, we have recorded greater demand for light weight products in the mobility sector as well as a greater demand for Composites, as opposed to traditional metals, in the wind energy market. Some of our products, such as resins and coatings, are subject to seasonal demand as they are used in market segments that have higher demand during spring and summer (e.g., paints for home maintenance and marine coatings). This seasonality helps us manage our volumes over the course of the year to maintain relatively stable production. ----- We divide our diverse product portfolio into three classes: Composites, Specialties and Intermediates. These product classes expose us to a broad range of attractive customer market niches, which have benefitted from positive macroeconomic and societal trends (such as, population growth benefitting the infrastructure and construction industries, and the increased focus on sustainability benefitting the wind energy industry). See “Industry—Key Outlook for our End Applications” The below chart shows the application of our product portfolio in a selection of customers’ end applications. _Integrated platform with stable profitability_ Our production process is based on a vertically-integrated model, which allows us to leverage the in-house production and consumption of Intermediates (e.g. phthalic and maleic anhydrides), which tend to have more volatile prices, in the downstream production of higher-margin Composites and Specialties. In 2020, phthalic and maleic anhydrides, which we produce for captive use, represented 25% of the total raw materials cost of producing UPRs. Therefore, we benefit from low volatility in terms of input cost and supply, and we are capable of delivering to our customers a greater level of availability of our products and certainty in delivery. Further, having access to vertically integrated intermediate and low-cost inputs supports our margins and helps us capture a greater share of profit across the value chain, especially in Europe where we have experienced demand for Intermediates outpacing the offer establishing a trend, which we believe, is likely to continue in the foreseeable future. The vertically integrated nature of our business, together with our proprietary catalyst technology used to produce our higher-margin products gives us significant operational autonomy from the volatile raw material prices, in particular in the Intermediates market. This reduces our dependency on suppliers while providing greater flexibility in timing price adjustments, as it allows us to foresee trends in advance, and an ability to respond quickly to changes in customer demand and test effectiveness of our products in-house. The Group is better able to predict trends in Intermediates pricing, as it purchases their main petrochemical raw materials. This allows the Group to be proactive in its price adjustment decisions compared to non-vertically integrated producers. Our proprietary catalyst technology has been developed through the years, allowing the Group to develop a leading technology for the oxidation catalysts for the production of maleic anhydride, phthalic anhydride and trimellitic anhydride, which can be used in conjunction with any of the processes currently used worldwide for the production of those molecules. Moreover, we license our technology to third parties, for example for the production of maleic anhydride from butane with fluid bed reactors, where the catalyst is a main part of its production. Our proprietary catalyst technology and know-how is currently used only by two other producers worldwide, which are not our end product competitors. ----- _Strong free cash flow from customer base and maintenance capex-light business model_ We have achieved resilient performance over the years with strong and stable cash flow generation. During the last three years, we have increased our profit for the period and Adjusted EBITDA Margin from €34.8 million and 10.2% in 2018, respectively, and €107.4 million and 11.8% in 2019, respectively, to €43.2 million and 15.0% in 2020, respectively. We have generated significant cash flows from operating activities and Free Cash Flow over the last three years, and in particular €115 million and €162 million, €169 million and €215 million, and €222 million and €255 million in 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively. Our business model, including our focus on directing our portfolio towards higher growth and higher margin products, has proven its resilience with strong performance in 2020 during the Covid-19 pandemic. During 2020 and the first half of 2021, there has been an increase in market demand for our products coupled with a market-wide decrease in supply, as a result of shortages of raw materials, logistics issues affecting the market, and competitors’factory closures. Combined with increased customer liquidity, these trends resulted in an increase in prices for our products which was greater than the increase in raw material prices. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, our revenue and Average Unit Margin were €2,028 million[2] and €640 per ton, compared to €1,746 million and €595 per ton, respectively and €2,043 million and €557 per ton, respectively, for the periods ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. Further, for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 our profit for the period and Adjusted EBITDA Margin were €125.8 million and 16.8%, compared to €43.2 million and 12.7%, respectively, and €107.4 million and 11.8%, respectively, for the period ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. Our robust margins are attributable to our vertical integration, our leadership position across the value chain, our strong relationships with our customers. Our contractual framework both with suppliers and customers allows for price renegotiation on a monthly or quarterly basis or provides for automatic price adjustment based on the average price of the commodity according to various price indices, which allows us to largely pass through volatility in raw materials, limiting the impact of raw material price movements on margins. We also strive to maintain stability through industry cycles by developing and maintaining relationships with customers that are industry leaders and relatively less vulnerable to economic downturns because of their financial strength and therefore maintain a stable demand for our products. Furthermore, we have a maintenance capital expenditure light operational structure, as our production processes rely on small scale reactors that operate at moderate temperatures and use batch production methods and, as a result, require limited maintenance and repair baseload capital expenditure. We also benefit from the cost advantages of operating large-scale, integrated facilities strategically located near major transportation facilities and customers locations. The combined result of our strong cash flow generation and asset light model has been that over time we consistently managed to achieve reductions in our net levels of indebtedness. In the period 2018-2020, we have incurred Total Capital Expenditures of €48.8 million, €50.2 million and €50.1 million per year, respectively, to maintain and enhance our facilities’ efficiency, representing 2-3% of our annual revenue in the same period, and we estimate capital expenditure of approximately €50 million per year in the coming years. We believe that this structure allows us to operate at lower cost and higher utilization rates and helps us maintain positive margins and solid cash flows even during industry downturns or periods of decreased customer demand. _Highly experienced management team, leading talented workforce_ Through acquisitions and organic growth, we have developed from a small regional European producer of Intermediates into a diversified global player in Composites, Intermediates and Specialties, with revenue of €1,745.8 million in 2020. Through this growth, we have established a strong know-how in the sectors in which we operate, particularly in understanding the profile of our customers and the dynamics of our business which has enabled us to sustain this global growth. This growth has been led, and enabled, by a team of highly qualified members of our senior management team that combined have over 45 years of experience in our industry. Our Chief Executive Officer, Rosario Valido joined Alusuisse (at the time a Group company) in 1982 and since then has held various management positions. Paolo Carugati joined the Group in 2006 as Chief Financial Officer, and had previously held other finance roles, including being CFO of another multinational group from 2000. Sergio Mario Conni joined the Group in 2009 following the acquisition of Chemial Group. Since then, Sergio has covered various operations and business management positions in the Group. From 2014 to 2017 Sergio covered the position of Senior 2 This based on management accounts and excludes approximately €5.3 million of income realized from March 2021 through the sales of the remaining stock on hand of Polynt Chemical (Changzhou) co. ltd., whose production was discontinued in February 2021 following the mandatory closure request received from the Chinese Government. ----- Vice President Americas, reporting to the CEO. He then moved back to Italy and served as EVP Europe, until taking over as Group COO in July 2020. Our senior management team is supported by a lean and efficient organizational structure that relies on talent, expertise and passion to help us create value. We invest in the training and wellbeing of our work-force as a means to improve performance and foster retention, which in turn are key factors in our efforts to further our growth and future development. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we invested €613.4 thousand on welfare projects in Italy. We also benefit from the expertise and experience of Black Diamond Capital Management LLC (“Black

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Diamond”), which has significant expertise and a successful track record in the chemicals market, both in
Subsubsection Text: Europe and the U.S. Black Diamond acquired Reichhold in 2015, and has controlled, together with Investindustrial, the Polynt Group since 2017. In addition to its interest in the Polynt Group, Black Diamond currently controls TFL Ledertechnik GmbH (“TFL”), a Europe-focused, global specialty chemicals player with a focus on specialty chemicals for the leather industry, and, together with Investindustrial, Bakelite Synthetics, a European and US specialty chemicals player carved out from Hexion’s phenolic specialty business. Black Diamond’s prior control investments in the Chemicals industry include Arclin, a specialty resins producer and Vertellus, a diversified specialty chemicals producer serving the agriculture, nutrition and various other markets.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Our principal objectives are to continue operating as a global supplier of Composites, Intermediates, and Specialties and to increase the value of the business by generating strong, sustainable and growing cash flows across industry cycles. To achieve these objectives we focus on five main pillars: _Leverage positive underlying industry dynamics_ Our markets are growing, with strong pull-through demand from our customer base and attractive end industries dynamics. We plan to continue to focus on such highly attractive end applications that offer significant and enduring growth potential with an aim to expand our operations. In Composites, we intend to take full advantage of recent trends in some of our key end-markets. These include increasing demand for light-weight UPRs in the transportation segment as well as increasing demand for the Composites used for wind turbines due to growing demand for wind turbines driven by the continuing shift to renewables. At the same time, we plan to exploit increasing demand for coating resins in the building market driven by the growing outdoor application sector, and increase our presence in the water-borne coatings segment as many emerging economies continue to switch from solvent-borne to water-borne coatings. In Specialties, we intend to further exploit the significant grow of plasticizers demand we recently recorded due to the increased use of plasticizers in the automotive markets, as well as the increased demand from non-cyclical applications such as wiring, cable and medical devices. We are focusing on developing sustainable solutions via special purposes plasticizers that are phthalate-free. Furthermore, we plan to continue benefitting from the increased use of malic acid and other specialties in multiple food and cosmetics applications. Our Specialties are widely used in high end applications and sectors, like cosmetics, food and feed, pharmaceutical, flavor and fragrancies, health care, and other luxury items. Most of these sectors are not cyclical and management expects to leverage on the Group’s breadth of experience and wide product portfolio to capture market growth. In Intermediates we intend to continue to benefit from our vertical integration to use our Intermediates and use our access to Intermediates production to manufacture higher margin products. _Pursue initiatives to grow and create value_ We pursue high-return organic initiatives to grow and create value with selected projects. We seek growth through improvements of our product portfolio, in particular with respect to Specialties, and value-added downstream products, as well as by targeting new geographies. In Asia for example, we aim to increase UPR margins by expanding the production of UPRs and Gelcoat in China. In Eastern-Europe, we believe we can capture demand growth through capacity expansion of UPRs and Gelcoat in Poland. Through our plant in Spain, we hope to target the electrical and automotive markets in Europe. In the U.S., we intend to expand the range of products in our facilities to include Specialty Anhydrides, Specialty Plasticizers and Compounds to support growth of our global clients operating in the Americas and to strengthen our footprint in high value-add products. ----- We are also aiming to improve our production flexibility across Europe, United Kingdom, and North Africa and to upgrade vinyl ester production technologies to serve clients in the growing wind energy markets. We are also pursuing other efficiency initiatives to target, among others, Intermediates with a view to improving operational efficiency, by seeking to achieve better selectivity and energy efficiency by carefully modifying the catalyst chemistry. For example, our new fluidized bed catalyst generation is intended to increase yield with a reduction in CO2 production per ton of maleic anhydride, as well as new phthalic anhydride reactor with additional capacity and reduced CO2 production. We will also continue to consider potential bolt-on acquisitions with focus on carefully selected assets. _Continue innovation to deliver successful new applications_ Our R&D operations are key to maintaining our innovation and ability to respond to market developments and customer needs, and are a core component of our customer offering. Our innovation projects are driven by market demand and customer needs for applications that meet evolving customer needs. This innovation is a key driver of revenue growth. We focus on continually improving our product offering through the introduction of tailor-made solutions and development of new applications to drive higher margins. Co-development initiatives are the predominant channel for developing new products that are demanded by customers for their new products, creating strong customer relationships and customer loyalty. Our main R&D objectives are to: (i) develop new formulations and cutting-edge technologies, such as environmentally friendly vapor-free coatings, (ii) lower the environmental impact of our production, (iii) improve process efficiency and productivity of MA, PA, and TMA, via proprietary catalyst technology, and by decreasing cost of production, and (iv) introduce new and better performing products aligned with segment needs. We intend to use, protect and further develop our intellectual property and unpatented proprietary knowhow by identifying the best practices and the most efficient technologies. We believe that technology innovation can help us achieve a sustainable cost position. We seek to optimize the overall effectiveness of our asset base by making appropriate investments in maintenance, turnaround times and capital equipment in conjunction with personnel training and site and plant benchmarking. _Grow an environmental and sustainability platform by focusing on sustainable products and manufacturing with a positive ESG market_ Our strategies and objectives are underpinned by a commitment to sustainability and ESG (environment, social and governance) values. We aim to operate and develop our business in a way that takes into account relevant economic, as well as environmental and social and governance factors. We also believe sustainability is a lever for growth and will enable us to tap into new and emerging business opportunities. To support this, we have recently appointed an ESG manager, who is responsible for internal auditing of ESG compliance. The below chart shows select ESG metrics for the year ended December 31, 2019. ----- For example, in order to reduce the environmental impact of Composites, we continue to identify new processes aimed at the recovery of chemicals in end-of-life Composites with the objective to re-use materials in polymer synthesis and to reduce the end-of-life environmental impact of Composites, and to improve their carbon footprint by favoring their use for multiple applications. We have a wide product portfolio and technology for recycled composites, such as recycling in cement production operations (full industrial examples available) and chemical recycling (under pilot scale development). For example, R-PET from bottles and other products is used to produce a type of UPR that is then used in piping and composite concrete material for buildings and infrastructures; and recycled carbon fiber from high-end automotive material is reused in producing SMC for transportation industry in structural applications. Moreover, on the R&D side, we are working with other industry partners and stakeholders on technology for chemical recycling of UPR, where the material is broken down into its original chemical components and re-reacted to produce new UPR molecules. In terms of CO2 emission, we continue to pursue a reduction in emissions and energy use optimization, in particular by focusing on the development of higher performing catalysts for maleic anhydride and phthalic anhydride production. We monitor our CO2 emissions globally and have implemented reduction plans in our production facilities with the higher emissions. Moreover, we purchase voluntary CO2 credits, to offset our CO2 emissions that are outside the scope of the EU ETS regulations. Furthermore, we continue to seek to reduce heat loss, increase electrical motor efficiency, improve lighting systems, and optimize natural gas burner systems. For example, some of our recently implemented projects are: (i) the creation of combined power and heat in Scanzorosciate (Italy), and (ii) the optimization of catalyst performance for selective oxidation processes to reduce CO2. Since 2017, we have reduced our CO2 emissions intensity (being emissions volume in proportion to our revenue) by 7.0% p.a. from 332 tons/€million in 2017 to 267 tons/€million in 2020. Although, our emissions intensity increased in 2020 compared to 2019 and 2018 due to a reduction in our revenue base in 2020 as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic, we continue to pursue a reduction in emissions. Based on an approximate internal calculation carried out by management on an interim basis, we estimate that our CO2 emissions for 2021 will be approximately 233 ton/€million. The following table shows our CO2 emissions intensity for the periods indicated. ----- Our portfolio includes various products with increasing use in renewables, such as UPRs, bonding paste, vinyl ester resins, and gelcoats for wind blades and nacelles. Recent trends for wind blades include the use of larger blades, higher throughput, and improved environmental controls. We are developing a new styrene-free Gelcoat to eliminate emissions of styrene. In addition, we continue to evaluate opportunities to minimize waste generation in our facilities, for example by reusing used/spent solvents both internally and externally. _Deleveraging_ On the Acquisition Closing Date and as a result of the Transactions, our Adjusted net transaction leverage ratio will be 3.8x. One of our primary goals is to continue to generate cash flow to facilitate deleveraging. Our management is strongly focused on deleveraging the Group’s balance sheet. See “Forward_Looking Statements.” To achieve this goal, we will place significant management emphasis on cash generation and efficient capital spending. Historically, we have been able to generate strong cash flow while meeting the capital requirement of our business, and we believe we are well positioned to generate strong free cash flow.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: _Current Trading_ Our recent performance for the two months ending August 31, 2021, in terms of Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted Unit Margins, has continued in line with the beginning of the year, as the Group continues to benefit from strong demand for its products leading to continued profitability and cash generation. Based on our unaudited preliminary management accounts for last twelve months ended August 31, 2021, we generated Adjusted EBITDA of approximately €376.8 million, particularly driven by higher volumes and higher Average Unit Margins. Further, based on our unaudited preliminary management accounts for the twelve months ended August 31, 2021, our revenues, GVA, Average Unit Margin and Volume were approximately €2,143.6 million, €716.2 million, 685 €/ton and 1,046 ton, respectively. As of August 31, 2021, we had cash and cash equivalents of approximately €415.4 million. The total implied enterprise value for the Acquisition was approximately €2.5 billion, representing an 8.9x multiple over the Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, which was equal to approximately €280 million. _The preliminary financial results presented above are derived from our unaudited internal monthly management accounts and are not intended to be a comprehensive statement of our operations or financial results for any period or the quarter ended September 30, 2021. This information has not been audited or reviewed, nor have any procedures been performed by our independent auditors with respect thereto. Accordingly, you should not place undue reliance on it, and no opinion or any other form of assurance is provided with respect thereto. Our preliminary financial results are based upon a number of assumptions and judgments that are subject to inherent uncertainties and are subject to change, and are not intended to be a comprehensive statement of our financial or operational results for these periods. We have not prepared condensed consolidated interim financial statements for any period after June 30, 2021. Accordingly, the preliminary financial results presented above may change and those changes may be material. See “Risks Factors,” “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Management’s Discussions and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” in this Offering Memorandum for a more complete discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our future performance._ -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: On June 29, 2021, Speciality Chemicals International II Limited (“SCIL II”) entered into a sale and purchase agreement (the “SPA”) to acquire the entire issued share capital of the Target from Speciality Chemicals International Limited (“SCIL”). Before the Acquisition Closing Date, it is expected that SCIL II will transfer its rights and obligations under the SPA to the Parent pursuant to a novation agreement to be entered into among SCIL, the Parent and SCIL II. Completion of the Acquisition is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including antitrust and foreign investment approvals (which have all been obtained), as well as the performance of certain closing actions. We currently expect completion of the Acquisition to take place in the fourth quarter of 2021. If completion does not take place by January 31, 2022 (or if extended, subject to satisfaction of certain conditions by the Parent, March 31, 2022), the SPA may be terminated by either party. See “Use of Proceeds” for the estimated sources and uses required for the Acquisition. See “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions”._ The Target is a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of SCIL, which is, directly or indirectly, owned by Global Chemicals S. à r.l. (“GCS”), Global Chemicals BD Holdings III, LLC or its successor in title (“BD III”), Global Chemicals BD Holdings IV, LLC or its successor in title (“BD IV”) and Reichhold Cayman, LP or its successor in title (“Reichhold Cayman”). GCS is indirectly controlled by funds affiliated with Investindustrial, and BD III, BD IV and Reichhold Cayman are indirectly controlled by Black Diamond. The Parent is a subsidiary of SCIL III LLC (“HoldCo”) and is indirectly controlled by Black Diamond The US Co-Issuer is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Parent. Both the Parent and the US Co-Issuer were incorporated to facilitate the Acquisition. The consideration payable by the Parent to SCIL under the SPA is €2,209,940,717 (assuming the Acquisition Closing Date would have occurred on June 30, 2021). The actual consideration payable at the Acquisition Closing Date may vary, depending on the timing of the Acquisition Closing Date as a result of a ticking fee and possible deductions due to any known leakages. A portion equal to 45.59% of the consideration will be paid in cash, with the remainder being paid through the issuance of a convertible loan note. It is expected that on the Acquisition Closing Date, the obligations under the convertible loan note will be transferred to the Parent’s indirect shareholder, SCIL II (Topco) Limited (“SCIL II Holdco”) and that SCIL will convert the loan note into such number of shares in SCIL II Holdco as would give SCIL ownership of not less than 99% of the shares in SCIL II Holdco and BD III and BD IV will contribute their shares in SCIL II Holdco to SCIL, thereby giving SCIL ownership of 100% of the shares in SCIL II Holdco. In addition, on the Acquisition Closing Date, we expect that GCS will reduce its capital by cancelling all of the shares in SCIL held by GCS and distribute the cash proceeds received under the SPA to GCS by way of a special dividend expressly provided for in SCIL’s articles of association, as a result of which GCS will exit its shareholding in SCIL. As a result, on the Acquisition Closing Date, the Parent will: (i) become the direct owner of the entire issued share capital of the Target, and (ii) become a wholly-owned indirect subsidiary of SCIL and, therefore, the Group will be under the indirect control of Black Diamond.

The Parent intends to use the proceeds of this Offering, together with the €85.0 million indirect cash investment made by Black Diamond and, potentially, certain minority parties that hold on interest in Reichhold Cayman (See “Summary—Corporate Structure and Certain _Financing Arrangement”), which will be contributed by SCIL II HoldCo by way of equity contributions_ through intermediate holding companies to the Parent, to finance in part the Acquisition (the “Equity

Subsection Title: Contribution”), and existing cash on the balance sheet of the Group to:
Subsubsection Text: On or about the Acquisition Closing Date, US Co-Issuer will lend, pursuant to certain proceeds loans in an aggregate amount of approximately €875 million, part of the gross proceeds of the issuance of the Notes offered hereby to the Parent (the “Co-Issuer Proceeds Loans”), which in turn will lend, pursuant to certain proceeds loans in an aggregate amount of approximately €300 million to Specialty Chemicals Holding I BV (the “SCH I BV”) for purposes of refinancing the Existing Senior Facilities (the “Parent Proceeds Loans”). Further, on or about the Acquisition Closing Date, Specialty Chemicals Holding II BV will lend to Polynt S.p.A a certain part of the Parent Proceeds Loans contributed by SCH I BV to it, pursuant to certain proceeds loans in an aggregate amount of approximately €84 million (the “Polynt Proceeds Loans”, and together with the Co-Issuer Proceeds Loans, and the Parent Proceeds Loans, the “Notes Proceeds Loans”). In addition, subsidiaries of the Parent and, subsequent to the Post-Transaction Reorganization, subsidiaries of both Issuers, may upstream further funds as needed for the payment of interest on the Notes by means of dividends and the granting or repayment of intercompany loans, as permitted by the covenant described under “Description of Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Restricted Payments—Limitation on Restricted _Payments.”_

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Contribution”), and existing cash on the balance sheet of the Group to:
Subsubsection Text: As of June 30, 2021, €502,300,000 and $59,100,000 was outstanding under the Existing Senior Facilities. A portion of the proceeds of the Offering will be used by the Parent to make the Parent Proceeds Loans on or about the Acquisition Closing Date. As further described under “ The Transactions—Notes Proceeds Loans”, the Parent Proceeds Loans are expected to be comprised of three facilities for an aggregate principal amount of €, deriving from Tranche A2 of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes, from Tranche B2 of the Floating Rate Notes and from Tranche C2 of the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes. The proceeds of the Parent Proceeds Loans will be used to repay in full the indebtedness of the Group under the Existing Senior Facilities on the Acquisition Closing Date. We refer to the repayment of the Group’s indebtedness under the Existing Senior Facilities as the “Refinancing.” The collateral securing the Existing Senior Facilities Agreement is expected to be released on or about the Acquisition Closing Date. We refer to the Acquisition (including the Equity Contribution), the Financing (including the entering into of the SSRCF), and the Refinancing together as the “Transactions.” See “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization” and “Description of Notes.”

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Contribution”), and existing cash on the balance sheet of the Group to:
Subsubsection Text: If the Offering of the Notes closes before the Acquisition Closing Date, pending the consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds from the offering of the Notes into the ----- Escrow Accounts. The Escrow Accounts will be pledged in favor of, the Trustee on behalf of the holders of the Notes. See “Summary—The Offering—Collateral”. The release of the Escrowed Property from the Escrow Accounts is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within one business day of the Acquisition Closing Date). See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption”. If these conditions are not satisfied on or before the Escrow Longstop Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption. The special mandatory redemption price for the Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the relevant series of Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of such special mandatory redemption. See “Risk factors—Risks Related to the Transaction— The Acquisition is _subject to certain conditions and risks and, if it is not consummated, the Issuers will redeem the Notes at 100% of the issue price, plus accrued and unpaid interestwhich means holders of the Notes may not obtain the return they expect on the Notes. In addition, the Issuers may not have sufficient funds to to pay all of the amounts due to the holders of the Notes in the event of a Special Mandatory Redemption”._ In the event of a special mandatory redemption, HoldCo will be required to fund the relevant Issuer in such aggregate amounts as are required in order to enable the Issuers to pay any funding shortfall, including Escrow Accounts fees, negative interest on the Escrow Accounts balances and costs and accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, owing to the holders of the Notes on such special mandatory redemption date, pursuant to a shortfall agreement. The holders of the Notes will not have any direct right to enforce the Escrow Equity Commitment, and must rely on the Issuers’rights to enforcement under the Escrow Equity Commitment. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Transaction— The Acquisition is subject to _certain conditions and risks and, if it is not consummated, the Issuers will redeem the Notes at 100% of the issue price, plus accrued and unpaid interest which means holders of the Notes may not obtain the return they expect on the Notes. In addition, the Issuers may not have sufficient funds to to pay all of the amounts due to the holders of the Notes in the event of a Special Mandatory Redemption.”_

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Contribution”), and existing cash on the balance sheet of the Group to:
Subsubsection Text: - fund the cash purchase price payable under the SPA by using (i) all proceeds from Tranche A1 (as defined under “Use of Proceeds) under the Euro Fixed Rate Notes; (ii) all proceeds from tranche B1 (as defined under “Use of Proceeds) under the Floating Rate Notes; and (iii) all proceeds from Tranche C1 under the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes; - fund the Parent Proceeds Loans, by using (i) all proceeds from Tranche A2 (as defined under “Use of _Proceeds) under the Euro Fixed Rate Notes; (ii) all proceeds from tranche B2 (as defined under “Use of Proceeds) under the Floating Rate Notes; and (iii) all proceeds from Tranche C2 (as defined under_ “Use of Proceeds) under the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes; and ----- - pay fees and expenses relating to the Transactions, by using (i) all proceeds from Tranche D (as defined under “Use of Proceeds) under the Euro Fixed Rate Notes; (ii) all proceeds from tranche E (as defined under “Use of Proceeds) under the Floating Rate Notes; and (iii) all proceeds from Tranche F (as defined under “Use of Proceeds) under the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes. For the avoidance of doubt, the “virtual tranching” of each of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes, the Floating Rate Notes and the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes is aimed at identifying the separate portions of the proceeds of the Offering being used to pay the cash purchase price for the Acquisition, make the Notes Proceeds Loans for purposes of, inter alia, the Refinancing and to pay fees and expenses relating to the Transactions, and will not entail issuing separate identifiers (CUSIPs, ISINs or common codes) for each such tranche under the Notes. See “Use of Proceeds”. Concurrently with or in advance of the Acquisition Closing Date, we expect to enter into a super senior revolving credit facility agreement in an aggregate principal amount of €85 million. The SSRCF will be secured by first-ranking security granted on an equal and ratable first-priority basis over the Collateral. In the event of an enforcement of the Collateral, the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from the Collateral (on a pro rata basis) only after the lenders under the SSRCF have been repaid in full pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement. In addition, we do not expect to draw amounts under the SSRCF at the Acquisition Closing Date but in the event that available cash on the Acquisition Closing Date is lower than our estimate due, among other things, to a negative movement in working capital, we may draw down amounts on or about the Acquisition Closing Date to fund any shortfall to complete the Transactions.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: In particular, the Post-Transaction Reorganization contemplates that: (i) Specialty Chemicals Holding II B.V. (“SCH II BV”) will acquire the preferred shares in PCCR USA Holdings Inc. (the “Preferred Shares”) from Polynt S.p.A. in exchange for a loan note; (ii) SCH II BV will undergo a statutory demerger under Dutch law, transferring the Preferred Shares and its shareholding in Specialty Chemicals International Inc. to a newly formed B.V. (the “New Demerged BV”) initially held by Specialty Chemicals Holding I B.V.; (iii) Reichhold Finance BV will be distributed up to Specialty Chemicals Holdings I BV and will then be merged into SCH II BV (with SCH II BV surviving); (iv) New Demerged BV will be distributed to the Parent; (v) the Parent will transfer New Demerged BV to US Co-Issuer in full satisfaction of the Co-Issuer Proceeds Loan and as a contribution to the equity of US Co-Issuer. As a result of the Post-Transaction Reorganization, US Co-Issuer will indirectly control the Group’s U.S. incorporated subsidiaries, other than Reichhold LLC2, which is expected to allow for a more efficient distribution of cash to US Co-Issuer to service its debt from the Offering. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to _Our Capital Structure—The Parent is a holding company that has no revenue generating operations of its own and will depend on cash from the operating companies of the Group to be able to make payments on the Notes. The US Co-Issuer is a special purpose vehicle which will have no assets and no subsdiaries until the succesfull completion of the Post-Transaction Reorganization, which we cannot assure you will be completed on a timely basis or at all”_

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Black Diamond currently controls the Target Group together with Investindustrial, and pursuant to the Acquisition will acquire control of the Target. Black Diamond is a leading alternative investment firm with over $8 billion in assets across four core platforms: (i) private equity funds; (ii) hedge funds; (iii) non-control stressed and distressed closed-ended funds; and (iv) collateralized loan obligations and structured products. Black Diamond was founded by Stephen Deckoff and has over 25 years of experience in underwriting, trading, restructuring and managing performing, stressed, distressed and private equity investments through multiple market cycles. Black Diamond is an SEC-registered Investment Adviser with over 80 employees operating from offices in Stamford, CT, London, UK and St. Thomas, VI. Black Diamond has a successful track record in the chemicals market, both in Europe and the U.S. Black Diamond currently controls TFL, a Europe-focused, global specialty chemicals player with a focus on specialty chemicals for the leather industry. In 2020, Black Diamond supported TFL through its transformational acquisition of Lanxess’s leather chemicals business and in 2021 Black Diamond together with Investindustrial completed the acquisition of Bakelite Synthetics, a European and US specialty chemicals player carved out from Hexion’s phenolic specialty business. Bakelite Synthetics is organised around four key segments (building materials, industrial applications, transportation and chemical intermediates) and is a strategic supplier and business partner to major manufacturers / OEMs in these verticals. Black Diamond’s prior control investments in the Chemicals industry include Arclin, a specialty resins producer and Vertellus, a diversified specialty chemicals producer serving the agriculture, nutrition and various other markets. In addition, Black Diamond has completed successful exits of businesses in the chemicals industry, with the sale of Arclin in 2017 and the sale of Vertellus in 2020 . -----
