In addition, on or shortly after the Acquisition Closing Date, we expect that GCS will exit its shareholding in SCIL. As a result, on the Acquisition Closing Date, the Parent will: (i) become the direct owner of the entire issued share capital of the Target, and (ii) become a wholly-owned indirect subsidiary of SCIL and, therefore, the Group will be under the control of Black Diamond. See “Principal Shareholders.” The shareholding percentages presented in the chart above represent the expected shareholding percentages in the Issuers and may be subject to variations. (2) On the Acquisition Closing Date, Black Diamond will provide the Parent with an aggregate amount of at least €85 million by way of equity contribution. The actual amount of the Equity Contribution may vary depending on the amount actually required to fund the completion of the Transaction, when taken together with the proceeds of the Offering, up to a maximum amount of €150 million. Following the Transactions, Black Diamond will indirectly hold the entire issued share capital of the Parent other than a stake of approximately 13% to 16%, depending on the exercise of certain pre-emption rights in connection with the Equity Contribution, that is expected to be held by minority investors. (3) Pending the consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds from the offering of the Notes into the Escrow Accounts. The Escrow Accounts will be pledged in favor of, the Trustee on behalf of the holders of the Notes. See “Summary—The Offering—Collateral”. The release of the Escrowed Property from the Escrow Accounts is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within one business day of the Acquisition Closing Date) to pay such consideration. See “Description _of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption”._ (4) The Parent, HoldCo and SCIL II Holdco were incorporated as holding companies for the purpose of the Acquisition and US Co-Issuer is expected to become a holding company as a result of the Post-Transaction Reorganization, have no independent ----- business operations, other than those in connection with their incorporation and the Transactions, and have no significant assets, other than the equity interest each of these companies holds in its subsidiaries . The US Co-Issuer is a special purpose vehicle which will have no assets and no subsdiaries until the successful completion of the Post-Transaction Reorganization. The only other asset of the Issuers, as of the Issue Date, will be the Escrowed Property pending consummation of the Acquisition. Prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, the restrictive covenants in the Indenture will only apply to the Issuers and the Issuers and their subsidiaries will not obtain control of the Target Group until the Acquisition Closing Date. (5) Prior to the Issue Date, the Parent and US Co-Issuer, among others, are expected to enter into a super senior revolving credit facility in an aggregate principal amount of €85 million. The SSRCF will be secured by first-ranking security granted on an equal and ratable first-priority basis over the Collateral. In the event of an enforcement of the Collateral, the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from the Collateral (on a pro rata basis) only after the lenders under the SSRCF and certain future hedging obligations have been repaid in full pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement. (6) On the Acquisition Closing Date, the net proceeds from the Offering of the Notes will be used, together with the proceeds from the Equity Contribution, and existing cash on balance sheet of the Target Group, to (i) fund (directly or indirectly) the Acquisition, (ii) repay on the Acquisition Closing Date, amounts outstanding under the Existing Senior Facilities; and (iii) pay fees and expenses relating to the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds”. (7) The Issuers are offering €1,300.0 million aggregate principal amount of Notes. The Notes will be general, senior obligations of the Issuers and will (i) be secured by liens over the Collateral equally, on a contractual first priority basis with the obligations under the SSRCF, certain other indebtedness that may be incurred in the future, certain hedging obligations, but pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, holders of Notes will receive proceeds from enforcement of security over the Collateral only after any obligations that are entitled to receive such proceeds on a super priority basis, including obligations under the SSRCF, certain other indebtedness that may be incurred in the future and certain hedging obligations, have been paid in full; (ii) rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Issuers’ existing and future senior indebtedness, including under the SSRCF; (iii) rank senior in right of payment to all of the Issuers’ existing and future indebtedness that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes; (iv) be effectively subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness or other liabilities of the Issuers that are secured by liens on assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness or liabilities; and (v) be structurally subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness and other liabilities of the subsidiaries of the Issuers that do not guarantee the Notes, including their obligations to trade creditors. The Notes are expected to be guaranteed on a senior basis, within 120 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date and substantially simultaneously with the guarantees granted in favor of obligations under the SSRCF, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, certain significant limitations under local law and customary guarantee limitations, by the Guarantors. On the Issue Date, the Notes will not be guaranteed and will be secured, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain significant limitations under local law, on a first-priority basis by security interests in the Issue Date Collateral. On the Issue Date and prior to release from Escrow, the Notes will also be secured by the Escrowed Property pursuant to the Escrow Charge. On or about the Acquisition Closing Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain significant limitations under local law, the Notes wil be secured by the SSN Post-Acquisition Date Collateral. Within 120 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain significant limitations under local law and substantially simultaneously with the obligations under the SSRCF, the Notes and Guarantees thereof (as defined herein) will be secured by the Post-Closing Date Collateral. The Collateral will also secure the SSRCF on a first-priority basis. The validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the security and the liability of each Guarantor (as defined herein) and security provider will be subject to certain limitations. The security interests in favor of the Notes and the Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. See “Risk factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Guarantees” and _“Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations”._ (8) For the period ended June 30, 2021, on an aggregate basis, the Guarantors generated 61.7%, of our profit for the period, 75.6% of our revenue (excluding intercompany transactions) and 78.6% of our Adjusted EBITDA. As of June 30, 2021, on an aggregate basis, the Guarantors accounted for 72.7% of our total assets (excluding equity investments in subsidiaries and intercompany transactions). The validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to certain limitations. See “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law _Considerations.” Adjusted for the Transactions, the Group will have €2,433,565 of Total financial indebtedness that is structurally_ senior to the Notes (i.e. incurred at subsdiaries of the Parent other than the US Co-Issuer and the Guarantors); and (ii) €783,346 of Total financial indebtedness that is effectively senior to the Notes (i.e. secured over assets of the Issuers and the Guarantors that do not form part of the Collateral). (9) On or about the Acquisition Closing Date, US Co-Issuer will lend, pursuant to certain proceeds loans in an aggregate amount of approximately €875 million, part of the gross proceeds of the issuance of the Notes offered hereby to the Parent (the “Co-Issuer

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: - 100% of the share capital of the Target; and - any Notes Proceeds Loan made to any member of the Target Group (as borrower) by the Issuers (as lenders) Also within 120 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain significant limitations under local law, the Notes will be secured by security interests granted on an equal and ratable first-priority basis over the following property, rights and assets (w) the shares of each Post Completion Date Guarantor and any other Material Subsidiary of the Parent; (x) the Polynt Proceeds Loans made to Polynt S.p.A. by Specialty Chemicals Holding II BV; (y) all assets owned by the Post Completion Date Guarantors incorporated in the United Kingdom, _provided that such security shall consist of a floating charge only; and_ (z) all assets owned by the Post Completion Date Guarantors incorporated in the United States, provided that (A) no security shall be provided over assets and property designated as collateral for the ABL Facility comprising (i) trade receivables, bank accounts or inventory, (ii) records, software, general intangibles, accounts, chattel paper, commercial tort claims, documents, goods, instruments, letters of credit, letter-of-credit rights, money and supporting obligations with respect to the foregoing, in each case directly evidencing, embodying, or governing the property described in clause (i), and (iii) all proceeds and products of the property described in clauses (i) and (ii); and (B) no security shall be provided over real estate (the “ Post-Closing Collateral”, and together with the Issue Date Collateral and Acquisition Closing Date Collateral, the “Collateral”). The Collateral will also secure the SSRCF on a first-ranking pari passu basis. See “Description _of_ _Certain_ _Financing _Arrangements—SSRCF.”_ The security interests may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability. For more information on the security interests granted, see “Description _of Notes—Security”, and for more information on potential_ limitations to the security interests, see “Limitations on Validity and _Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security Interests and Certain_ ----- _Insolvency Law Considerations”, “Risk Factors—Risks related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral”._ The security interests may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of Notes—Release of Liens”. Guarantors . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** On the Issue Date, the Notes will not be guaranteed. The Notes are expected to be guaranteed on a senior basis, within 120 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date and substantially simultaneously with the guarantees granted in favor of obligations under the SSRCF, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain significant limitations under local law and customary guarantee limitations, by the Guarantors. For the six months ended June 30, 2021, on an aggregate basis, the Guarantors generated 61.7%, of our profit for the period, 75.6% of our revenues (excluding intercompany transactions) and 78.6% of our Adjusted EBITDA. As of June 30, 2021, on an aggregate basis, the Guarantors accounted for 72.7% of our total assets (excluding equity investments in subsidiaries and intercompany transactions). The validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to certain limitations. See “Limitations _on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_ Optional Redemption . . . . . . . .** _Fixed Rate Notes At any time prior to, 2023, the Issuers may redeem some or all of the Fixed Rate Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus, in each case, accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the applicable redemption date plus the applicable “make whole” premium. At any time prior to, 2023, the Issuers may redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Fixed Rate Notes (including any additional Fixed Rate Notes), using the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to % of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but not including, the applicable redemption date, and additional amounts, if any; provided that at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Fixed Rate Notes (including any additional Fixed Rate Notes) remains outstanding after each redemption and the redemption occurs within 180 days after the closing of any such equity offering, as described under “Description of Notes—Optional _Redemption.”_ Prior to, 2023, the Issuers may, during each twelve months period following the Issue Date, redeem up to 10% of the original aggregate principal amount of each series of the Fixed Rate Notes (including any additional Notes of the same series) at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date, as described in the “Description of Notes— _Optional Redemption”._ At any time on or after, 2023, the Issuers may redeem some or all of the Fixed Rate Notes at the redemption prices set forth in “Description of Notes—Optional Redemption” _Floating Rate Notes_ At any time prior to, 2022, the Issuers will be entitled, at their option, to redeem all or a portion of the Floating Rate Notes at a ----- redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, plus the relevant “make-whole” premium. At any time on or after, 2022, the Issuers may redeem all or a portion of the Floating Rate Notes at the redemption prices described in this Offering Memorandum under the caption “Description of Notes—Optional Redemption—Euro Floating Rate _Notes,” plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if_ any, to the date of redemption.

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: Reasons . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** If certain changes in the law (or in its interpretation) of any relevant taxing jurisdiction impose certain withholding taxes or other deductions on the payments on any series of Notes, the relevant Issuer may redeem the applicable series of Notes in whole, but not in part, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date. See “Description _of_ _Notes—Optional _Redemption for Taxation Reasons”_ Additional Amounts . . . . . . . . .** Any payments made by or on behalf of the Issuers or any Guarantor under or with respect to the Notes or Guarantees will be made without withholding or deduction for taxes unless required by law. If such withholding or deduction is required by law in any “relevant taxing jurisdiction,” the relevant Issuer or the relevant Guarantor, as applicable, will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amounts received after the withholding or deduction is not less than the amount that would have been received in the absence of the withholding or deduction, subject to certain exceptions. See “Description of Notes—Certain Definitions—Additional Amounts”. Change of Control . . . . . . . . . .** Upon the occurrence of certain defined events constituting a change of control or upon certain asset sales, each holder of any series of Notes may require the relevant Issuer, as applicable, to repurchase all or a portion of the Notes of the relevant series at a price equal to 101% of their principal amount plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date.

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: Mandatory Redemption . . . . .** If the Offering of the Notes closes before the Acquisition Closing Date, concurrently with the closing of the Offering, and pending consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow Accounts. The Escrow Accounts will be controlled by the Escrow Agent and pledged in favor of the Trustee on behalf of the holders of the Notes. The release of the proceeds deposited in the Escrow Accounts will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within one business day). Upon delivery to the Trustee and the Escrow Agent of an officer’s certificate stating that the conditions to the release of the proceeds from escrow are satisfied, the Escrowed Property will be released to the Issuers and utilized as described in “Use of Proceeds,” “Description of _Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”_ If the conditions to the release of the Escrowed Property have not been satisfied on or prior to the Escrow Longstop Date, or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption. The special mandatory redemption price of the Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional ----- amounts, if any, to, but excluding, such special mandatory redemption date. Amounts may be released from the Escrow Accounts prior to the Acquisition Closing Date to pay negative interest charged on the Escrow Accounts (if any) and to pay interest on the Notes on any interest payment date in respect thereof occurring prior to the release of the proceeds from escrow. In the event of a special mandatory redemption, HoldCo will be required to fund the Parent in such aggregate amounts as are required in order to enable the Issuers to pay any funding shortfall, including Escrow Accounts fees, negative interest on the Escrow Accounts’ balances and costs and accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, owing to the holders of the Notes on such special mandatory redemption date (the “Escrow Equity Commitment”), pursuant to a shortfall agreement. The holders of the Notes will not have any direct right to enforce the Escrow Equity Commitment, and must rely on the Issuers’ respective rights to enforcement under the Escrow Equity Commitment. In addition, the conditions applicable to the special mandatory redemption may be waived by holders of the Notes representing a majority in aggregate principal amount of the Notes outstanding. See “Description of Notes—Escrow of _Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—The Acquisition is subject to certain conditions and risks and, if it is not consummated, the Issuers will redeem the Notes at 100% of the issue price, plus accrued and unpaid interestwhich means holders of the Notes may not obtain the return they expect on the Notes. In addition, the Issuers may not have sufficient funds to to pay all of the amounts due to the holders of the Notes in the event of a Special Mandatory Redemption.”_ Covenants . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture will, among other things, restrict the ability of the Parent and its restricted subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - create or incur certain liens; - make certain restricted payments; - make certain investments; - impose restrictions on the ability of their subsidiaries to pay dividends or make other payments to the relevant Issuer; - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; - transfer, receive or sell certain assets including subsidiary stock; - consolidate or merge with other entities; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Each of these covenants is subject to certain exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of Notes—Certain Covenants” Certain of these covenants may also be suspended in the event that the Notes receive investment grade ratings from the relevant credit rating agencies. See “Description of Notes—Certain Covenants— _Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status.”_ Use of Proceeds . . . . . . . . . . . .** The net proceeds from the Offering of the Notes will be used, together with the proceeds from the Equity Contribution, the SSRCF and existing cash on balance sheet, to (i) fund (directly or indirectly) the cash consideration for the Acquisition (using (x) Tranche A1 under ----- the Euro Fixed Rate Notes; (y) Tranche B1 under the Floating Rate Notes; and (z) Tranche C1 under the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes), (ii) repay on the Acquisition Closing Date, amounts outstanding under the Existing Senior Facilities (using the Parent Proceeds Loans, comprising of (x) Tranche A2 under the Euro Fixed Rate Notes; (y) Tranche B2 under the Floating Rate Notes; and (z) Tranche C2 under the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes); and (iii) pay fees and expenses relating to the Transactions (using (i) Tranche D under the Euro Fixed Rate Notes; (ii) Tranche E under the Floating Rate Notes; and (iii) Tranche F under the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes). See “Use of _Proceeds”._ For the avoidance of doubt, the “virtual tranching” of each of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes, the Floating Rate Notes and the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes is aimed at identifying the separate portions of the proceeds of the Offering being used to consummate the Acquisition and make the Parent Proceeds Loans for purposes of, inter alia, the various elements of the Refinancing, respectively, and will not entail issuing separate identifiers (CUSIPs, ISINs or common codes) for each such tranche under the Notes.

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: Considerations . . . . . . . . . . .** For a discussion of certain U.S. federal income tax considerations generally applicable to the ownership and disposition of the Notes, see “Tax Considerations—U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations.” You should consult your tax advisor to determine the U.S. federal, state, local and other tax consequences of the ownership and disposition of the Notes. Form and Denomination . . . . . .** The Dollar Fixed Rate Notes will be issued in minimum denominations of U.S.$200,000 and in integral multiples of U.S.$1,000 in excess thereof maintained in book-entry form. The Euro Notes will be issued in minimum denominations of €100,000 and in integral multiples of €1,000 in excess thereof maintained in book-entry form.

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Transfer Restrictions; Absence of a Public Market for the
Subsubsection Text: Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes have not been registered under the Securities Act and thus are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. The Issuers cannot assure you that a market for the Notes will develop or that, if a market develops, the market will be a liquid market. The Initial Purchasers have advised the Issuers that they currently intend to make a market in the Notes. However, the Initial Purchasers are not obligated to do so and any market making with respect to the Notes may be discontinued without notice. See “Plan of Distribution”. Listing . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Application will be made to list the Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange. Trustee . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** BNY Mellon Corporate Trustee Services Limited. Security Agent . . . . . . . . . . . . .** BNY Mellon Corporate Trustee Services Limited. Paying Agent . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Bank of New York Mellon SA/NV, London Branch. Registrar and Transfer Agent . . .** The Bank of New York Mellon SA/NV, Dublin Branch. Listing Agent . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Carey Olsen Corporate Finance Limited. Governing Law . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture, the Notes and the Guarantees will be governed by New York law. The Intercreditor Agreement and the Escrow Agreement will be governed by the laws of England and Wales. Each Security Document will be governed by applicable local laws. -----

Section Title: SUMMARY FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA
Subsubsection Text: (i) Income related to sale or discontinuation of businesses in 2018 is related to the sale of the putty business of Polynt Composites Brasil. In 2019 the income related to sale or discontinuation of businesses is related to the sale of distribution business of Polynt Composite Canada. In the six months ended June 30, 2021 the income related to sale or discontinuation of businesses is related to the sale of Taboao land, Brazil and to the part of the compensation already received from the Chinese Government for the mandatory closure of the plant of Polynt Chemical (Changzhou) co. ltd (“PCH”) imposed by Chinese Government. This mandatory closure caused the discontinuance of production in the first quarter of 2021 and ultimately the closure of the site is planned within December 2021. The Chinese Government will compensate PCH paying instalments subject to certain terms and condition. As these incomes related to sale or discontinuation of businesses are not connected to the core business of the Group, management included these adjustments for the purposes of preparing Adjusted EBITDA. (ii) Indirect tax income is income related to the recognition of a tax credit on past years’ indirect taxes in Reichhold do Brazil following a decision of the Brazilian Supreme Court (SFT) in May 2021. This decision eliminated a double taxation impact with effect starting from March 15, 2017. The Supreme Court also determined that companies who had paid the extra indirect taxes and who filed a legal claim prior to March 15, 2017 would be able to recover these taxes paid from prior periods. Considering the final Supreme Court decision and that Reichhold do Brazil filed a legal claim prior to March 15, 2017, covering the periods from October 2003 through April 2017, the Group has accounted for an “income” for these available tax credits in the six months period ended June 30, 2021. As this income is non-recurring in nature, management included this adjustment for the purposes of preparing Adjusted EBITDA for the six months ended June 30, 2021. (iii) Costs related to cash-settled share-based plans represents the accrual of the award to certain directors and employees of one-off payments under the Phantom Share Option Plan (“PSP”) and extraordinary deal bonus plan (“EB Plan”). The PSP has a timeframe up to 2026, while the EB Plan has a timeframe up to the end 2021 and contemplated a one-off compensation to certain directors and employees linked to specific, pre-agreed events such as the Acquisition. Every fiscal year a liability was recorded as a charge to the statement of profit and loss based on the estimated payout and trigger date. As a change of control will likely become effective prior to the original two plans duration, a significant accrual has been accounted for in the six months ended June 30, 2021. The accrued awards to certain directors and employees under the PSP will be settled by cash as part of the Management Bonuses in connection with the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds”and “Transactions—Sources _and Uses”. As the Cash-settled share-based plan accrual is non-core and not directly corresponding to the business of each_ period, management included this adjustment for the purposes of preparing Adjusted EBITDA. (iv) Restructuring expense are costs related to site closures in Dubai, Canada, US, Brazil, Norway, Australia, Hong Kong, and to the closure imposed by the Government in China (Polynt Chemical (Changzhou) co. ltd). and other restructuring costs. Management included this adjustment for the purposes of preparing Adjusted EBITDA in order to reflect the core performance of the Group. (v) Merger and acquisition (“M&A”) expenses includes external M&A advisors and financial, commercial and legal due diligence fees and expenses, in respect to completed and potential acquisitions. As these are one-off costs that were incurred in connection with extraordinary transactions, management included this adjustment for the purposes of preparing Adjusted EBITDA. ----- (vi) Claim settlement costs in 2019 related to the definitive settlement agreement of a claim between (a) certain subsidiaries of the former Reichhold Group and (b) the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (“PBGC”) with an effective date November 1, 2019. The foregoing agreement settles the claim asserted by the PBGC in March 2015 against the non-US Reichhold subsidiaries. The PBGC had assumed the pension obligations of Reichhold Inc as part of the Reichhold, Inc bankruptcy process. Claim settlement costs in 2020 related to the definitive settlement agreement between (a) certain subsidiaries of the former Reichhold Group, (b) the Insurance Companies of the Group and (c) Fountaine Pajot (“FP”) signed on February 12, 2020. As both claims were related to the former Reichhold Group, management do not consider these costs as part of the core business of the Group and included this adjustment for the purposes of preparing Adjusted EBITDA. (vii) Insurance compensation received in 2019 is a consequence of an accident occurred at Polynt S.p.A. Maleic Anhydride Ravenna Plant (Italy) causing damage to the catalyst reactor. The occurrence was covered by the insurance policy, including the loss of margins due to lower performance of the plant subsequent to the accident as the Group scheduled to replace both the reactor and the catalyst in the following years. Therefore, the compensation was partially deferred. As this is a one-off event that incurred in connection with an extraordinary event, management included this adjustment for the purposes of preparing Adjusted EBITDA. (viii) The inventory provision income is a non-IFRS management adjustment to adjust for margins accounted for in the six months ended June 30, 2021 and relates to specific and exceptional conditions of the market prices of some raw materials. During the six months period ended June, 30 2021, the prices of several raw materials increased significantly. Since selling prices are based on the current price of raw materials and cost of goods sold is impacted by raw material prices of previous period, which were significantly below current prices, exceptional margins were made during the aforementioned period. The adjustment has been calculated based on a percentage of the average increase in variable costs in the first six months ended June 30, 2021 compared to the previous years and budget. As these margins are considered by management a one-off event related to extraordinary market conditions of raw materials, management included this adjustment for the purposes of preparing Adjusted EBITDA in order to reflect continuing profitability of the business. (2) Adjusted EBITDA margin represents Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of revenue. (3) Operating working capital represents the amount of trade receivables plus inventories, less trade payables. (1) We define Adjusted cash and cash equivalents as cash and cash equivalents of the Target, as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions, including (i) the €62.435 million of cash generated in the period between June and August 2021 and available to the Group as of August 31, 2021, and (ii) the use of proceeds from the Transactions, as if they had occurred on June 30, 2021. (2) We define as Adjusted total financial indebtedness as the amount of Total financial indebtedness on a consolidated basis of the Target, as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions, including the use of proceeds from the Offering, as if they had occurred on June 30, 2021. (3) We define as Adjusted net transaction financial indebtedness as the amount of Net financial indebtedness on a consolidated basis of the Target excluding other financial indebtedness, as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions, including the use of proceeds from the Offering, as if they had occurred on June 30, 2021. (4) We define as Adjusted net senior secured indebtedness as the consolidated as Adjusted net transaction financial indebtedness of the Issuers, secured by the Collateral, as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions, including the use of proceeds from the Offering, as if they had occurred on June 30, 2021. (5) We define Adjusted EBITDA as profit for the period before income taxes, financial income, financial expense and depreciation, ----- amortization and impairment losses, as adjusted to remove the effect of certain non-recurring and non core items that management considers not reflective of the performance of our core operations. For a reconciliation of Adjusted EBITDA to Operating Income, see “Summary Financial Information—Summary of Other Financial and Non-IFRS Data” (6) We defined as Adjusted interest expense as the estimated consolidated interest expense of the Parent on an adjusted basis for the period ended June 30, 2021, after giving effect to the Transactions including the use of proceeds from the Offering, as if they had occurred on July 1, 2020, subject to the assumptions set forth under “Use of Proceeds.” As adjusted interest expense includes commitment fees payable on the Existing Senior Facilities and assumes that the SSRCF was undrawn throughout the entire period. Section Title: SUMMARY FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA
Subsubsection Text: _The following tables present our summary financial and other information and have been derived from, and should be read in conjunction with, our Financial Statements that have been prepared in accordance with IFRS and are included elsewhere in this offering memorandum and the sections entitled “Presentation of Financial and Other Information,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations,” “Selected Financial Information,” “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalization.” We have extracted the consolidated historical financial information of the Target for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Historical Financial Information” and “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Basis of Preparation” and our Audited Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. We have extracted the summary financial information as of June 30, 2021 and for each of the six month periods ended June 30, 2021 and June 30, 2020 from the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Target and its subsidiaries as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2021 with unaudited comparative financial information for the six months ended June 30, 2020, prepared in accordance with IAS 34 Interim Financial Reporting and included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The summary unaudited financial information for the 12 months ended June 30, 2021 is based on the Consolidated Financial Statements and is calculated by adding the unaudited financial information for the six months ended June 30, 2021 to the difference between the financial information for the year ended December 31, 2020 and the unaudited financial information for the six months ended June 30, 2020. The unaudited financial information for the 12 months ended June 30, 2021 has been prepared solely for the purpose of this Offering Memorandum, is not prepared in the ordinary course of our financial reporting and has not been audited or reviewed. It is not necessarily representative of our results of operations for any future period or our financial condition as of any future date. The financial information for the year ended December 31, 2019 includes the impact of the application of IFRS 16 with effect from January 1, 2019. However, as permitted by IFRS, the financial information for the year ended December 31, 2018 has not been restated to reflect the impact of IFRS 16. See “Presentation of Financial Information—IFRS 16 Leases”. We have also presented summary unaudited as adjusted consolidated financial and other data prepared to give pro forma effect to the Transactions as if the Transactions had occurred on June 30, 2021 for the as adjusted statement of financial position information and on July 1, 2020 for the as adjusted statement of profit or loss information. Such summary unaudited as adjusted financial information is based on available information and certain assumptions and estimates that we believe are reasonable and may differ from actual amounts. It is for informational purposes only and does not purport to present what our results or other metric would actually have been had the Transactions occurred on the dates presented or to project our results of operations or financial position for any future period or our financial condition at any future date. The unaudited financial information of the Group for the twelve-month period ended June 30, 2021 is calculated by taking the results of operations for the six-month period ended June 30, 2021 and adding it to the results of operations for the full year ended December 31, 2020 and subtracting the results of operations for the six-month period ended June 30, 2020. This data has been prepared solely for the purpose of this Offering Memorandum, is not prepared in the ordinary course of our financial reporting and has not been audited or reviewed. Prospective investors should bear in mind that certain performance indicators and ratios that we present in this Offering Memorandum are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS, U.S. GAAP, SEC requirements or any other generally accepted accounting principles. Such Non-IFRS Measures may not accurately reflect our performance, liquidity or our ability to incur debt and should not be considered as alternatives to performance or liquidity measures derived in accordance with IFRS, U.S. GAAP, SEC requirements or any other generally accepted accounting principles, may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies, have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS. Because of these limitations, our Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to meet our obligations. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on our Financial Statements and using these Non-IFRS Measures only supplementally to evaluate our performance. See “Presentation of Financial Information—Non- IFRS Financial Measures.”_ -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Adverse and uncertain global economic conditions could negatively impact our business and ability to borrow or raise capital.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is substantially dependent on overall global economic conditions and historical demand has been strongly correlated with global GDP trends. Declining economic conditions—or negative perceptions about global or local economic conditions—could result in a significant decrease in demand in our end applications and adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition. We estimate that the majority of our revenue is generated by sales of our products that are ultimately used in the electrical, construction and transportation sectors. These industries are all cyclical in nature and have historically been adversely affected by downturns in the global economy. The supply-demand balance in the markets where we compete and prices for raw materials are strongly influenced by the overall economic conditions in the U.S., Europe, China and India. In 2020, a sharp decline in economic activity in China in January and February was followed by similar downturns in the rest of the world from March onward. Global GDP declined by 3.5% in 2020. Eurozone GDP contracted by 7.2% (compared to a 1.3% increase in 2019). Some countries were especially hit: GDP fell by 9.0% in France, 9.2% in Italy, 11.1% in Spain and 10.0% in the United Kingdom. In 2020, U.S. GDP fell by 3.4% (compared to a 2.2% increase experienced in 2019). China was the only major global economy to report growth in 2020, with a 2.3% GDP increase (against a 6.0% increase experienced in 2019). In India, by contrast, GDP fell by 8.0% after a lockdown lasting several months (compared to a 4.2% increase in 2019). Although global economic activity is currently growing again, it is not forecasted to return to pre-pandemic levels in the near term. The pace and extent of the global economic recovery remains uncertain, and certain markets, including emerging markets, may not in the future achieve the growth rates that they have historically recorded. An extended recession or other periods of declining economic conditions, either globally or locally in any of the markets in which we operate, could substantially decrease the demand for our products and adversely affect our business. In addition, a rise in inflation rates in the markets where we operate could have a negative impact on the demand for our products. In 2020, we generated the largest proportion of our profit, revenues and Adjusted EBITDA by country in the U.S. and as a result we are vulnerable to deteriorations in the economic conditions of the U.S., which in turn could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition or results of operations. In the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, we generated 36.7%, 33.9% and 32.4%, respectively, of our total revenues, 94.9%, 30.0% and 33.3%, respectively, of our profit for the period,, and 39.6%. 35.6% and 31.7%, respectively, of our Adjusted EBITDA in the U.S.. In addition, in 2020 we generated the second largest proportion of our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA by country in Italy and our results are particularly vulnerable to changes in economic and political conditions in Italy. In the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, we generated 25.4%, 26.4% and 27.4%, respectively, of our total revenues, (13.2)%, 17.4% and 52.2%, respectively, of our profit for the period, and 27.0%. 28.7% and 39.5%, respectively, of our Adjusted EBITDA in Italy. Any deterioration in economic conditions in Italy could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition or results of operations. ----- Similarly, a significant adverse change in a customer’s financial position, as a result of adverse economic conditions, Covid-19 or otherwise, could increase our credit risk relating to that customer’s receivables or limit our ability to collect accounts receivable from that customer. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our top ten customers accounted for 27.5% of our sales volume, while our largest customer accounted for 6.4% of our sales volume. Continued weakness in the global economy for a significant period of time, or a further deterioration of global economic conditions, could result in our customers experiencing less profitability in their businesses, cash flow shortages, and difficulty in obtaining financing, which may ultimately lead to liquidations or bankruptcies. In this respect, on September 29, 2021, the shareholders’ meeting of Polynt S.p.A. resolved to put into liquidation the following Chinese subsidiaries: (i) Polynt Hong Kong Co. Ltd., a company set up in 2007 with the aim of developing the business activities of the Polynt group in China, following the cessation of such activities; and (ii) Polynt Chemical (Changzou) Co. Ltd., following the stipulation on November 30, 2020 of a closure and relocation agreement with the local Chinese government authority having as its objective the cessation and relocation of all the production activities, in order to promote the high quality development of the Yangtze River economic belt. Any of these occurrences could cause us to limit or discontinue business with those customers. Our suppliers may also experience similar conditions, which could impact their ability to fulfil their obligations. Any of these events could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Furthermore, a number of our customers and suppliers rely on access to credit and/or financing to fund their operations, either of which may be limited due to adverse economic conditions. The inability of our customers to access credit facilities may adversely affect our business by reducing sales and increasing exposure to bad debt, thereby reducing our profitability. In addition, the inability of our suppliers to access credit facilities may adversely affect our business by causing shortages that in turn may result in higher prices for raw material and transportation, which could have an adverse effect on our margins. Our products are used in various end applications, including building and construction, transportation, automotive, electrical, food and feed, marine and home appliances. Markets for our products that have performed well in recent periods despite the struggling global economy may not continue their strong performance, and demand for our products may suffer as a result. Wind energy, transportation and infrastructure are three of key industries that have performed well even during the global economic crisis, particularly with respect to wind energy as people and corporations place an emphasis on clean, affordable and renewable energy. The infrastructure sector managed to remain relatively strong due to increased spending on projects by governments to help jump start economic recovery. Despite the strong performance of these two sectors during a time when the economy at large was struggling, we cannot guarantee that demand for wind energy products or that spending on infrastructure products will not decrease. Consumption in the infrastructure and construction sectors could decrease following the tapering off of the economic support measures enacted in response to the Covid-19 pandemic. Furthermore, spending on wind energy may decline as other sources of both traditional and clean energy become less expensive. In addition, support for government spending on infrastructure may diminish for a variety of reasons including budgetary constraints and the onset of inflationary economic conditions. A decrease in demand for wind energy or decreased government spending on infrastructure projects (or both) could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Political factors also impact the demand for our products and given the various geographical regions we serve, these could further impact our operating results. Demand in Europe and North America has also been driven by customers switching to high-quality products and technological advances in manufacturing that resulted in the replacement of traditional building materials with flexible and recyclable composites and other synthetic materials. Demand in regions such as China and South America has been driven by increased population growth, a growing middle class, focus on industrialization investments and higher infrastructure spending. Our results reflect these trends where we have seen an increase in demand for specialty chemical products being used in building and construction projects in these regions. Accordingly, trends in the industries and geographies where we operate, which are adverse to our business, could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The raw materials we use in our production operations are derived from crude oil and other petroleum feedstocks, which are subject to supply shortages and price volatility.
Subsubsection Text: Raw material costs comprise the largest portion of our operating costs. The majority of the raw materials we use are based on crude oil, including butane, orthoxylene, benzene, styrene and pseudocumene. The availability of these raw materials is essential to our operations. As a general matter, if a supplier is unable to ----- meet its obligations under delivery agreements with us, we may be forced to incur higher costs to obtain the necessary raw materials elsewhere or, in certain limited cases, we may not be able to obtain the raw materials at all. The prices we pay for our raw materials are closely linked to the price of crude oil and crude oil price fluctuations have affected, and will continue to affect, our results of operations and our financial condition. Other raw material costs such as the cost of soybean oil and normal butane used in the production of certain coating crude oil prices. Supply of petroleum feedstocks is often affected by factors over which we have limited control such as market conditions, general global economic prospects, production capacity in the markets, production constraints on the part of our suppliers, fluctuations in crude oil, natural gas and other commodity prices, infrastructure failures, political conditions, weather conditions, regulations and other factors. Any reduction in supply of our raw materials would significantly impair our ability to conduct our operations and would, therefore, have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Moreover, the producers of such petroleum derivatives generally link the price of the products they sell to the international market price of crude oil and other petroleum feedstocks, which are subject to frequent volatility as a result of factors over which we have limited control. Our supply agreements typically provide for market-based pricing. As a result, (i) fluctuations in the global market price of crude oil and other feedstocks tend to have a direct and immediate effect on the prices we pay for such products, (ii) our operating income, operating margin and cash flows from operations are vulnerable to adverse fluctuations in the exchange rates between the U.S. dollar and the euro and (iii) our raw material costs may vary significantly from period to period, even when the volume of our production remains relatively constant. In early March 2020, the global oil markets were negatively impacted by an oil supply conflict occurring when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and other major oil producing nations (“OPEC +”) were initially unable to reach an agreement on production levels for crude oil, at which point Saudi Arabia and Russia initiated efforts to aggressively increase production. The convergence of these events with the Covid-19 pandemic created the unprecedented dual impact of a dramatic decline in the demand for oil as a result of the significant slowdown in the global economy coupled with the risk of a substantial increase in supply. The result has been a steep decline in oil prices, which has negatively impacted our results due to the reduction of the value of the inventory. In addition, in early September 2021, the global oil markets were negatively impacted by a general crisis of the energy sector as a result of market dynamics wherein crude oil is in short supply, which may affect the supply and prices of crude oil through the first quarter of year 2022 or through any future period. Economic factors, including inflation and fluctuations in interest rates, could have a negative impact on our business. If our costs become impacted by significant inflationary pressures or interest rate increases, we may not be able to fully offset such higher costs through price increases. Most of our contracts with suppliers and customers allow for price renegotiation on a monthly or quarterly basis or for automatic price adjustment based on the average price of the commodity according to different price indices, which is intended to enable us to pass raw materials cost increases to our customers by raising the price of our products. However, there is no guarantee that this flexibility will be sufficient to adapt our contracts to current business conditions in a way that is suitable to us, or at all. We are not always able to pass through raw material price increases, or in some instances we suffer a certain time lag and, therefore, experience lower margins. Our inability to quickly pass through all raw material cost increases is affected by several additional factors. For example, demand in the end applications where our customers compete can sometimes be too weak to absorb the full effect of price increases. As a result, we sometimes postpone passing on cost increases in an attempt to maintain sales volumes, which can adversely affect our margins. Moreover, if prices of our raw materials, such as crude oil, are declining, customers may delay their purchases of our products until the price drop is reflected in the product’s price. An inability to raise our prices sufficiently or in a timely manner could have, and has in the past had, a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition or results of operations. Changes in raw material prices also have a direct effect on our working capital levels. In general, increases in the cost of raw materials leads to an increase in our working capital requirements, as our inventories and trade receivables increase as a result of higher raw materials prices, which increase is only partially offset by an increase in trade payables. Due to the quantity and turnover of the raw materials that we typically keep in stock, this increase occurs gradually over a period of three months. Conversely, decreases in the cost of raw materials lead to a decrease in our working capital requirements within the same three-month period following the decrease in costs. ----- Adverse global economic conditions, market instability, including as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic, and volatile commodity price fluctuations make it increasingly difficult for us, our customers and our suppliers to accurately forecast future product demand and sales prices, which could cause us to procure raw materials in excess of what is needed to meet end-product demand. This could cause a material increase in our inventory carrying costs and, in the event of falling market prices for our end products, result in significant charges to write-down inventory to market prices. In a declining price environment, demand can decline as customers postpone orders in anticipation of further price decreases. In response to changes in demand levels, our competitors may price their products more aggressively in order to retain market share, which can result in an adverse market environment for us in the short term until the market reaches a new equilibrium. There may be other unforeseen effects, which we cannot predict given the volatility of raw material prices, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition or results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The occurrence of operational interruptions or problems at our facilities or to our transport infrastructure could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition or results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is dependent on the continued and uninterrupted performance of our production facilities. We have 36 production and distribution facilities in Italy, Germany, France, Poland, Spain, Norway, the United Kingdom, China, South Korea, Malaysia, India, Brazil, Canada, Mexico and the United States, and each is subject to operating risks including: - severe weather conditions such as hurricanes, fires, earthquakes, floods, extreme temperature fluctuations or any other natural or man-made disaster; - explosions and other accidents, including pipeline leaks and ruptures; - human error or mechanical failures; - unplanned production downtime; - transportation interruptions; - the impact of pandemics, including the Covid-19 pandemic; - negligent actions of third parties; - terrorism or sabotage aimed at disrupting our production facilities; - unpermitted discharges or releases of toxic or hazardous substances or gases; - political and economic conditions, which drive rapid changes in prices for our key raw materials; and - other environmental health, safety and security risks. These hazards can cause personal injury and loss of life, severe damage to or destruction of property and equipment as well as environmental damage, and may result in suspension of operations and the imposition of civil and criminal liabilities, including penalties, fines and damage awards. See “—We may incur litigation_related expenses and/or reputational damage, among other losses”. In addition, the global nature of our business necessarily causes us to be susceptible to disruptions of logistics flows for the delivery of raw materials caused by unforeseen events beyond our control, such as poor handling provided by logistics service providers, natural disasters, adverse weather conditions, riots and labor strikes. If there is any delay in delivery, damage to products or any related or similar event, our operations may be materially and adversely affected. For example, the closure of the Durban, South Africa harbor in July 2021 as a result of civil unrest and the partial closures and reduced operations in certain ports in Guangdong, China, in June 2021 as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic caused delays in the delivery of raw materials to our production facilities with a consequential effect on our production logistics. We also have scheduled downtime at our plants in order to perform necessary inspections and testing to comply with industry regulations and to permit us to carry out any maintenance that may be necessary. Scheduled maintenance may require longer downtime than anticipated. Extended downtime at any of our major operating facilities, whether the result of scheduled maintenance or otherwise, could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition or results of operations. Any significant interruption occurring from time to time in operations at our facilities, including interruptions caused by the events described above, may exceed the limitations of our current insurance coverage, and may materially reduce the productivity and profitability of a particular production plant, or our business as a whole, during and following such interruptions. For example, certain electric power outages ----- in Texas, U.S. resulted in the closure of our production facilities in the state for over a week in February 2021, while in 2019 the damage in the catalyst reaction in one of the maleic anhydride reactors in our Ravenna, Italy plant caused a reduced in the production of the plant and required the replacement of the reactor and the catalyst used therein. Activities for the replacement of the reactor are ongoing and we expect it to be operational by 2022. If any of the foregoing events were to occur, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition or results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We rely on a limited number of suppliers of certain raw materials for our production requirements.
Subsubsection Text: We depend on a limited number of third-party suppliers to provide us, in a timely manner and at competitive prices, the raw materials we use in our production activities. For example, there is only one European supplier of the raw material we use to produce trimellitic anhydride, and only one Italian supplier of the raw material we use to produce maleic anhydride. We are, therefore, vulnerable to: (i) the unavailability of such raw materials or the delays in the delivery of such raw materials to our plants; (ii) substantial increases in the price of such raw materials and the limited bargaining power that necessarily comes with negotiating with such suppliers; (iii) decisions by our current suppliers to discontinue the supply of any such raw materials; (iv) financial or operational difficulties affecting our key suppliers; (v) macro and micro economic impacts (such as industry expansions, plant shutdowns, scheduled maintenance, force majeure actions etc.); or (vi) the impact of pandemics such as the Covid-19 pandemic on the price and availability of raw materials. In addition, some of our suppliers operate out of plants that were built several decades ago and may become less reliable as they approach their end of life stage. As a result, any disruption or delay in the supply of those materials from a particular supplier, an inability to source raw materials of appropriate quality, or loss of a supplier where we are unable to find a suitable alternative, may hinder our ability to fulfill customers’ orders on a timely and cost-effective basis or in the required quantities, which could result in order cancellations, decreased revenue and/or loss of market share and damage to our reputation. Further, volatility in costs and pricing can result in contractual disputes with suppliers or an inability to contract on mutually satisfactory terms. Adverse resolution of any such disputes or contract negotiations could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Additionally, many of our suppliers have operations that are subject to the health, safety, security and environmental risks associated with the use of hazardous materials. Any health, safety, security or environmental-related incidents affecting these suppliers may result in significant regulatory actions, fines and other penalties, including restrictions, prohibitions or sanctions on their operations. Such consequences in turn could impair their ability to meet their obligations under present or future supply agreements. Any problems accessing raw materials from our suppliers may require us to obtain those raw materials from other sources which may not be available on commercially reasonable terms or at all, and could require us to incur significantly higher transportation costs, higher costs of raw materials or significant delays, any of which could adversely affect our ability to meet our production requirements and delivery deadlines. Furthermore, as a result of our vertically-integrated business model, any difficulties in obtaining raw materials and/or adverse effects on the production of our products could further impair our downstream production process which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The outbreak of Covid-19 has had and may continue to materially and adversely impact on the sales and operations of some of our business areas.
Subsubsection Text: In late 2019, a novel strain of coronavirus, Covid-19, was first detected in Wuhan, China. In March 2020, the World Health Organization declared Covid-19 a global pandemic, and governmental authorities around the world have implemented measures to reduce the spread of Covid-19. The outbreak of Covid-19 and measures to prevent its spread, including restrictions on travel, imposition of quarantines, prolonged closures of workplaces and other businesses and the related impact from the disruptions to transport flows, supply chains, customers’ businesses and associated reduction in consumer demand have had, and may continue to have, an impact on our performance. In the first half of 2020, our sales volumes around the world were impacted by weaker end applications demand, the closure of certain of our key customers’businesses and disruptions in certain parts of our supply chain, including the temporary shutdown of certain of our sites due to government stay-at-home measures. However, our professional hygiene, home and personal care and wood protection market fields in the U.S. and Europe, experienced resilient levels of demand. Although this increased demand had the effect of partially offsetting decreases elsewhere in the business, there can be no assurance that areas of increased demand will ----- be sustained. As the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic continues to evolve, the outbreak may continue to have a negative impact on our performance in certain sectors such as transportation and automotive. We have taken measures, and may take additional measures, intended to minimize the risk of the Covid-19 pandemic on our employees and operations, including encouraging employees to work remotely where possible. The increase in remote working has created and may continue to create additional operational risks for us, including risks related to employee productivity, satisfaction, mobility, tax, and training. We expect that the impact of these disruptions, including the extent of their adverse impact on our financial and operational results, will ultimately depend on the duration of such disruptions, which will in turn depend on the duration of the Covid-19 pandemic, the impact of governmental regulations and the effects of more restrictive lockdown measures that might be imposed in response to the pandemic. Further, the Group has been and may continue to be impacted by the effect that similar disruptions have on its suppliers, vendors, distributors and customers. Although we believe that to date, the outbreak of Covid-19 has not had a material adverse effect on our operations, we are not able to predict the full impact and duration of the Covid-19 pandemic on our operations going forward due to a variety of variables, many of which are outside of our control, including ongoing lockdowns in various countries in which we operate, the availability of essential onsite personnel, the trajectory of new cases and variants around the world, the duration of any government imposed preventative measures, the efficacy of various governmental stimulus packages and the impact of the pandemic on global economy, the timeframe for widespread distribution of Covid-19 vaccines and the extent to which customer behavior is, or may be, permanently impacted. To the extent the Covid-19 pandemic adversely affects our business, liquidity and results of operations, it may also have the effect of intensifying many of the other risks described in this “Risk Factors” section. The Covid-19 pandemic may also cause other materially adverse impacts on our business and industry, each of which could adversely affect our business, prospects, results of operations or financial condition. Any future global pandemics may also have similar, or more severe, effects on global economic activity and on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The chemicals industry is subject to cyclicality, seasonality and volatility.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is subject to cyclicality, as a function of general economic conditions. All of our products, other than very few exceptions such as food applications, are subject to cyclicality. Historically, the chemicals industry as a whole has experienced alternating periods of capacity shortages leading to tight supply conditions, followed by periods when substantial capacity was added resulting in oversupply, declining capacity utilization rates and declining prices and profit margins. These factors, among other things, make forecasting more difficult and a failure to properly manage the cyclicality of our business may have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial conditions and results of operations. We are also subject to seasonality. Our products are used in various end applications for building and construction, transportation, automotive, electrical, food and feed, marine and home appliances. Most of these industries, particularly the building and construction sectors, have exhibited seasonal demand over the historical periods presented. For example, in the northern hemisphere, the summer paint and construction season drives increased mid-year coating sales that typically decline during the colder winter months. As a result, our working capital reflects similar trends with increased working capital requirements in the first half of the year, and a decrease in the second half of the year. Certain of our other products, such as resins and coatings, are also subject to seasonal demand due to the fact that they are used in market segments that have higher demand during spring and summer (e.g., paints for home maintenance and marine coatings). We believe this seasonality, has affected, and will continue to affect, our results of operations. Our business is subject to volatility. Several factors that have historically contributed to volatile margins in the chemicals industry, and in our business particularly, most of which are beyond our control, include: - costs of raw materials; - macroeconomic volatility, described above, particularly in the electrical, construction and transportation sectors; - exchange rate fluctuations for producers with a global manufacturing footprint or distribution; - oversupply due to capacity expansions by existing or new competitors; - short-term utilization rate fluctuations due to planned turnarounds and unplanned production downtime; - regulatory requirements driving required technology and manufacturing changes; and ----- - political and economic conditions, which drive rapid changes in prices for our key raw materials. We believe this cyclicality, seasonality and volatility have affected, and will continue to affect, our business, prospects, financial conditions and results of operations. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of _Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—General Economic Conditions, Demand and Cyclicality in our End Applications and Supply Dynamics.”_ In addition, given the current uncertainty in the global economic environment (that could result in lower demand) and the implications of the variable supply-demand balance in the chemicals industry, increasing supply could increase pressure on our margins and could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition or results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to credit risk related to both our customers and suppliers.
Subsubsection Text: A number of our customers and suppliers rely on access to credit to fund their operations. The ability of both our customers and suppliers to access necessary credit may be limited for a number of reasons, including adverse economic conditions. If our customers are unable to access credit facilities they may be unable to pay for products we supply them in a timely fashion or at all, which may adversely affect our business by reducing our sales and increasing our exposure to doubtful debts, thereby reducing our profitability. As of June 30, 2021, our provision for doubtful debt was €12 million. Additionally, any inability by our suppliers to access credit facilities, for whatever reason, may adversely affect our business by impacting availability and increasing prices for raw materials and transportation, which could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Compliance with environmental, health and safety laws and regulations and the retention of requisite permits related to our operations could result in significant ongoing costs and may result in further obligations and liabilities associated with our businesses.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to a variety of environmental, building permit, fire prevention, seismic, zoning and health and safety laws and regulations in each of the jurisdictions in which we operate. In particular, we are subject to a number of increasingly stringent local, state, and international environmental and health protection requirements with regard to, among other things, greenhouse gas emissions, air emissions, wastewater discharges and the use, handling and disposal of chemicals and hazardous substances. Moreover, stringent and evolving regulations apply to the machinery and equipment that we use to operate our business. Compliance with such laws and regulations requires expenditures (including capital expenditures for remediation and containment work), research and development expenditure to upgrade products and plants and/or increased operating costs, which would have an impact on our cost of production and our results of operations and may be difficult to pass through to our customers. A breach of any such laws or regulations may result in the limitation or suspension of production or subject us to material monetary fines and penalties, civil or criminal sanctions, or other liabilities. We may also be required to expend funds to remediate any non-compliance with any such laws or regulations. Such remediation work can last for extended periods of time, exceeding 10 years, and we are typically reliant on third-party contractors to conduct such remediation. Furthermore, environmental laws may expose us to liability for environmental damage that our current or former sites cause, including damage to neighboring landowners or residents, particularly as a result of the contamination of soil, groundwater or surface water, and especially drinking water, or to natural resources. We may also be liable for the damages caused to human health by the presence of hazardous containing materials (including asbestos and other radioactive materials) at the premises owned or operated by us, as well as for any on-site environmental contamination caused by pollutants or hazardous substances whose transportation or treatment we or companies we acquired arranged or conducted and we may also be liable for any environmental damage (such as contamination) caused by former owner(s) of the sites that we currently own and/or operate. In particular, some environmental laws provide for joint and several strict liability for releases of hazardous substances into the environment, which could result in liability for environmental damage without regard to negligence or fault. Environmental legislation is evolving in a manner that is expected to result in stricter standards and enforcement, larger fines and increased liability, and potentially increased capital expenditures and operating costs for compliance. As of December 31, 2020 and June 30, 2021, respectively, we made a provision for €22.4 million and €23.0 million, respectively, for ecological clean-ups. Environmental laws and regulations may result in an increase in our costs of operations. The environmental, health and safety laws, regulations and permits that govern our operations tend to become increasingly more stringent over time, including as a result of greater public scrutiny of environmental issues, and we could in the future assume additional obligations and therefore incur substantial incremental costs to ----- ensure our continued regulatory compliance. The pace of change together with the lack of regulatory harmony could result in unintentional noncompliance. If we do not accurately predict and adequately provision for the amount or timing of costs of any future compliance or if we misinterpret our obligations under any of these regulatory changes, we may be deemed to be in violation of environmental, health and safety laws, regulations or permits. Given the nature of our business, violations of environmental, health and safety requirements, whether current or future, may result in substantial fines or penalties, the imposition of other civil or criminal sanctions, clean-up costs and other remediation or restoration requirements, claims for personal injury or property damages, the installation of costly pollution control equipment, or restrictions on, or the suspension of, our operating permits or activities. Any of the foregoing, including the costs we incur as a result of the foregoing could have a material impact on our business, prospects, results of operations or financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Climate change, and the regulatory and legislative developments related to climate change, may materially adversely affect our business and financial condition, and we must comply with current and future regulations targeting greenhouse gas and other emissions.
Subsubsection Text: The impacts of climate change may materially and adversely impact the cost, production and financial performance of our operations. Any impacts to our business and financial condition as a result of climate change are likely to occur over a sustained period of time and are therefore difficult to quantify with any degree of specificity. For example, extreme weather events may result in adverse physical impacts to our sites or portions of our infrastructure, which could disrupt our supply chain and ultimately our business operations. In addition, disruption of transportation and distribution systems could result in reduced operational efficiency and interruption of deliveries and higher costs. Climate related events have the potential to disrupt our business, including the business of our customers, and may cause us to experience higher attrition, losses and additional costs to resume operations. A number of governments or governmental bodies have introduced or are contemplating legislative and regulatory changes in response to various climate change interest groups and the potential impact of climate change. The chemicals industry may become a target for future regulation regarding climate change. Legislation and increased regulation regarding climate change could impose significant costs on us and our suppliers, including costs related to equipment, environmental monitoring and reporting, and other costs to comply with such regulations. Any future climate change regulations could also negatively impact our ability to compete with companies situated in areas not subject to such limitations.
