The Group has not implemented a suite of policies which would be expected of an organization at a mature stage of its data protection compliance journey, but has initiated a GDPR (and similar regulations throughout the world) compliance program, with the intention of implementing data protection policies across the Group Information technology systems failures, including risks associated with upgrading our systems, network disruptions and breaches of data security could disrupt our operations by impeding our operational efficiencies, delaying processing of transactions and inhibiting our ability to protect customer or internal information. Our computer systems, including our backup systems, could be damaged or interrupted by power outages, computer and telecommunications failures, computer viruses, internal or external security breaches, events such as fires, earthquakes, floods, tornadoes and hurricanes, and/or errors by our employees. Although we have taken steps to address these concerns by implementing sophisticated network security, backup systems and internal control measures, a system failure or data security breach could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition or result of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: Our business relies on hardware, software, equipment and services supplied by third parties.
Subsubsection Text: We have important relationships with certain suppliers of equipment and services. Our suppliers may, among other things, change service levels, extend delivery times, supply unreliable equipment, raise prices and limit or discontinue supply due to their own shortages, business requirements, regulatory intervention, changes in trade policies or otherwise. Conversely, we may ourselves need to discontinue or reduce the use of products and services from particular suppliers due to similar or other reasons, including with limited notice. In many cases we maintain longstanding relationships with certain suppliers. This makes it more difficult to find replacement suppliers quickly in the event that a supplier refuses to offer us favorable prices, ceases to produce the equipment we use or fails to provide the services we require. In the event that products or services provided by third parties do not meet our expectations, or if the suppliers are insolvent, it may be difficult or impossible to enforce claims against them, in whole or in part. The occurrence of any of these risks may create operational problems, damage our reputation, result in the loss of customers and could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition or results of operations. We are also exposed to risks associated with the potential financial instability and business continuity issues of our suppliers. If our suppliers were to discontinue certain products or services or interrupt the provision of equipment or services to us, whether as a result of bankruptcy, regulatory actions, court decisions ----- or otherwise and if we were unable to procure satisfactory substitutes, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition or results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: We are susceptible to claims of anti-competitive practices.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is subject to competition and antitrust laws, rules and regulations applicable in the various jurisdictions in which we operate. We may become subject to investigations and proceedings by national and supranational competition and antitrust authorities for alleged infringements of antitrust laws, which could result in fines or other forms of liability or otherwise damage our reputation. For example, Polynt Composites Brazil Ltda. (“PC Brazil”) and Reichold Do Brasil Ltda. (“Reichhold Brazil”) are involved in administrative proceedings concerning alleged anticompetitive conduct, notably a cartel for coating and composite resins and the exchange of commercially sensitive information with competitors investigated by the Brazilian antitrust authority (“CADE”). The proceedings started in 2016, and have not yet reached a final judgment. Reichhold Brazil signed a leniency agreement (granting Reichhold Brazil full administrative immunity, and criminal immunity to the individuals who signed the leniency agreement) and PC Brazil has entered into a settlement agreement (granting PC Brazil a discount on the applicable fine), however, both agreements and full compliance with the obligations set out therein must be confirmed by CADE in its final decision regarding the case, which as of the date of this Offering Memorandum has not yet been issued.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: Uncertainty relating to Brexit, market perceptions concerning the instability of the Euro, and political and economic decisions in countries of the European Union could adversely impact our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: On January 31, 2020, the United Kingdom left the European Union (commonly referred to as “Brexit”), subject to a transition period that ended on December 31, 2020. We operate three facilities in the United Kingdom. Furthermore, our sales to the United Kingdom accounted for 4.9% of our total revenue for the six month period ended June 30, 2021. There is uncertainty as to the medium-term and long-term effects of Brexit on economic development in the United Kingdom. To the extent that the performance of the United Kingdom economy declines, does not improve or improves only over an extended period of time, our business, prospects, financial condition or result of operations may be materially and adversely affected. The legal, political and economic uncertainty created by Brexit, including the risk that other countries may decide to leave the European Union in the future could have a material adverse effect on global economic and market conditions. As a result, there can be no assurance that these or any other factors related to Brexit will not have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, concerns persist regarding the debt burden of certain Euro Area countries and their potential inability to meet their future financial obligations, the overall stability of the Euro, given the diverse economic and political circumstances in individual Euro Area countries, Brexit and volatility in the value of the Euro. These concerns could lead to the reintroduction of individual currencies in one or more Euro Area countries. These potential developments, or market perceptions concerning these and related issues, could have negative impacts on capital markets, including reductions in asset values, increased foreign currency fluctuations and greater volatility, potentially impacting our ability and that of our customers, suppliers and lenders to obtain financing and access liquidity at acceptable financing costs, the availability of supplies and materials, and the demand for our products.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to implement our business strategies.
Subsubsection Text: Our future financial performance and success largely depend on our ability to implement our business strategies successfully. We cannot assure you that we will be able to successfully implement our business strategies or that implementing these strategies will sustain or improve, and not harm, our results of operations. For example, we may not be able to increase our manufacturing efficiency or asset utilization or achieve other cost savings. In addition, the costs involved in implementing our strategies may be significantly greater than we currently anticipate. Our business strategies are based on assumptions about future demand for our products, new products and applications we are developing and, on our ability, to optimize utilization of our existing and future production facilities. Each of these factors depends on, among other things, differentiating our offerings and avoiding the commoditization of key chemistries in our products, our ability to innovate to keep up with changes in technology, customer preferences or the competitive environment, obtaining necessary regulatory approvals of appropriate scope, our ability to acquire and integrate businesses, financing operations and product development activities, maintaining and expanding high-quality an efficient manufacturing operations, efficiently managing our supply chains, responding timely to competitive and regulatory changes, ----- complying with competition regulations in various jurisdictions, accessing quality raw materials in a cost-effective and timely manner, obtaining or securing adequate intellectual property rights, and retaining and attracting highly skilled technical, managerial, marketing and finance personnel. These challenges may be accentuated as a result of widespread remote working arrangements due to measures adopted in response to the Covid-19 pandemic. We may not be able to implement our strategy of optimizing utilization of assets in accordance with our plans or at all. Additionally, even if we achieve our goals, the cost of implementing these initiatives could ultimately exceed their benefits. Any failure to develop, revise or implement our business strategies in a timely and effective manner could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Since the economic downturn in global markets in 2008, 2009 and, more recently, 2020, macroeconomic volatility has made it more difficult to predict GDP development in many economies, resulting in frequent modifications to GDP growth expectations published by economic research institutions, as well as in adjustments by market research specialists, sometimes giving rise to significant revisions to growth expectations for specific markets. Furthermore, the ongoing uncertainty of the Covid-19 pandemic may have a continued adverse effect on economic and geopolitical developments. As a result, many companies in the chemical and biotech industries, including ourselves, may find it difficult to accurately model and predict the prospects for their businesses, and it may be difficult for investors to use historical financial information as an indicator for future results. Any failure by us to accurately predict the economic environment and the development of our business could lead to misjudgments as to the level of production capacities needed for our business, increase the risk of failed investments and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: We depend on the expertise and experience of key personnel and our management team. We may face difficulties in attracting specialized personnel.
Subsubsection Text: We depend on the performance and continued service of our senior management team, including our Chief Executive Officer, our Chief Financial Officer and our Chief Operating Officer. Our senior managers and key personnel have extensive knowledge of our business, the industry, market trends and our customers, and are therefore critical to our continued growth and development. Because of the specialized and technical nature of our business, our future performance is dependent on the continued service of, and on our ability to attract and retain, qualified management, scientific, technical, marketing and support personnel. Competition for such personnel is intense, and we may be unable to continue to attract or retain such personnel. We may face difficulties finding personnel with the necessary skills given the specialized demands of our business. We may need to offer increasingly high levels of compensation and benefits to continue to attract the necessary personnel, which could significantly increase our costs. In addition, we may be unable to replace any departing employees in a timely manner. For example, recently, a shortage in factory workers across the U.S. has resulted in a high turnover as workers move employers as they are offered higher wages. Any inability to recruit, train or retain such personnel could hinder our ability to develop and market successful new products and to operate our business, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: Our business could be adversely affected by any significant disruption in relations with our employees.
Subsubsection Text: As of June 30, 2021, we employed 3,148 employees on a full-time basis in 16 countries. 56% of our non-management employees are covered by some form of collective bargaining arrangement at site or national level or a works council agreement. Many of our employees reside in countries in which employment laws provide our employees with significant bargaining power or other rights that may require us to spend more time and expenses when altering or amending employees’ terms of employment or making staff reductions. Most of our employees in Europe are represented by unions or works councils and generally must approve changes in conditions of employment, including salaries and benefits. We may not be able to renew any such collective bargaining agreements or work council agreements on terms similar to current terms, or renegotiate such agreements on acceptable terms. Additionally, in foreign jurisdictions where we operate, national unions and foreign governments may be unable to reach agreements, which could result in work stoppages that are out of our control. Furthermore, if a collective bargaining agreement or a works council agreement is negotiated at higher cost, such costs may need to be absorbed by us, or be passed through to customers in the form of higher prices which may make us less competitive. Further, a labor disturbance or work stoppage at any of our facilities as a result of any changes to our employment terms and conditions or for any other reason could have a material adverse effect on such facility’s ----- operations and, potentially, on our business, results of operations and financial condition. There is a risk that our employees could strike in the future, which could materially adversely impact our business, prospects, results of operations or financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: We may be required to increase our contributions to our pension schemes.
Subsubsection Text: We have pension commitments to our existing and some of our former employees. These commitments are partially covered by pension schemes, pension funds, special purpose funds and insurance policies. The amount of obligations is based on certain actuarial assumptions, including discount factors, life expectancy, pension trends and future salary development as well as expected interest rates applicable to the applicable plan, scheme or fund assets. As of June 30, 2021, our total provisions for pensions amounted to €18 million. If the actual results deviate from these assumptions, this could result in a considerable increase of the pension commitments and thus to higher allocations to pension reserves in future years and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In Brazil, United Kingdom, Germany, Norway, we sponsor defined benefit plans which provide retirement savings benefits to eligible employees. Generally, employees are eligible to participate in the plan upon hire. The plans are subject to employment and taxation rules and regulations in the relevant jurisdictions, including regulations and rules that would require us to increase funding to these plans if they are determined to be underfunded. Any requirement to increase funding to these plans could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: Our total assets include property, plant and equipment. Changes to estimates or projections used to assess the fair value of these, or operating results that are lower than our current estimates, may cause us to incur impairment charges to our property, plants and equipment.
Subsubsection Text: Our total assets include property, plant and equipment. We make certain estimates and projections in connection with impairment analyses for these long-lived assets. We also review the carrying value of these assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value of the asset may not be recoverable. We record an impairment loss when the carrying value of the underlying asset, asset group or reporting unit exceeds its fair value. These calculations require us to make a number of estimates and projections of future results. If these estimates or projections change, we may be required to record additional impairment charges on certain of these assets, which could adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: We may incur goodwill and intangible asset impairment charges. Significant impairment of our goodwill and intangible assets could materially impact our financial position and results of our operations.
Subsubsection Text: We carry a significant goodwill balance on our balance sheet primarily as a result of the business combination with Reichhold. We record goodwill in connection with the excess of the purchase price over the fair value of the identifiable assets and the liabilities acquired and contingent liabilities assumed in business combinations. Our goodwill accounted for 4.53%, 4.33% and 4.59% of our total assets as of December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively. As of June 30, 2021, our total goodwill, amounted to €65.8 million, representing 3.85% of our total assets. Goodwill is recorded on the date of acquisition and, in accordance with IFRS, is tested for impairment annually and whenever there is any indication of impairment. Impairment may result from, among other things, deterioration in our performance, a decline in expected future cash flows, adverse market conditions, adverse changes in applicable laws and regulations and a variety of other factors. The amount of any impairment must be expensed immediately as a charge to our income statement. The application of a goodwill impairment test requires significant management judgment in preparing relevant projections. If our estimates and judgment are inaccurate, the fair value determined could be inaccurate and the impairment may not be recognized in a timely manner. If the fair value declines, we may need to recognize goodwill impairment in the future, which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations. In addition, we perform valuation of the intangible assets to determine the relative fair value to be assigned to each asset. The intangible assets are expensed or amortized using the straight-line approach over the estimated economic useful lives of the assets. We may record impairments on goodwill or intangible assets in the future or that such impairments will not be material. Any significant impairment losses charged against our goodwill or intangible assets could adversely affect our results of operations or financial condition. -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: If an individual within the Group or a third party acting on behalf of one of our Italian entities (or any of our non-Italian entities operating in Italy) commits certain crimes, the entity may be subject to administrative liability pursuant to 231 Decree and may face the application of sanctions, also on an interim basis, which include fines, confiscation of the proceeds of the crime and—under specific circumstances—a prohibition on contracting with public entities, termination of existing contracts and concessions, revocations or restrictions of licenses.
Subsubsection Text: Our business involves risks associated with, inter alia, safety at the workplace, damages to the environment, fraud, bribery and corruption in managing our operations. Although we maintain internal monitoring systems, we may be unable to detect or prevent all unsafe working conditions, environmental damage, fraud, bribery, corruption or other crimes involving our employees, directors, representative agents or third parties acting on our behalf. We may, therefore, be subject to civil, administrative and criminal penalties and to reputational damage. The involvement or association of our directors, employees or agents with fraud, bribery or corruption and other crimes committed in relation to our activities, or allegations or rumors relating thereto, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Italian corporate entities (and foreign-based corporate entities operating in the Italian territory) may be subject to administrative liability pursuant to 231 Decree in case certain specific crimes are committed in their interest or to their advantage by individuals who have a functional relationship with said corporate entities, such as employees, directors and representatives. Crimes which could cause a corporate entity’s administrative liability pursuant to 231 Decree include, inter alia, those committed when dealing with public administrations (including corruption, bribery, misappropriation of public contributions and fraud to the detriment of the state), corporate crimes, environmental crimes (including environmental pollution (inquinamento ambientale) and environmental disaster (disastro ambientale)), money laundering and self-money laundering (autoriciclaggio), crimes of manslaughter or serious injury in violation of provisions on health and safety at the workplace, and tax crimes. The implementation of Organizational, management and control models (“OMCs”) under 231 Decree along with the appointment of a supervisory body (Organismo di Vigilanza) entrusted with their monitoring, however, provide the foregoing corporate entities with a defense from the administrative liability set forth by 231 Decree. If a crime falling within the scope of 231 Decree is committed by individuals who have a functional relationship with such corporate entities in their interest or to their advantage, the court will examine the OMC implemented by the relevant company and, only if it is considered to be inadequate, ineffectively implemented or insufficiently monitored by the supervisory body, the relevant company could be subject to fines, confiscation of the proceeds of the crime and—if specifically provided for such crime—disqualification sanctions which include: (i) debarment from exercising business; (ii) suspension from, or revocation of, current or future authorizations, licenses, grants which were instrumental to the commission of the crime; (iii) prohibition from contracting with public authorities; (iv) exclusion from subsidies, loans contributions or, where applicable, the revocation of those already granted; and (v) prohibition on publicizing goods or services. The duration of these disqualifications sanctions usually ranges from a minimum of three months to a maximum of two years (in very serious cases, however, some of these disqualifications sanctions can be applied permanently). Moreover, under Italian law any Office of the Public Prosecutor is subject to a constitutional duty to initiate criminal investigations as soon as it becomes aware that a crime might have been committed. This implies that, regardless of the apparent merits of a case, if an individual having a functional relationship with an Italian corporate entity (or a foreign-based corporate entity operating in Italy) is deemed to have committed a crime falling within the scope of 231 Decree in its interest or to its advantage, both that individual and the relevant subsidiary will face criminal investigations. Furthermore, pending these criminal investigations, if serious evidence is gathered by the Office of the Public Prosecutor to sustain that the corporate entity is liable in connection with a crime and there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that it might relapse into the wrongdoing, a criminal judge may order the application of any of the aforementioned sanctions as interim measures. Polynt S.p.A. and Reichhold S.r.l. have both implemented an OMC; as previously noted, however, the adoption of such compliance system does not in itself preclude the application of sanctions under 231 Decree in case a crime falling within the scope of 231 Decree is committed by individuals who have a functional relationship with such corporate entities in their interest or to their advantage and their OMCs are considered to be inadequate, ineffectively implemented or insufficiently monitored by their supervisory bodies. ----- If, therefore, Polynt S.p.A. and Reichhold S.r.l. (or any of our non-Italian entities operating in Italy) are found liable under 231 Decree and disqualifications sanctions are imposed in connection with a specific crime, their authorizations, licenses, concessions and financing agreements may be terminated (or our ability to draw under financing agreements may be suspended) and they may face temporary or permanent suspension of the operations, debarment from contracting with public authorities and debarment or cross-debarment from public funding, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. Any proceeding relating to alleged crimes falling within the scope of 231 Decree, even if it ultimately discharges the relevant entity, could be costly and could divert management’s attention away from other aspects of our business. Any such proceedings may also cause adverse publicity and reputational harm and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. For example, following a workplace injury occurred in 2017 on Polynt’s S.p.A.’s premises, a criminal proceeding for alleged culpable injuries was initiated against two managers of the Group, which resulted in a first-instance acquittal. Such acquittal is still subject to a potential appeal by the relevant Public Prosecutor Office and the allegedly culpable events that were the subject of this proceeding may still lead to a 231 Decree proceeding against Polynt S.p.A. itself, pursuant to applicable Italian legislation.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to tax audits. Tax laws or the interpretation or application of tax laws could change in a way that is unfavorable to us.
Subsubsection Text: Due to the global nature of our business, we are subject to income taxes in multiple jurisdictions. Significant judgment and estimation is required in determining our worldwide provision for income taxes, including assessments of future earnings which could impact the valuation of our deferred tax assets. In the ordinary course of our business, there are various transactions and calculations, including intercompany transactions and cross-jurisdictional transfer pricing, for which the ultimate tax determination is uncertain or otherwise subject to interpretation. We are regularly audited by tax authorities who may disagree with our tax estimates or judgments. Although we believe our tax estimates are reasonable, the final determination of any such tax audits could differ from our historical income tax provisions and accruals and any additional tax liabilities resulting from such final determination could have a material adverse effect on our financial position. In addition, we are and may in the future become involved in proceedings with national or regional tax authorities. While we attempt to assess in advance the likelihood of any adverse judgments or outcomes to these proceedings or claims, it is difficult to predict final outcomes with any degree of certainty. The levels of taxation to which our operations are subject could increase in the future. Any such future increases in the levels of taxation, or the implementation of any new taxes to which our operations will be subject, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. We are also subject to intercompany pricing laws, including those relating to the flow of funds among our Group pursuant to, for example, loan agreements, licensing agreements or other arrangements. In addition, given that our headquarters are located in Italy, certain members of our group are subject to Italian tax law, whose compliance and administration is generally a complex process that often requires taxpayers to make subjective determinations in relation to their application. For example, we currently have a pending claim with the Italian Tax Authority, resulting out of an audit for the 2014, 2015 2016 and 2017 fiscal years with respect to Polynt S.p.A. for certain additional tax payments allegedly due. The Group has allocated €6.2 million as provision for such matter as of June 30, 2021. Adverse developments in tax laws or regulations (including future Italian legislation, judicial or administrative changes or interpretations with respect to tax laws to which our business is subject) could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. In addition, the relevant authorities may disagree with the positions we have taken or intend to take regarding the tax and social security treatment or characterization of any of our transactions, including the treatment or characterization of our indebtedness, including the Notes, existing and future intercompany loans and guarantees or the deduction of interest expenses. We may also fail to comply with tax laws inadvertently or through reasons beyond our control. If any of these circumstances were to occur, it could result in lengthy legal disputes and, ultimately, in the payment of substantial amounts of tax, interest and penalties, which could have a material effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition. In such cases, it may be necessary to defend our tax filings in court, if a reasonable settlement cannot be reached with the relevant tax authorities, and any ensuing litigation could be costly and distract management from the other affairs of our business. Tax audits and investigations by the ----- competent tax authorities may generate negative publicity which could harm our brand and reputation with sponsors and commercial partners.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: Repatriating cash from certain subsidiaries could have negative tax consequences. Our large group of companies may give rise to inefficiencies.
Subsubsection Text: Our multi-subsidiary corporate structure, spanning across a number of different jurisdictions, is susceptible to administrative inefficiencies and, in certain jurisdictions, regulatory restrictions for moving cash within the group and we do not have a Group-wide cash pooling arrangement in place. In addition, some of our subsidiaries are in jurisdictions which are subject to significant restrictions on the flow of capital abroad, including exchange control, limitations on shareholder loans and capital controls (for example, China or India), which may restrict our ability to use cash from parts of our operations to support others. For example, we may require an extended period of time to liquidate the relevant entity under applicable law before being able to repatriate the total compensation due by the Chinese local government for the Changzhou Site’s Closure and Relocation, accordingly, as of June 30, 2021, we had CNY 86 million (approximately €11.2 million) of restricted cash held in China. The operation of our business through multiple subsidiaries results in certain administrative expense that we would not incur if all of our operations were conducted within a leaner structure. Expenses arise from more complex record keeping and internal procedures for allocating various operating expenses, among our subsidiaries, and in the preparation of our financial statements. Until we are able to eliminate or combine certain subsidiaries, these companies will add to our cost structure and these costs may place us at a competitive disadvantage to groups that are more efficiently organized than we are.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to adequately protect our intellectual property rights.
Subsubsection Text: Proprietary protection of our products and processes is important to our business success and competitive position, and we have an extensive portfolio of registered patents and trademarks. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we hold (i) 354 patents, and have an additional 107 pending patent applications; (ii) 778 active trademark registrations and 3 pending applications; and (iii) 21 domain names. Our efforts to protect our proprietary rights may be insufficient to prevent others from developing similar products to ours. Despite our efforts, the laws of many foreign countries do not protect our intellectual property rights to the same extent as do the laws of the United States or the European Union. Furthermore, any pending patent application filed by us may not result in an issued patent, or if such patents are issued to us, such patents may not provide meaningful protection against competitors or against competitive technologies. The expiration of a patent or the failure of our patents to protect our formulations, processes, technology or proprietary knowhow could result in intense competition, with consequent erosion of profit margins. In addition, our competitors and any other third parties may obtain patents that restrict or preclude our ability to lawfully manufacture and market our products in a competitive manner, which could materially adversely affect our business, prospects, results of operations or financial condition. 23 of our patents are expected to expire within the next two years, including those related to low VOC low tack gel coat resins, and low VOC vinyl ester resin and applications. In addition, because of the rapid pace of technological change, the confidentiality of patent applications before their publication (typically 18 months from filing) and/or uncertainty in predicting the outcome of proceedings relating to the ownership or the scope of protection of patents relating to certain technologies, competitors may be unexpectedly issued patents that we do not anticipate. Similar patents issued by competitors could reduce the value of our product pipeline or, to the extent they cover key technologies on which we have unknowingly relied, require us to seek to obtain licenses or cease using the technology and we cannot ensure that we would be able to obtain such licenses on acceptable terms or at all. We also rely significantly upon unpatented proprietary know-how and continuing technological innovation, along with other trade secrets, to develop and maintain our competitive position. Third parties (including our competitors) may develop such knowledge or technology independently without violating our trade secret rights. While it is our policy to enter into confidentiality agreements with our employees and third parties to protect our intellectual property: (i) our confidentiality agreements may be breached; (ii) such agreements may not provide meaningful protection for our trade secrets or proprietary know-how; or (iii) adequate remedies may not be available in the event of an unauthorized use or disclosure of these trade secrets and know-how. ----- Insufficient protection of intellectual property may limit our ability to make use of technological advantages or result in a reduction of future profits. This may cause competitive restrictions and have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition or results of operations. In addition, according to EU Directive 2016/943/UE on trade secrets, the failure to adopt adequate security measures to protect confidential information may weaken trade secrets protection recognized by law.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Title: If we are subject to a claim for infringing on intellectual property rights of third parties, it may be costly and time-consuming, and an unfavorable outcome in any litigation would harm our business.
Subsubsection Text: The use of intellectual property may expose us to ongoing litigation, regarding either intellectual property claims made by or against us. We may spend significant time and effort and incur significant litigation costs if we are required to defend ourselves against intellectual property rights claims brought against us, regardless of whether the claims have merit. If we are found to have infringed on the patents or other intellectual property rights of others, we may be subject to substantial claims for damages, which could materially impact our business, financial condition and results of operations. We may also be required to cease development, use or sale of the relevant products or processes, or we may be required to obtain a license on the disputed rights, which may not be available on commercially reasonable terms, if at all. In addition, where we initiate litigation, such legal activity is costly and may divert technical and management personnel from their ordinary responsibilities. Furthermore, we may not prevail in any such litigation or proceeding. A determination in an intellectual property litigation or proceeding that results in a finding of a non-infringement by others of our intellectual property or an invalidation of our patents may result in the use by competitors of our technologies or processes and sale by competitors of products that resemble our products, which may adversely affect our ability to compete as well as create increased supply and corresponding downward pricing pressure.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Relocation”), which resulted in a decrease in our sales volumes in Asia in 2019.
Subsubsection Text: If any of the risks described above materialize, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition or results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our historical financial information may not be representative of our future results.
Subsubsection Text: Our Consolidated Financial Statements have not been adjusted to reflect the impact of any changes to the statement of profit or loss, statements of financial position or statement of cash flows that might occur as a result of purchase accounting adjustments to be applied as a result of the Transactions. However, the Issuers will account for the Acquisition using the acquisition method of accounting under IFRS and will apply purchase accounting adjustments in connection with the Acquisition to the financial statements for accounting periods subsequent to the Acquisition Closing Date. The application of purchase accounting could result in different carrying values for existing assets and liabilities and we may add additional assets to our statement of financial position, which may include, inter alia, intangible assets, such as goodwill, brand name, customer relationships and software. We may also recognize different amortization and depreciation expenses. Due to these and other potential adjustments, if we provide consolidated financial statements for periods after the Acquisition Closing Date at the level of the Issuers, our future financial statements could be materially different once the adjustments are made and may not be comparable to our Consolidated Financial Statements included in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The Acquisition is subject to certain conditions and risks and, if it is not consummated, the Issuers will redeem the Notes at 100% of the issue price, plus accrued and unpaid interest which means holders of the Notes may not obtain the return they expect on the Notes. In addition, the Issuers may not have sufficient funds to pay all of the amounts due to the holders of the Notes in the event of a Special Mandatory Redemption.
Subsubsection Text: On June 29, 2021, SCIL II entered into a sale and purchase agreement (the “SPA”) to acquire the entire issued share capital of the Target from SCIL. Before the Acquisition Closing Date, it is expected that SCIL II will transfer its rights and obligations under the SPA to the Parent pursuant to a novation agreement to be entered into among SCIL, the Parent and SCIL II Completion of the Acquisition is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including antitrust and foreign investment approvals (which have all been obtained), as well as the performance of certain closing actions. Pending completion of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds from the Offering (the “Escrowed Property”) into the Escrow Accounts on the Issue Date. The release of the Escrowed Property is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within one business day from the Acquisition Closing Date) to pay such consideration. We do not yet know whether the Acquisition will be successfully completed. If the conditions precedent to the Acquisition are not satisfied or waived, as applicable, by the Escrow Longstop Date, then the Acquisition will not be consummated (unless the parties agree otherwise). If the conditions to the release of the Escrowed Property, as more fully described under “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special ----- _Mandatory Redemption” have not been satisfied on or prior to the Escrow Longstop Date or upon the_ occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a Special Mandatory Redemption as described in “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and you may not obtain the return you expect to receive on the Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Accounts may not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on the Escrow Equity Commitment.
Subsubsection Text: The Escrowed Property will be limited initially to the gross proceeds of the Offering and will not be sufficient to pay the Special Mandatory Redemption Price, which is equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the Special Mandatory Redemption Date. See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory _Redemption” and In the event that the Special Mandatory Redemption Price payable upon such Special_ Mandatory Redemption exceeds the amount of the Escrowed Property, HoldCo will be required to fund the difference between the Special Mandatory Redemption Price and the amount of the Escrowed Property, including accrued interest and additional amounts (if any) due with respect to the Notes from the Issue Date to the Special Mandatory Redemption Date and any negative interest which has accrued on the Escrowed Property, by seeking to enforce the Escrow Equity Commitment. Holders of the Notes will not have any direct right to enforce the Escrow Equity Commitment, and must rely on the Issuers’respective rights to enforcement under the Escrow Equity Commitment. There can be no assurance that the relevant entities providing such commitment will have sufficient funds to make this payment, and the Issuers may not have access to the funds necessary to allow them to pay the full amount of the required redemption price in the event of a Special Mandatory Redemption. Your decision to invest in the Notes is made at the time of purchase. Changes in the business or financial position of the business of the Group, or the terms of the Acquisition, between the Issue Date and the Escrow Release Date, may have an impact on our creditworthiness, and you will not be able to rescind your decision to invest in the Notes as a result thereof.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The Issuers do not currently control the Group’s business and will not control the Group’s business until the Acquisition Closing Date.
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuers do not, directly or indirectly, hold any issued and outstanding ordinary shares of any entity included in, or any of the assets of, the Group’s business. As a result, the Issuers’ ability to influence the Group’s business’s management is limited. In particular: - the Group’s management may not operate the business until the Acquisition Closing Date in the same way that the Issuers and the Sponsor (which currently indirectly jointly controls the Group and will have control of the Group as a result of the Acquisition) would; - much of the information contained in this Offering Memorandum relating to the Group’s business had to be derived from public sources and, in the case of certain additional information relating to the Group’s business, has been provided to the Issuers by the Group, and the Issuers have relied on such information that is publicly available or was supplied to them by the Group in their preparation of this Offering Memorandum; - the Acquisition has required, and will likely continue to require, substantial time and focus from the Group’s management, which could adversely affect their ability to operate the Group; and - the Group’s management is required to manage the Group under its own responsibility and in a manner that is in the best interest of the Group. We cannot assure you that the Acquisition will be consummated given it is dependent on a number of closing conditions, including receipt of antitrust and regulatory approvals. If we are not able to satisfy or waive these conditions, as applicable, the Acquisition will not be consummated.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The Acquisition may entitle our customers and certain other business partners of the Group to terminate their agreements as a result of change of control provisions.
Subsubsection Text: The Acquisition will constitute a change of control under certain agreements entered into by the Group. In particular five customer contracts in relation to the supply of UPRs and Composites and four supplier contracts in relation to the supply of raw materials derived from crude oil and other petroleum feedstocks contain change of control provisions. One agreement contains an indirect change of control provision which will be triggered by the Transactions, while the others contain ambiguous wording and therefore it cannot be excluded that the change of control clauses contained therein will be triggered by the Transactions. ----- Counterparties under these agreements may be entitled to terminate their agreements with us. We have not requested waivers from the counterparties for the Transaction, therefore some of these counterparties may exercise their termination rights, which could have an adverse effect on our business, prospects financial position or results of operations, or could take the opportunity to renegotiate terms and conditions and demand for more favorable terms than those currently in force. Moreover, we are conducting informal discussions with the relevant lenders in relation to a waiver of any acceleration clause that may be triggered by the Transaction, but not sought to obtain any consents as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, also in light of the fact that the Transactions entails a change from joint to single control of the Group, with no new investors. As of June 30, 2021, the total amount outstanding under the Local Facilities which include an acceleration clause which may be triggered by the Transactions is €21.0 million.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We have incurred, and to incur, significant costs in connection with the Transactions.
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Transactions, we have incurred and expect to continue to incur significant costs and expenses, including financial advisory, legal, accounting, consulting and other advisory fees and expenses, and other related expenses. In addition, we may incur significant one-time charges as a result of costs associated with the Transaction. We will not be able to quantify the exact amount of these charges or the period in which they will be incurred until after the Transactions are completed. While we have assumed that a certain level of expenses will be incurred in connection with the Transactions, there are many factors that could affect the total amount or implementation expenses. There may also be additional unanticipated significant costs in connection with the Transaction that we do not anticipate and may not be able to recoup. These costs and expenses could reduce the benefits and income we expect to achieve from the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds.”

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: Our substantial leverage and debt service obligations could materially adversely affect our business, financial position and results of operations and preclude us from satisfying our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: Following the completion of the Transaction, we will be highly leveraged and have significant debt service obligations. As of June 30, 2021, after giving effect to the Transaction, we would have had Total financial indebtedness in the amount of €1,351,591,000 See “Capitalization,” “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements,” and “Description of Notes”. We anticipate that our high leverage will continue to exist for the_ foreseeable future. The degree to which we will be leveraged following completion of the Transaction could have important consequences to holders of the Notes, including: (i) making it more difficult for the Issuers and their subsidiaries to satisfy their respective obligations with respect to the Notes, the SSRCF and other debt and liabilities we may incur; (ii) increasing our vulnerability to, and reducing our flexibility to respond to, general adverse economic and industry conditions; (iii) requiring the dedication of a substantial portion of our cash flow from operations to the payment of principal of, and interest on, our indebtedness, thereby reducing the availability of such cash flow to fund working capital, capital expenditures, acquisitions, joint ventures, product research and development, or other general corporate purposes; (iv) restricting us from pursuing acquisitions or exploiting business opportunities; (v) limiting our flexibility in planning for, or reacting to, changes in our business, the competitive environment and the industry in which we operate; (vi) negatively impacting credit terms with our suppliers and other creditors; (vii) increasing our exposure to interest rate increases because some of our indebtedness bears a floating rate of interest; (viii) placing us at a competitive disadvantage compared to our competitors that are not as highly leveraged; and (ix) limiting our ability to obtain additional financing to fund future operations, capital expenditures, business opportunities, acquisitions and other general corporate purposes and increasing the cost of any future borrowings. Any of these or other consequences or events could have a material adverse effect on our ability to satisfy our obligations, including under the Notes and the SSRCF and Existing ABL Facility.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: The Parent is a holding company that has no revenue generating operations of its own and will depend on cash from the operating companies of the Group to be able to make payments on the Notes. The US Co-Issuer is a special purpose vehicle which will have no assets and no subsdiaries until the succesfull completion of the Post- Transaction Reorganization, which we cannot assure you will be completed on a timely basis or at all.
Subsubsection Text: The Parent is a holding company with no business operations other than management of the equity interests it holds in its subsidiaries. The US Co-Issuer is a special purpose vehicle and currently has no subsidiaries and will have no assets, other than the receivables under the Notes Proceeds Loan, until the successful completion of the Post-Transaction Reorganization. Following completion of the Acquisition (and ----- in the case of the US Co-Issuer, completion of the Post-Transaction Reorganization), the Issuers will be dependent upon the cash flow from their operating subsidiaries in the form of dividends or other distributions or payments, including the receviables under the Proceeds Loans, in order to meet its obligations, including their obligations under the Notes. Given our international operations, we have a large number of operating subsidiaries and business participations, which individually contribute to our results. The amounts of dividends and distributions available to the Issuers and to service the intra-group loans will depend on the profitability and cash flows of their subsidiaries and the ability of each of those subsidiaries to declare dividends under applicable law, including applicable tax laws or transfer profits under profit and loss transfer agreements, if applicable. The Issuers’ subsidiaries, however, may not be able to, or may not be permitted under applicable law to, make distributions or advance upstream loans to the Issuers to make payments in respect of its indebtedness, including the Notes, which will be subject to the risks described above and could be inefficient from a tax perspective See “Limitations on Validity and Enforcement of the Guarantees and _Security Interests and Certain Insolvenccy Law Considerations.”_ Various agreements governing our debt may restrict and, in some cases may actually prohibit, the ability of these subsidiaries to move cash within their restricted group. Applicable tax laws may also subject such payments to further taxation. Applicable law as well as profit and loss transfer agreements between several entities within the Group may also limit the amounts that some of our subsidiaries will be permitted to pay as dividends or distributions on their equity interests, or even prevent such payments. In particular, the ability of the Issuers’ subsidiaries to pay dividends to the Issuers will generally be limited to the amount of distributable earnings/reserves available to each of them and the ability to pay their respective debt when due. The subsidiaries of the Issuers that do not guarantee the Notes have no obligation to make payments with respect to the Notes. While the Indenture will limit the ability of the Issuers’ subsidiaries to incur consensual restrictions on their ability to pay dividends or make other intercompany payments, these limitations are subject to significant qualifications and exceptions, including exceptions for restrictions imposed by applicable law. We cannot assure you that we will be able to accomplish the Post-Transaction Reorganization on a timely basis or on satisfactory terms, if at all. In such an event, the US Co-Issuer will have no assets and will not be able to rely on any distributions from operating subsidiaries. Moreover, any such distribution made from operating subsidiaries to the Issuers (as applicable) may be subject to higher taxes or greater leakage when servicing interest on our debt and therefore we may not have sufficient assets to repay any portion or all of our debt. Finally, our ability to deduct interest expense would be more limited which will, in turn, reduce the amount of cash available to service the interest on our debt, incuding the Notes. Even if we are able to accomplish the Post-Transaction Reorganization as planned, distributions made from certain operating subsidiaries to the Issuers may be subject to taxation or corporate law restrictions, reducing the amount of cash available to the Group to service the interest on on our debt, incuding the Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: The Issuers are indirectly controlled by Black Diamond whose interests may be inconsistent with the interests of the holders of Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Issuers are indirectly owned and controlled by Black Diamond, which also controls, together with certain funds affiliated with Investindustrial, the Group, and will become the sole indirect owner of the Group upon completion of the Acquisition. See “Principal Shareholders”. As a result, Black Diamond will have, directly or indirectly, the power to affect our legal and capital structure as well as the ability to elect and change our management and to approve other changes to our operations and to influence the outcome of matters requiring action by our shareholders. Black Diamond’s interests in certain circumstances may conflict with your interests as noteholders, particularly if we encounter financial difficulties or are unable to pay our debts when due. For example, the shareholders, which will under the control of Black Diamond, could vote to cause us to incur additional indebtedness. Black Diamond is in the business of making investments in companies and may acquire and hold interests in businesses that compete directly or indirectly with us. Black Diamond may also pursue acquisition opportunities that are complementary to our business and, as a result, those acquisition opportunities may not be available to us. In addition, Black Diamond may have an interest in pursuing transactions that, in its judgment, could enhance its equity investments, even though such transactions might involve risks to you as a holder of the Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: We may incur substantially more debt in the future, which may make it difficult for us to service our debt, including the Notes, and impair our ability to operate our businesses.
Subsubsection Text: Despite our substantial leverage, we may incur substantial additional debt in the future. The Indenture and the SSRCF Agreement permit the incurrence of significant additional debt thereunder. The Indenture ----- and the SSRCF Agreement also permit us to incur a substantial amount of indebtedness at subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Notes and to incur indebtedness that shares in the Collateral or that benefits from security interests over assets that do not secure the Notes. Any debt that our subsidiaries incur could be structurally or effectively senior to the Notes to the extent that such subsidiaries do not guarantee the Notes or such debt is secured by liens that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such debt, and other debt could be secured or could mature prior to the Notes. Although the SSRCF Agreement and the Indenture will contain restrictions on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, these restrictions are subject to a number of significant qualifications and exceptions, and under certain circumstances the amount of indebtedness that could be incurred in compliance with these restrictions could be substantial. If new debt is added to our existing debt, the related risks that we now face would increase. In addition, the SSRCF Agreement and the Indenture will not prevent us from incurring obligations that do not constitute indebtedness under those agreements. Our inability to service our debt could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and our ability to fulfil our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: Following completion of the Transactions, we will be subject to restrictive covenants that will limit our operating and financial flexibility.
Subsubsection Text: The SSRCF Agreement and the Indenture will contain covenants which impose significant operating and financial restrictions on us. These agreements will limit our ability to, among other things: (i) incur or guarantee additional indebtedness or issue certain preferred stock; (ii) make certain restricted payments and investments; (iii) transfer or sell assets; (iv) enter into transactions with affiliates; (v) create or incur certain liens; (vi) create or incur restrictions on the ability of our subsidiaries to pay dividends or to make other payments to us; (vii) take certain actions that would impair the security interests in the Collateral granted for the benefit of the holders of the Notes; (viii) merge, consolidate or transfer all or substantially all of our assets; and (ix) pay or redeem subordinated debt or equity. All of these limitations will be subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of Notes—Certain Covenants.” The covenants to which we will be subject could limit our ability to finance our future operations and capital needs and our ability to pursue business opportunities and activities that may be in our interest. In addition, the SSRCF Agreement will require us to comply with certain affirmative and negative covenants while amounts under the SSRCF remain outstanding. Furthermore, the SSRCF Agreement will require us to comply with a consolidated net leverage ratio financial covenant while amounts exceeding a certain threshold remain outstanding under the SSRCF. See “Description of _Certain Financing _Arrangements—SSRCF.”Our ability to meet the financial ratio under the SSRCF Agreement may be affected_ by events beyond our control, and we cannot assure you that we will meet such financial ratio. A breach of any of the covenants or restrictions under the SSRCF Agreement, including if we fail to comply with the financial ratio thereunder, could result in an event of default under the SSRCF Agreement. Upon the occurrence of an event of default that is continuing under the SSRCF Agreement, subject to certain applicable thresholds, cure rights and cure period, the relevant creditors could cancel the availability of the SSRCF and elect to declare all amounts outstanding under the SSRCF, together with accrued interest, immediately due and payable. In addition, a default under the SSRCF, could lead to an event of default and acceleration under other debt instruments that contain cross default or cross acceleration provisions, including the Indenture. If our creditors, including the creditors under the SSRCF, accelerate the payment of those amounts, we cannot assure you that our assets and the assets of our subsidiaries would be sufficient to repay in full those amounts, to satisfy all other liabilities of our subsidiaries that would be due and payable and to make payments to enable us to repay the Notes. In addition, if we are unable to repay those amounts, our creditors could proceed against any Collateral granted to them to secure repayment of those amounts.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: We will require a significant amount of cash to service our debt and sustain our operations, which we may not be able to generate or raise.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to make principal or interest payments when due on our indebtedness, including the SSRCF and our obligations under the Notes, and to fund our ongoing operations or expansion plans, will depend on our future performance and ability to generate cash, which, to a certain extent, is subject to the success of our business strategy as well as general economic, financial, competitive, legislative, legal, regulatory and other factors, as well as other factors discussed in these “Risk Factors,” many of which are beyond our control. We cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations, that currently anticipated growth, cost savings or efficiencies will be realized or that future debt financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs including the repayment at maturity of the then outstanding amount under the SSRCF. At the ----- maturity of the SSRCF, the Notes or any other debt that we may incur, if we do not have sufficient cash flows from operations and other capital resources to pay our debt obligations, or to fund our other liquidity needs, we may be required to refinance or restructure our indebtedness. Moreover, we are in the process of terminating the Existing ABL Facility and are in discussions about entering into a similar asset based secured revolving facility with new lenders. However, if we are not able to replace the Existing ABL Facility, or we are not able to obtain a waiver from the lenders thereunder, should the change of control provision be triggered before the termination of the Existing ABL Facility, our ability to fund our ongoing operations or expansion plans could be materially adversely affected. If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced to: (i) sell assets; (ii) obtain additional debt or equity capital; or (iii) restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity. The type, timing and terms of any future financing, restructuring, asset sales or other capital raising transactions will depend on our cash needs and the prevailing conditions in the financial markets. We cannot assure you that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory terms, if at all. In such an event, we may not have sufficient assets to repay any portion or all of our debt. Any failure to make payments on the Notes on a timely basis would likely result in a reduction of our credit rating, which could also harm our ability to incur additional indebtedness. In addition, the terms of our debt, including the Notes and the SSRCF, will limit, and any future debt may limit, our ability to pursue any of these alternatives. Any refinancing of our debt could be at higher interest rates and may require us to comply with more onerous covenants, which could further restrict our business, financial position and results of operations. There can be no assurances that any assets that we could be required to dispose of could be sold or that, if sold, the timing of such sale and the amount of proceeds realized from such sale would be acceptable. If we are unsuccessful in any of these efforts, we may not have sufficient cash to meet our obligations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: The Notes will not be initially secured by all of the Collateral.
Subsubsection Text: On the Issue Date, and until up to 120 days after the Acquisition Closing Date (if such event occurs at all), the Notes will not be secured by all of the Collateral, as further described under “Description of the Senior _Secured Notes—Security.” On the Issue Date and prior to release from Escrow, the Notes will be secured by_ the Escrowed Property pursuant to the Escrow Charge. On the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain significant limitations under local law, on a first-priority basis, by security interests in the Issue Date Collateral, which Issue Date Collateral will also secure the obligations under the SSRCF on a pari passu basis. We will agree in the Indenture to take such necessary actions to secure the Notes on (or as soon as reasonably possible after), subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain significant limitations under local law and substantially simultaneously with the obligations under the SSRCF on a pari passu basis, by first-priority security interests in the SSN Post-Acquisition Date Collateral Collateral on the Acquistion Closing Closing Date and the SSN Post-Closing Collateral within 120 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date, respectively. There can be no assurance, however, that we will be successful in procuring such liens within the time periods specified, the failure of which would result in an “event of default”under the Indenture. The security interests will be limited to the same extent as those under the SSRCF and otherwise as set forth under “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and _Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations,”which limitations could be significant. See also_ “—Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral—Corporate benefit, financial assistance laws, _capital maintenance and other limitations on the Guarantees and the Collateral may adversely affect the validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the Collateral.” It should be noted that if a guarantee or a security_ interest granted by a Guarantor or security provider in certain jurisdictions is granted or perfected after the secured obligation arose, such guarantee or security interest may be subject to clawback provisions under applicable local insolvency laws. See “ Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security _Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: Liabilities under the SSRCF are super senior liabilities in accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, creditors under the SSRCF and counterparties to certain hedging obligations and future indebtedness permitted to be incurred under the terms of the Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement ranking pari passu with the SSRCF are entitled to be repaid with proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral in priority over the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Intercreditor Agreement includes provisions governing the sharing of proceeds from enforcement of the Collateral. Such enforcement proceeds are required to be turned over to the Security Agent. The Security ----- Agent is required to apply turned over amounts and other recoveries by the Security Agent from enforcement actions toward discharging the super senior obligations (if any) (including, among others, those under the SSRCF, certain hedging obligations and future indebtedness that may be secured on a super senior basis, pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement (the “Super Senior Liabilities”)) in priority to applying any such amounts toward discharging the Notes. As such, you may not benefit from amounts recovered from an enforcement of the Collateral if the then outstanding claims under such Super Senior Liabilities are greater than the proceeds recovered. Any proceeds remaining from an enforcement sale of Collateral will, after all obligations under such Super Senior Liabilities have been discharged, be applied pro rata in repayment of the Notes and any other indebtedness that ranks pari passu with the Notes. Furthermore, claims of our secured creditors that are secured by assets that do not also secure the Notes will have priority with respect to such assets over the claims of holders of the Notes to the extent of the value of such assets. As such, the claims of the holders of the Notes will be effectively subordinated to the rights of such secured creditors to the extent of the value of the assets securing such indebtedness. Furthermore, assets pledged to secure the ABL will not also be pledged to secure the Notes or the Super Senior Liabilities.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: The Issuers, the Guarantors and the other Collateral providers will have control over the Collateral, and the sale of particular assets could reduce the pool of assets securing the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Security Documents relating to the Notes will allow the Issuers, the Guarantors and the other Collateral providers in the ordinary course of business to remain in possession of, retain exclusive control over, freely operate, and collect, invest and dispose of any income from the Collateral to the extent that it relates to their assets. So long as no acceleration event has occurred and subject to certain conditions, the Issuers, the Guarantors and the other Collateral providers may, among other things, without any release or consent by the Security Agent, conduct ordinary course activities with respect to the Collateral, such as selling, factoring, abandoning or otherwise disposing of certain Collateral and making ordinary course cash payments, including repayments of indebtedness.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: Holders of the Notes may not control certain decisions regarding the Collateral.
Subsubsection Text: The obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees thereof will, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, be secured on a first ranking basis with security interests over the Collateral that will also secure our obligations under the Super Senior Liabilities (including the SSRCF). The Indenture also permits the Collateral to secure additional indebtedness in accordance with the terms thereof and the Intercreditor Agreement. The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the Security Agent may refrain from enforcing the Transaction Security unless the Security Agent receives enforcement instructions from the relevant creditor instructing group. Any instructions provided by a relevant creditor instructing group must be in accordance with the security enforcement principles provided in the Intercreditor Agreement. Instructions in relation to the enforcement of the Transaction Security may be delivered to the Security Agent by any of (i) the creditors representing in aggregate more than 50% of the aggregate super senior credit participations of the creditors of the Super Senior Liabilities (which includes the lenders under the SSRCF) (the “Majority Super Senior Creditors”), or (ii) the creditors representing at least 50% of (A) the aggregate senior secured credit participations of the creditors of the Senior Secured Notes Liabilities (which includes holders of the Notes) and the Future Pari Passu Liabilities and (B) the aggregate senior secured credit participations of the creditors of the Hedging Liabilities that are not Super Senior Hedging Liabilities (the “Majority Senior Secured Creditors”). If the Majority Super Senior Creditors or the Majority Senior Secured Creditors wish to instruct the Security Agent to commence enforcement of any Transaction Security, the creditor representative(s) (each a “Creditor Representative”) of the relevant creditor instructing group shall notify the Security Agent and the creditor representative of each other creditor of the Priority Liabilities. Following delivery of proposed enforcement instructions, the Creditor Representatives of the Majority Super Senior Creditors and the Majority Senior Secured Creditors will consult with each other in good faith as to the manner of enforcement for a period of 15 days (or shorter period as the relevant parties may agree) (the “Consultation Period”) with a view to coordinating the instructions to be given by the relevant creditor instructing group and agreeing the strategy for enforcement unless: (i) the Majority Super Senior Creditors and the Majority Senior Secured Creditors otherwise agree; (ii) there is an absence of conflicting enforcement instructions; (iii) an insolvency event has occurred in relation to any debtor or other member of the Group and the Transaction Security has become enforceable as a result; or (iv) one of the relevant instructing groups determines in good faith that no consultation period or, as the case may be, a shorter consultation period is necessary in order to avoid impairing the value which would be realized on enforcement of the Transaction Security to an extent that would prevent the discharge of the Super Senior Liabilities in full or have a material ----- adverse effect on the ability to effect an enforcement or distressed disposal. In circumstances where (iv) applies, any instructions delivered by a Creditor Representative must be limited to those necessary to protect or preserve the interests of the relevant creditor instructing group on behalf of which it acts as a Creditor Representative and the Security Agent will act in accordance with the instructions first received.
