An arrangement or transaction, or series of arrangements or transactions, shall be regarded as artificial to the extent that it is not put into place for valid commercial reasons, which reflect economic reality; and/or (iii) in case a related entity is from a Dutch tax perspective regarded the recipient of the (Deemed) Payments, whereas such related recipient entity is not regarded as the recipient (gerechtigde) thereof pursuant to the laws of the country in which such entity is (deemed) resident or pursuant to the laws of which such entity is established (opgericht). No additional amounts shall be payable with respect to any Note or Guarantee in relation to the withholding or deduction for or on account of any taxes imposed or to be withheld in the Netherlands pursuant to the Dutch Withholding Tax Act 2021 (Wet bronbelasting 2021) as published in the Official Gazette (Staatsblad) Stb. 2019, 513 of December 27, 2019. See “Description of Senior Secured Notes — Withholding _Taxes”._

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Debt”) mirroring the obligations of the Issuers and the Guarantors owed to holders of the Notes under or in
Subsubsection Title: You may face foreign currency exchange as a result of investing in the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Euro Notes will be denominated and payable in Euro. If you are a U.S. investor, an investment in the Notes will entail foreign exchange related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes in the value of the euro relative to the U.S. dollar because of economic, political and other factors over which we have no control. Depreciation of the euro against the U.S. dollar could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to you on a U.S. dollar basis.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Debt”) mirroring the obligations of the Issuers and the Guarantors owed to holders of the Notes under or in
Subsubsection Title: The Indenture will not be qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended.
Subsubsection Text: The Indenture will not be required to, and will not be, qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended (the “TIA”) and will not incorporate or include and will not be subject to any of the provisions of the TIA. Consequently, the holders of Notes will not be entitled to the protections provided under the TIA to holders of debt securities issued under a qualified indenture, including those respecting preferential collections by the trustee or conflicting interests of the trustee. See “Description of Notes.” -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Debt”) mirroring the obligations of the Issuers and the Guarantors owed to holders of the Notes under or in
Subsubsection Text: connection with the Indenture (“Principal Obligations”). All or part of the pledges and other security interests in such jurisdictions will be granted to the Security Agent as security interests for the Parallel Debt and will not directly secure the Principal Obligations. Under the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement, the Parallel Debt will be at all times in the same amount and payable at the same time as the Principal Obligations and any payment in respect of the Principal Obligations shall discharge the corresponding Parallel Debt and any payment in respect of the Parallel Debt shall discharge the corresponding Principal Obligations. In respect of the security interests granted to secure the Parallel Debt, the holders of the Notes will not have direct security ----- interests and will not be entitled to take enforcement actions in respect of such security interests except through the relevant Security Agent. Therefore, the holders of the Notes will bear the risk of insolvency or bankruptcy of the relevant Security Agent. In addition, the Parallel Debt construct has not been tested under law in certain of these jurisdictions and to the extent that the security interests in the Collateral created under the Parallel Debt construct are not validly granted, are unenforceable or are successfully challenged by other parties, holders of the Notes will not receive any proceeds from an enforcement of such security interests in the Collateral. See “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security Interests and _Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_ For a more detailed description of various limitations on the security under Italian law, see “Limitations _on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations—Italy.”_ In Spain, security interests are construed as ancillary rights to the secured obligation(s); thus, for a security interest to be validly perfected it must be accepted by the creditors of the secured obligations or by a third party duly authorized to act on their behalf, and legal title over a security interest must be held directly by the creditors of such secured obligations or such third party duly authorized to act on their behalf. Therefore, and since the concepts of trustee and security agent are not expressly recognized under Spanish law, there is no assurance that Spanish courts would recognize the acceptance of the security interests in the Collateral by the Security Agent for the benefit of the holders of the Notes or the perfection or creation of the security interests in the Collateral. Moreover, the enforcement of the Collateral by the Security Agent may be made conditional to the existence of a power of attorney granted by each of the secured parties in favor of the Security Agent for such purpose and such power of attorney should be duly notarized by a local notary and affixed with an apostille (or be legalized before the Spanish consulate authorities in cases where the country of the secured party is not a party to The Hague Convention). If no such power of attorney is provided or such power of attorney is not valid, the Security Agent may not be able to enforce the Collateral in Spain on behalf of the holders of the Notes. Therefore, there could be a delay in the enforcement of the Collateral in Spain while the Security Agent obtains such powers. In addition, in Spain, it may be the case that for the actual enforcement of the Collateral, each of the secured parties benefiting from such Collateral would have to evidence its title to the secured obligations, ratify such Collateral and accept the benefit of the security interest in their respective names by executing a public deed through duly appointed representatives by means of notarized and apostilled powers of attorney. See “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees _and Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Text: On June 29, 2021, Speciality Chemicals International II Limited (“SCIL II”) entered into a sale and purchase agreement (the “SPA”) to acquire the entire issued share capital of the Target from Speciality Chemicals International Limited (“SCIL”). Before the Acquisition Closing Date, it is expected that SCIL II will transfer its rights and obligations under the SPA to the Parent pursuant to a novation agreement to be entered into among SCIL, The Parent and SCIL II. Completion of the Acquisition is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including antitrust and foreign investment approvals (which have all been obtained), as well as the performance of certain closing actions. We currently expect completion of the Acquisition to take place in the fourth quarter of 2021. If completion does not take place by January 31, 2022 (or if extended, subject to satisfaction of certain conditions by the Parent, March 31, 2022), the SPA may be terminated by either party. See “Use of Proceeds” for the estimated sources and uses required for the Acquisition. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions”. The Parent shall have the right to extend the longstop date to no later than March 14, 2022, subject to procuring that the financing commitment in the commitment letters, delivered in connection with the Acquisition, is extended to maintain certainty of funding on the same terms and conditions. See “Use of Proceeds” for the estimated sources and uses required for the Acquisition. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions”. The SPA contains customary title and capacity warranties, but does not contain business warranties, given that Black Diamond is an existing investor in the Group. The SPA also includes customary signing to completion covenants given by SCIL for the conduct of the business between signing and completion. The consideration payable by the Parent to SCIL under the SPA is €2,209,940,717 (assuming the Acquisition Closing Date would have occurred on June 30, 2021). The actual consideration payable at the Acquisition Closing Date may vary, depending on the actual timing of the Acquisition Closing Date as a result of a ticking fee and possible deductions due to any known leakages. 45.59% of the consideration will be paid in cash, with the remainder being paid through the issuance of a convertible loan note. It is expected that on the Acquisition Closing Date, the obligations under the convertible loan note will be transferred to the Parent’s indirect shareholder, SCIL II (Topco) Limited (“SCIL II Holdco”) and that SCIL will convert the loan note in exchange for the issuance of such number of shares in SCIL II Holdco as would give SCIL ownership of not less than 99% of the shares in SCIL II Holdco and BD III and and BD IV will contribute their shares in SCIL II Holdco to SCIL, thereby giving SCIL ownership of 100% of the shares in SCIL II Holdco. In addition, on the Acquisition Closing Date SCIL will reduce its capital by cancelling all of the shares in SCIL held by GCS and distribute the cash proceeds received under the SPA to GCS by way of a special dividend, expressly provided for under SCIL’s articles of association. As a result, Black Diamond will increase its indirect control over the Target Group from joint to control, while Investindustrial will exit its investment in the Target Group.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Text: The cash portion of the purchase price for the Acquisition is expected to be approximately €1,010 million, subject to certain customary closing adjustments. The Parent intends to use the proceeds of this Offering together with the €85.0 million indirect cash investment made by Black Diamond and potentially certain minority parties that hold an interest in Reichhold Cayman (see “Summary—Corporate Structure and Certain _Financing Arrangements”), which will be contributed by SCIL II HoldCo by way of equity contributions_ through intermediate holding companies to the Parent to finance in part the Acquisition (the “Equity

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Contribution”), and existing cash on the balance sheet of the Group to:
Subsubsection Text: - fund the cash purchase price payable under the SPA by using (i) all proceeds from Tranche A1 (as defined under “Use of Proceeds) under the Euro Fixed Rate Notes ; (ii) all proceeds from tranche B1 (as defined under “Use of Proceeds) under the Floating Rate Notes; and (iii) all proceeds from Tranche C1 under the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes; - fund the Parent Proceeds Loan, by using (i) all proceeds from Tranche A2 (as defined under “Use of _Proceeds) under the Euro Fixed Rate Notes ; (ii) all proceeds from tranche B2 (as defined under “Use of Proceeds) under the Floating Rate Notes; and (iii) all proceeds from Tranche C2 (as defined under_ “Use of Proceeds) under the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes; and - pay fees and expenses relating to the Transactions, by using (i) all proceeds from Tranche D (as defined under “Use of Proceeds) under the Euro Fixed Rate Notes ; (ii) all proceeds from tranche E (as defined under “Use of Proceeds) under the Floating Rate Notes; and (iii) all proceeds from Tranche F (as defined under “Use of Proceeds) under the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes. ----- For the avoidance of doubt, the “virtual tranching” of each of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes, the Floating Rate Notes and the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes is aimed at identifying the separate portions of the proceeds of the Offering being used to pay the cash purchase price for the Acquisition, make the Notes Proceeds Loans for purposes of, inter alia, the Refinancing and to pay fees and expenses relating to the Transactions, and will not entail issuing separate identifiers (CUSIPs, ISINs or common codes) for each such tranche under the Notes. See “Use of Proceeds”.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Text: As of June 30, 2021, €502,300,000 and $59,100,000 was outstanding under the Existing Senior Facilities. A portion of the proceeds of the Offering will be used by the Parent to make the Parent Proceeds Loans. As further described under “The Transaction—Notes Proceeds Loans”, the Parent Proceeds Loans is expected to be comprised of three facilities for an aggregate principal amount of approximately €300 million, deriving from Tranche A2 of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes, from Tranche B2 of the Floating Rate Notes and from Tranche C2 of the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes. The proceeds of the Parent Proceeds Loans will be used to repay in full the indebtedness of the Group under the Existing Senior Facilities on the Acquisition Closing Date. We refer to the repayment of the Target’s indebtedness under the Existing Senior Facilities as the “Refinancing.” The collateral securing the Existing Senior Facilities Agreement is expected to be released on or about the Acquisition Closing Date. See “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization” and “Description of Notes.”

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Text: Pending the consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds from the offering of the Notes into the Escrow Accounts. The Escrow Accounts will be controlled by the Escrow Agent. See “Summary—The Offering—Collateral”. The release of the Escrowed Property from the Escrow Accounts is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within three business days of the Acquisition Closing Date) to pay such consideration. See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; _Special Mandatory Redemption”._ If these conditions are not satisfied on or before the Escrow Longstop Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption. The special mandatory redemption price for the Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of such special mandatory redemption. See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption,” “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Accounts may not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on the Escrow Equity Commitment”._ In the event of a special mandatory redemption, HoldCo, will be required to fund the relevant Issuer in such aggregate amounts as are required in order to enable the Issuers to pay any funding shortfall, including Escrow Accounts fees, negative interest on the Escrow Accounts balances and costs and accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, owing to the holders of the Notes on such special mandatory redemption date, pursuant to a shortfall agreement. The holders of the Notes will not have any direct right to enforce the Escrow Equity Commitment, and must rely on the Issuers’rights to enforcement under the Escrow Equity Commitment. See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption,” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed _Property are not satisfied, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Accounts may not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on the Escrow Equity Commitment.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Text: On or about the Acquisition Closing Date, US Co-Issuer will lend, pursuant to certain proceeds loans in an aggregate amount of approximately €875 million, part of the gross proceeds of the issuance of the Notes offered hereby to the Parent (the “Co-Issuer Proceeds Loans”), which in turn will lend, pursuant to certain proceeds loans in an aggregate amount of approximately €300 million to Specialty Chemicals Holding I BV (the “SCH I BV”) for purposes of refinancing the Existing Senior Facilities (the “Parent Proceeds Loans”). Further, on or about the Acquisition Closing Date, Specialty Chemicals Holding II BV will lend to Polynt S.p.A. a certain part of the Parent Proceeds Loans contributed by SCH I BV to it, pursuant to certain proceeds loans in an aggregate amount of approximately €84 million. (the “Polynt Proceeds Loans”, and together with ----- the Co-Issuer Proceeds Loans, and the Parent Proceeds Loans, the “Notes Proceeds Loans”). In addition, subsidiaries of the Parent and, subsequent to the Post-Transaction Reorganization, subsidiaries of both Issuers, may upstream further funds as needed for the payment of interest on the Notes by means of dividends and the granting or repayment of intercompany loans, as permitted by the covenant described under “Certain _Covenants—Limitation on Restricted Payments.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Text: _An investment in the Notes is subject to a number of risks. Prospective investors should consider carefully the risks described below and the other information contained in this Offering Memorandum prior to making any investment decision with respect to the Notes. Each of the risks discussed below could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition, which, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on the principal amount and interest which investors will receive in respect of the Notes. In addition, each of the risks discussed below could adversely affect the trading or the trading price of the Notes or the rights of investors under the Notes and, as a result, investors could lose some or all of their investment. The risks and uncertainties that we describe below are not the only ones we face. Additional risks and uncertainties that we are not aware of or that we currently believe are immaterial could also have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition. The order in which the risks are presented in this Section “Risk Factors” does not necessarily reflect the likelihood of their occurrence or the magnitude of their potential impact on our business, financial position, results of operations and prospects or on the trading price of the Notes. This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in these forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including the risks described below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a global specialty chemicals group headquartered in Italy. Our business began in the mid 1950s and through a series of acquisitions and corporate reorganizations we have grown into one of the leading global composites and coatings technology producer in the world, with extensive footprint and reach. We divide our products into three classes: Composites, Specialties and Intermediates. Each class comprises several individual products which, in turn, have multiple applications for various industries. In addition, many of our products, particularly our Intermediates, rather than being sold straight to end-users, are used internally in the production of other, higher-margin products in different classes. We sell our products to over 5,000 customers worldwide. Over the years, we have built many strong and stable relationships with our customers, many of whom we have been supplying for over 20 years, primarily through our experienced, international internal sales staff who market our products in over 100 countries. We operate 36 production and distribution facilities and 13 R&D laboratories, spanning across Europe, the Americas and Asia. Our operations consist of: (i) research and development; (ii) sourcing and purchase of raw materials; (iii) production, energy sourcing and quality control; and (iv) product sales, technical assistance and distribution. As of June 30, 2021 employ over 3,134 employees. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we had total revenue, GVA and Average Unit Margin of €1,745.8 million, €585.0 million and €595 per ton, respectively (€2,043.0 million, €584.5 million and €557 per ton in 2019, respectively), selling 983,966 tons of our products. Our profit for the same period and Adjusted EBITDA were €43.2 million and €261.1 million, respectively (€107.4 million and €241.4 million in 2019). For the year ended December 31, 2020, 44.5% of our total revenue were generated in the Americas, while 44.4% were generated in Europe, and the remaining 11.1% of our total revenue generated in Asia, respectively. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, we had total revenue, GVA and Average Unit Margin of €2,028 million,[3] €674.5 million and €640 per ton, respectively, selling 1,053,336 tons of our products with 42.2% of our total revenue generated in the Americas, 47.8% in Europe, and the remaining 10% of our total revenue generated in Asia. Our profit and Adjusted EBITDA for the same period were €125.8 million and €341.2 million, respectively. 3 This based on management accounts and excludes approximately € 5.3 million of income realized from March 2021 through the sales of the remaining stock on hand of Polynt Chemical (Changzhou) co. ltd., whose production was discontinued in February 2021 following the mandatory closure request received from the Chinese Government. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The analysis of the financial condition and results of operations for the Group contained herein discusses financial information derived from the Financial Statements. See “Presentation of Financial Information”.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: General Economic Conditions, Demand and Cyclicality in our End Applications and Supply Dynamics
Subsubsection Text: The specialty chemicals industry is generally affected by the overall general economic conditions with historical demand strongly correlated with global gross domestic product (GDP) trends. For example, global GDP in 2020 was significantly affected by Covid-19 pandemic. In 2020, a sharp decline in economic activity in China in January and February was followed by similar downturns in the rest of the world from March onward. Global GDP declined by 3.5% in 2020. Euro Area GDP contracted by 7.2% (2019: +1.3%). Some countries were particularly impacted: GDP fell by 9.0% in France, 9.2% in Italy, 11.1% in Spain and 10.0% in the United Kingdom. Overall, U.S. GDP fell by 3.4% (2019: +2.2%). China was the only major global economy to report growth in 2020, of 2.3% (2019: +6.0%). In India, by contrast, GDP fell by 8.0% after a lockdown lasting several months (2019: +4.2%). Although global economic activity is currently growing again, it is not forecasted to return to business as usual in the near term. We were impacted by the GDP trends in the first half of 2020. However, following the decline in economic activity in the first half of 2020, our economic performance improved in the final quarter of 2020, compared to the same period in 2019. Although our sales declined in 2020, with 983,966 tons compared to 1,050,093 tons in 2019, our Adjusted EBITDA in the period September to December 2020 increased compared to the same period in 2019, and our revenue, GVA and Average Unit Margin increased to approximately €611.1 million, €208.8 million and €583 per ton, respectively, compared to €626.3 million, €186.2 million and €568 per ton, respectively, in the same periods, respectively. Moreover, despite the ongoing economic effects of the Covid-19 pandemic, our results of operations in the first half of 2021 recovered to pre-pandemic levels, despite sales volumes still remaining below 2019 levels. For example, while sales for the period ended June 30, 2021 were 534,152 tons, compared to 464,782 tons and 548,119 tons in the same periods in 2020 and 2019, respectively. Profit for the period and Adjusted EBITDA in the period ended June 30, 2021 increased to approximately €108.8 million and €199.3 million, respectively, compared to €26.2 million and €119.2 million, respectively, and 34.5 million and €128.2 million, respectively, in the same periods in 2020 and 2019, respectively. Similarly, revenue, GVA and Average Unit Margin in the period ended June 30, 2021 increased to €1,143.2 million,[4] €369.4 million and €692 per ton, respectively, compared to € 861.0 million, €279.9 million and €602 per ton, respectively, and €1,078.5 million, €301.0 million and €549 per ton, respectively, in the same periods in 2020 and 2019, respectively. These results were achieved mainly due to an increase in demand for our products coupled with a market-wide decrease in supply, as a result of shortages of raw materials, logistics issues affecting the market, and competitors’ factory closures. Combined with increased customer liquidity, these trends resulted in an increase in prices for our products and therefore an increase in our margins. Our products are used in several industries, including building and construction, transportation, automotive, electrical, food and feed, marine and home appliances. Most of these industries, particularly the building and construction sectors, have exhibited cyclical demand over the historical periods presented. We believe this cyclicality, which is a function of general economic conditions, has affected, and will continue to affect, our results of operations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—The _chemicals industry is subject cyclicality, seasonality and volatility.”_ Political factors also impact the demand for our products and given the various geographical regions we serve, these could impact our operating results. Demand in Europe and North America in recent years has also been driven by customers switching to higher quality products and advances in manufacturing that has resulted in the replacement of traditional building materials with flexible and recyclable Composites and other synthetic materials. Demand in developing regions such as Malaysia and South America has been driven by increased population growth, a growing middle class, a focus on industrialization investment and higher 4 This based on management accounts and excludes approximately € 5.3 million of income realized from March 2021 through the sales of the remaining stock on hand of Polynt Chemical (Changzhou) co. ltd., whose production was discontinued in February 2021 following the mandatory closure request received from the Chinese Government. ----- infrastructure spending. Our results of operations reflect these trends where we have seen an increase in demand for Specialty chemical products being used in building and construction projects in developing regions. The competitive landscape and macro and micro economic impacts (i.e industry expansion, plant shutdowns, scheduled maintenance, force majeure actions and others) also influence the market supply and our operating results.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Fluctuations in the Prices of Raw Materials
Subsubsection Text: Raw material costs comprise the largest portion of our operating costs. The majority of the raw materials we use are based on crude oil, including butane, orthoxylene, benzene, styrene and pseudocumene. The prices we pay for such raw materials are closely linked to the price of crude oil and crude oil price fluctuations have affected, and will continue to affect, our results of operations and our financial condition. Other raw material costs include the cost of soybean oil and normal butane used in the production of certain coating crude oil prices. We, like other specialty chemical producers, typically seek to mitigate the risks of fluctuating commodity prices by having contracts both with suppliers and customers that allow for price renegotiation on a monthly or quarterly basis or that provide for automatic price adjustment based on the average price of the commodity according to different price indices. The remainder of our volumes bought and sold are done so using either spot contracts at the then-prevailing market prices or otherwise based on formulas reflecting quotes in industry newsletters and other pricing benchmarks which in turn reflect the most recent changes in raw material costs at the time of sale. We also attempt to align the price negotiation periods between our customer contracts and the relevant supplier contracts where possible. Passing through increases or decreases in raw material costs to our customers (either through price renegotiation or automatic price adjustments), while seeking to maximize our margins without commodity hedging, causes our revenues to fluctuate in close relation to raw material prices (assuming constant sales volumes). We are not always able to pass through raw material price increases, or in some instances we experience a certain time lag and, therefore, experience lower margins. Conversely, in 2020 and the first half of 2021 we were able to effectively pass through increases in raw material costs, thus reducing the negative impact derived by the increases in raw material costs. Our inability to quickly pass through all raw material cost increases might be affected by several additional factors. For example, demand in the end applications where our customers compete can sometimes be too weak to absorb the full effect of price increases. As a result, we sometimes postpone passing on cost increases in an attempt to maintain sales volumes, which can adversely affect margins. Changes in raw material prices also have a direct impact on our working capital levels. In general, increases in the cost of raw materials leads to an increase in our working capital requirements, as our inventories and trade receivables increase as a result of higher raw materials prices, which increase is only partially offset by an increase in trade payables. Due to the quantity and turnover of the raw materials that we typically keep in stock, this increase typically occurs gradually over a period of three months. Conversely, decreases in the cost of raw materials typically lead to a decrease in our working capital requirements within the same three-month period following a decrease in costs. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—The raw materials we use in our _production operations are derived from crude oil and other petroleum feedstocks, which are subject to supply shortages and price volatility”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Vertical Integration and a Focus on High-margin Composites and Specialties
Subsubsection Text: Our vertically integrated production model allows us to leverage the in-house production and consumption of lower-margin, less profitable, more price-volatile Intermediates (i.e., phthalic and maleic anhydrides) in the downstream production of higher-margin Composites and Specialties. For example, phthalic and maleic anhydrides, which we produce for captive use, represent approximately 40% of the total raw materials cost of producing UPRs. We estimate that vertical integration increased our total margins for 2020 by approximately €12.0 million, calculated on the basis of the profits made by external suppliers for our captive products and assuming that all GVA is retained by the Group. Furthermore, we benefit from the optimization of production in our plants as a result of the captive use of Intermediates. The vertically integrated nature of our business together with our proprietary catalyst technology used to produce our higher-margin products gives us significant operational autonomy from the volatile and less ----- profitable Intermediates market, while providing increased visibility on market trends, a greater independence in timing price adjustments and an ability to respond quickly to changes in customer demand and, therefore, has a significant effect on our results of operations.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We produce and sell a wide range of specialty chemical products in multiple geographic regions, which affects our results of operations. Within our product classes, we offer thousands of product formulations, which comprise a broad and varied product portfolio allowing us to meet the needs of customers in a wide array of end applications. Composites are tailored to a number of specific applications more than Intermediates, so the Composites focus of our product offering, mitigates our exposure to the volatile Intermediates market and allows us to meet the needs of more customers in a wide range of industries from the transportation and construction to the food and feed industries. We believe our geographic diversification creates multiple advantages, as it allows us to have facilities in close proximity to both our supplier and customer bases. This proximity is a particular advantage as most of our key products can typically only travel to up to 2 thousand kilometres and have a 1-month shelf life, enabling us to meet client needs on a timely basis while minimizing logistics cost of transporting our raw materials and finished products. Our geographic diversification also acts as a natural hedge against localized economic downturns and allows us to maximize operating leverage and boost margins by increasing output volume in regions that experience increasing demand. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We operate internationally and, as a result, are exposed to various currency risks and exposures. Although our reporting currency is Euro, a significant portion of our revenue is denominated in currencies other than Euro, predominantly the U.S. dollar. For the year ended December 31, 2020 and six months ended June 30, 2021, 36% and 40%, respectively, of our revenue was Euro-denominated, 37% and 34%, respectively, was U.S. dollar-denominated or U.S. dollar-linked with the remainder denominated in other currencies. The primary effects of exchange rates on our results of operations may be described in terms of translation and transaction exposure. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—Our operations require the use of _several different currencies, exposing us to both transaction and translation effects of exchange rate fluctuations”. Translation Risk_ Translation risk is the risk that the value of our net sales, costs, assets and liabilities reported in Euro on our consolidated income statement and balance sheet will fluctuate due to changes in foreign exchange rates. For instance, strengthening of the Euro against the U.S. dollar will result in a decrease in our net sales, costs, assets and liabilities denominated in U.S. dollars but reported in Euro. As many of our subsidiaries operate in markets that use currencies other than the Euro, these effects may be significant. Management estimates that in 2020 an increase or decrease to U.S. dollar exposure of 10% would impact profit or loss and equity by ----- approximately €2.1 million and €2.6 million, respectively. Translation from each company’s reporting currency into Euro does not expose us to any cash flow risk and thus this exposure is not hedged. _Transaction Risk_ As a result of our global customer and operations base, our Group companies occasionally enter into contracts expressed in currencies different from their operating currencies. Because these contracts are often settled and/or executed over a certain period of time, we are exposed to the risk that the relative exchange rate will fluctuate unfavorably between execution and full performance of the contracts. Although we engage in some currency hedging to mitigate the effects of currency transaction risk, the strength of our geographic diversification generally allows us to make use of natural hedges within our foreign currency denominated operations, including through matching the currency of our sales to the currency of the purchases of raw materials and other production costs. The revaluation of assets and liabilities denominated in currencies other than the functional currencies of our Group companies results in either financial income or financial expense on our income statement for the relevant period. For the year ended December 31, 2020 and the six months ended June 30, 2021, the Group had financial income from exchange rate gains of €9.0 million and €9.4 million, respectively and financial expense on exchange rate losses of €31.6 million and €4.3 million, respectively, mainly related to the exchange rate effect on outstanding loans denominated in USD and intercompany loans for some of the subsidiaries.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are affected by the various country HSE regulations and the Group’s HSE policies. We have incurred, and expect to continue to incur, on-going capital expenditures to ensure compliance with current and future HSE laws and regulations. Carbon dioxide and other GHG emissions are by-products of our production processes, and as a result we are regulated by the EU Emissions Trading System in the EU and the EPA in the United States. National or regional legislation and regulations may impose additional restrictions on us in the future in relation to our carbon dioxide and other GHG emissions, which could lead to increased costs or capital expenditures or require additional operational changes at our production facilities. The main regulations relating to safety of substances and chemicals affecting our industry are REACH in the European Union, which imposes significant obligations on the chemicals industry as a whole with respect to the testing, evaluation, assessment and registration of basic chemicals and semi-specialty chemical products, and the Toxic Control Substance Control Act in the United States. Complying with these obligations is expensive and time consuming and leads to increased production costs and reduced operating margins for chemical products. In addition, from time to time, we incur remediation costs at our current facilities and decommissioning costs associated with closing production facilities. As of June 30, 2021 and December 31, 2020 we had provisions of €23.0 million and €22.4 million, respectively, for anticipated ecological remediation costs that may be necessary at certain facilities. Given the nature of our chemical operations, should historical or future environmental conditions be discovered, the Group may incur significant future remediation costs including fines and potential damages. See “Regulation”, “Business—Environmental and Health and Safety Matters”, “Risk Factors—Risks _Related to our Business and Industry—We must comply with extensive and constantly changing health, safety and environmental laws and regulations”, “—We may be subject to ongoing costs and regulations related to contamination or exposure impacts from our operations or products”and “— Climate change, and the regulatory and legislative developments related to climate change, may materially adversely affect our business and financial condition, and we must comply with current and future regulations targeting greenhouse gas and other emissions.”_ for a discussion of these regulations and their effect on our operations.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to utilize our assets by operating at full, or close to full, capacity to achieve maximum production volumes materially affects our results of operations. Moreover, certain of our facilities have minimum capacities below which they cannot be efficiently operated. Our utilization rate is influenced by factors such as industry consolidation, regulation, product substitution, unplanned downtime for our and our competitors’ facilities, industry cycles and customer demand. ----- We aim to operate our facilities at full capacity, while maintaining a balance between optimizing volume output and the pricing of the corresponding chemical products produced at the relevant facilities. We regularly review and analyze utilization rates and product mix across our portfolio with the aim to optimize utilization rates depending on demand. We attempt to minimize the need for facility downtime and maximize the useful life of our production facilities by undertaking regular maintenance closures to perform necessary inspections and testing to comply with industry regulations and to permit us to carry out any necessary maintenance activities. We aim to schedule these closures during seasonal periods of reduced demand and in coordination with our raw material suppliers’ planned shutdowns. For example, we schedule maintenance closures of most of our European production facilities during August and December of each year to correspond with generally reduced demand during those periods. When possible, we seek to limit the effect of scheduled outages on our results by increasing inventory ahead of planned turnarounds and by coordinating with our customers to manage expectations in terms of product availability and logistical changes such as changes in the location from which we will ship our chemical products. Typically, before a major shutdown, we either sell less of our chemical products or enter into swap contracts with other chemical producers and inform customers we are doing so in order to increase our stored inventory in an effort to ensure we have adequate chemical products available. This allows us to continue to supply our customers with minimal disruption.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to manage and control costs has a significant effect on our results of operations. We have historically been able to react to adverse economic conditions and other events that have the effect of reducing the demand for our products by reducing our underlying cost base, implementing efficient corporate and management structures and maximizing the utilization of our assets by shifting production. We remain competitive with our low fixed-cost base: for the year ended December 31, 2020, fixed costs represented 21.8% of our total costs (compared to 18.5% in 2019). In addition, our vertically integrated production model has the effect of reducing costs, particularly transportation and raw material costs. Further the Group’s scale and operational synergies will enable optimizations, including the ability to organize production in response to peak demand, exploit economies of scale, reduce overheads, and integrate anhydride production across facilities. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Sales Volume, GVA and Average Unit Margin
Subsubsection Text: We focus on GVA as a key metric to determine the profitability of our operations. We define GVA as total revenue from all products less variable costs (including raw material, energy and distribution costs). The Group’s GVA depends therefore on our ability to manage variable costs and to pass increases through to customers, thereby increasing revenue and maintaining profitability. For the year ended December 31, 2019, our GVA grew to €584,524 per ton, compared to €540,995 per ton in in 2018, mainly due to strong profitability in the Composites market. Similarly, strong profitability for both Composites and ----- Intermediates in the second half of 2020 and first half of 2021 led to a GVA of €674,539 per ton for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021. The increase in GVA per ton in these periods was driven by a successful pricing strategy, focus on innovations, products being a low portion of customer’s manufacturing costs, combined with high level of service and technical support. Increased sales volume typically results in increased sales revenue, but also increased costs including costs of raw materials to produce the volume sold and increased cost of services due to increased transports costs. During 2020 and the first half of 2021, there has been an increase in market demand for our products coupled with a market-wide decrease in supply, as a result of shortages of raw materials, logistics issues affecting the market, and some competitors’ factory closures, while the Group was able to serve its customers without disruption, resulting in sales volumes recovering strongly in the first half of 2021 and increasing compared to the first half of 2020. Combined with increased customer liquidity, these trends resulted in an increase in prices for our products and therefore an increase in our margins. We define Average Unit Margin as GVA divided by the total volume of products sold to third parties and measured as € per ton. The performance of Average Unit Margins generally follows similar trends as GVA. The table below sets forth our Sales volume, GVA, Average Unit Margins and Adjusted EBITDA for the periods below.

Subsubsection Text: We experience some seasonal fluctuations in the demand for certain of our products. For example, in the northern hemisphere the summer paint and construction season drives increased mid-year coating sales that typically decline during the colder winter months. As a result, our working capital reflects similar trends with increased working capital requirements in the first half of the year, and a decrease in the second half of the year. While certain of our products, such as resins and coatings, are subject to seasonal demand due to the fact that they are used in market segments that have higher demand during spring and summer (e.g., paints for home maintenance and marine coatings), we believe our overall results are typically relatively stable over the calendar years as a result of the diversity of our product offerings and our geographic diversification.

Subsubsection Title: Management of Trade Receivables and Bad Debts
Subsubsection Text: Our level of trade receivables and the likelihood of collecting those receivables has a significant effect on our results of operations and cash flows. We actively manage our trade receivables through internal credit procedures whereby we analyze new customers’ credit standing before any credit is granted, including ----- third-party appraisals, when available. Credit with customers is checked annually and customers that do not meet our credit criteria may only make purchases against advance or guaranteed payment. These procedures have enabled us to limit our bad debts, even in periods of economic slowdown when it traditionally becomes more difficult to secure payment from customers. We also sell certain trade receivables pursuant to recourse and non-recourse factoring facilities. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Factoring _Facilities”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting the Comparability of our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our intra-Group sales primarily include sales of Intermediates from certain Group companies to other Group companies that use those Intermediates in the production of Composites and Specialties and sales of UPR between Group companies for the production of compounds and gelcoat. Intra-Group transactions are conducted on an arm’s-length basis and are eliminated in the consolidated results presented herein.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting the Comparability of our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The Group adopted IFRS 16 Leases from January 1, 2019. IFRS 16 introduces a single, on-balance sheet lease accounting model for lessees. A lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make lease payments. There are recognition exemptions for short-term leases and leases of low-value items. Lessor accounting remains similar to the current standard (i.e. lessors continue to classify leases as finance or operating leases). The Group applied IFRS 16 using the modified retrospective approach, under which the cumulative effect of initial application is recognized in retained earnings of January 1, 2019. Accordingly, the comparative information presented for the year ended December 31,2018 was not restated. On transition to IFRS 16, the Group recognized additional right-of-use assets and additional lease liabilities. The initial adjustment on financial liabilities as of January 1, 2019 was €16,5 million, while the final effect on financial liabilities as of December 31, 2019 was €12,2 million. As a result, our 2019 results were decreased by €106,000.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Explanation of Key Income Statement Items
Subsubsection Text: Revenue:_** Includes revenue from the sale of our products. We recognize revenue from a sale at the time a product is consigned to the shipper or purchaser, which, pursuant to our general contract terms, is the moment at which the risk and benefits of ownership of our products are transferred. Raw Materials, Consumables and Supplies:_** Includes the costs of the materials and supplies used in our production activities and the changes in inventories of our raw materials, consumables and supplies. Cost of Services:_** Includes costs for technical, legal and consulting expenses, advertising expenses, utilities, banking and insurance expenses, IT and other services. Personnel Expense:_** Includes the wages and salaries, social security contributions, employee severance indemnities and pension costs. Other Income/(Operating Expenses):_** Includes income and expenses items that are unusual in terms of their nature, amount and occurrence. Depreciation, Amortization and Impairment Losses:_** Include expenses related to the depreciation of fixed assets and amortization of intangibles with definite lives over their estimated useful lives as well as impairment losses. Financial Income/(Expense):_** Financial income includes interest income from bank accounts and deposits. Financial expense includes interest on bank borrowings and other financial expenses. Income Taxes:_** Include current income taxes, changes in deferred tax assets and changes in liabilities. Other Comprehensive Income/(Loss), Net of Tax:_** Includes gains and losses on cash flow hedges and exchange differences on translating foreign operations and the related income taxes. -----

Subsubsection Text: Depreciation, amortization and impairment losses for the six months ended June 30, 2021 increased to € 42.9 million from €35.6 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020. This increase of € 7.2 million or 20.3% was primarily due to the impairment of certain assets of the Chinese subsidiary Polynt Chemical (Changzhou) Co. Ltd. As a result of an agreement dated November 2020 Polynt Chemical (Changzhou) Co. Ltd. has agreed to discontinue the production activity in its site in Changzhou (China) from March 2021. We envisage that the site will be completely closed by the end of 2021.

Subsubsection Text: Europe.** Sales in Europe for the year ended December 31, 2019 decreased to 516.1 thousand tons from 528.4 thousand tons for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease of 12.3 tons or 2.3% was primarily due to the reduced availability of maleic anhydride as a consequence of an incident at the Ravenna plant in February 2019, which impacted the Intermediates business, and the general slowdown of the European economy that impacted the plasticizers business. The Intermediates business was also impacted negatively in 2019 by the duties imposed by the US on China, as more volumes from competitors flooded into Europe as they were disincentivized from selling into the US. The Americas.** Sales in the Americas for the year ended December 31, 2019 decreased to 407.9 thousand tons from 418.9 thousand tons for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease of 11.0 thousand tons or 2.6% was primarily due to lower demand for coatings and composites. Asia.** Sales in Asia for the year ended December 31, 2019 decreased to 126.1 thousand tons from 130.0 thousand tons for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease of 3.9 thousand tons or 3.0% was primarily due to the stoppage of our Chinese Intermediates production site (along with all other sites in the same area) in the fourth quarter of 2019, as mandated by the local authorities. ----- The following table sets forth the Group’s revenue by geography for the periods indicated.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Following the completion of the Transactions, in addition to our other sources of liquidity as described above, we will have access to the SSRCF, which provides for drawings of up to €85 million. As of the Issue Date, we expect that the SSRCF will be undrawn. As of the Issue Date, we expect that the SSRCF will be undrawn. The Existing ABL Facility is in the process of being terminated. We are in discussions with a view of entering into a a similar asset based secured revolving facility with new lenders but we cannot assure that such replacement will occur on similar terms or at all. We believe that our operating cash flows, together with the cash reserves and the SSRCF and factoring transactions, will be sufficient to fund our working capital requirements, anticipated capital expenditures and debt service requirements as they become due, although we cannot assure you that this will be the case. For more information regarding our indebtedness and cash service requirements on our indebtedness following the Offering, see “Capitalization” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements”. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our cash requirements consist mainly of the following: - operating activities, including our working capital requirements; - servicing the Group’s indebtedness; - funding acquisitions; - funding capital expenditures; and - paying taxes. Our sources of liquidity have historically consisted mainly of the following: - cash generated from our operating activities; - cash on our balance sheet; - the sale of certain receivables pursuant to recourse and non-recourse factoring arrangements; and - borrowings under the loan and working capital facilities. As of June 30, 2021, our Net financial indebtedness was €242.9 million, compared to Net financial indebtedness of €317.1 million as of December 31, 2020. After giving effect to the transactions and the ----- proceeds therefrom, as of June 30, 2021, our Net financial indebtedness would be €1,281.0 million. See “—Net _Financial Indebtedness” for more discussion of our indebtedness._ The Parent intends to use the proceeds of this Offering together with the Equity Contribution and existing cash on the balance sheet of the Group to: - fund the cash purchase price payable under the SPA by using Tranche A1, Tranche B1 and Tranche C1; - fund the Parent Proceeds Loans, by using Tranche A2, Tranche B2 and Tranche C2; and - pay fees and expenses relating to the Transactions, by using Tranche D, Tranche E and Tranche F. For the avoidance of doubt, the “virtual tranching” of each of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes, the Floating Rate Notes and the Dollar Fixed Rate Notes is aimed at identifying the separate portions of the proceeds of the Offering being used to pay the cash purchase price for the Acquisition, make the Proceeds Loan Proceeds Loan for purposes of, inter alia, the various elements of the Refinancing and to pay fees and expenses relating to the Transactions, and will not entail issuing separate identifiers (CUSIPs, ISINs or common codes) for each such tranche under the Notes. See “Use of Proceeds”.

Subsubsection Text: “Net financial indebtedness” is the amount of long-term financial indebtedness, plus current financial indebtedness, less other financial assets and cash and cash equivalents. We present Net financial indebtedness in this Offering Memorandum because we understand that certain investors believe that netting cash against debt provides a clearer picture of the financial liability exposure. However, other companies may present Net financial indebtedness differently than we do. Net financial indebtedness is not a measure of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to any other measures of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. See “Presentation of Financial Information—Non-IFRS _Financial Measures”._ As of June 30, 2021 and December 31, 2020, Net financial indebtedness amounted to €242.9 million and €317.1 million, respectively. This decrease of €74.2 million was primarily due to increased cash and cash equivalents as a result of the cash flows generated from the operating activities. ----- As of December 31, 2020 and 2019, Net financial indebtedness amounted to €317.1 million and €300.0 million, respectively. This increase of €17.0 million, or 5.7%, was due to the same factors affecting cash flows discussed above. As of December 31, 2019 and 2018, Net financial indebtedness amounted to €300.0 million and €447.9 million, respectively representing a decrease of €147.8 million which was due to the same factors affecting cash flows discussed above.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We define operating working capital as the amount of trade receivables plus inventories, less trade payables. Changes in raw material prices have a direct effect on our operating working capital levels. In general, increases in the cost of raw materials lead to an increase in our operating working capital requirements, as our inventories and trade receivables increase as a result of raw materials prices and related sales levels, partially offset by an increase in trade payables. Due to the quantity of raw materials that we typically keep in stock, this increase occurs gradually over a period of three months. Conversely, decreases in the cost of raw materials lead to a decrease in our operating working capital requirements within a typically three-month period following the decrease in costs. Our operating working capital levels vary as a result of several other factors as well, including the effect of selling prices, production stoppages and maintenance works, changes in payment terms in the case of key suppliers, foreign exchange rates, our decisions to hold inventories, the operating level of our business, seasonality and cyclicality of the industries that we supply. The decrease in operating working capital of €44.5 million from €306.7 million as of December 31, 2019 to €262.2 million as of December 31, 2020 was primarily due to lower inventory levels. Historically, we have financed our operating working capital requirements out of available cash balances, cash earnings, active working capital management and the sale of certain receivables pursuant to recourse and non-recourse factoring operations.
