Unless the context indicates otherwise, in this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”, references to “we”, “us” or the “Group” refer to the Target, and its subsidiaries for periods and discussions corresponding to the Financial Statements._

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We are a global specialty chemical group headquartered in Italy. One of the leading global composites and coatings technology producers in the world, with unparalleled footprint and reach. We divide our products into three classes: Composites, Specialties and Intermediates. Each class comprises several individual products which, in turn, have multiple applications for various end applications. In addition, many of our products, particularly our Intermediates, rather than being sold straight to end-users, are used internally in the production of other, higher-margin products in different classes. We sell our products to over 5,000 customers worldwide, with whom we have built strong and stable relationships over the years, primarily through our experienced, international internal sales staff who market our products in over 100 countries. We have longstanding relationships with our customers, many of whom we have been supplying for over 20 years. We operate 36 production and distribution facilities and 13 R&D laboratories, spanning across Europe, the Americas and Asia.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Composites include resins and compound products and represent our largest class of products accounting for 79.8% of our revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021. Our resins include UPRs, vinylester and coating resins (such as gelcoat, alkyd and epoxy resins), while our compounds are principally categorized as SMCs and BMCs. See “Business—Our Products—Composites.” Composites display unique characteristics like light-weight, rigidity, resistant to chemicals, good electrical insulation properties, temperature resistance and durability that keep maintenance costs low compared to substitute legacy materials such as steel, aluminum, titanium, concrete and steel. Composites are batch-produced and are characterized by the large number of different formulations that can be used for a wide variety of end applications with different requirements, resulting in highly customized products. We have approximately 1,200 different formulations for UPRs, and approximately 500 for each of gelcoats and compounds. The geographical distinction of the production network plays a crucial role for composites producers, who are faced with a need to balance the benefits of economies of scale from a smaller number of sites (as incremental capacity additions in a site are less capital intensive than setting up a new facility) with the necessity to have production sites that are close to customers. Customer proximity is particularly relevant for UPRs as they have a short shelf life (approximately 1 month) which makes it difficult for them to travel far from their production site. We operate 36 production and distribution facilities spanning across Europe, the Americas and Asia. We hold leading positions across our composites class of products including UPRs and Compounds. We are also a leading producer of alkyd coating resins in North America. ----- The global composites sector was estimated to be worth approximately €12.1 billion in 2020, with the UPR, compounds and coating resins sectors comprising approximately €7.9 billion, €3.2 billion and €1.1 billion, respectively. We believe that for the period 2019−2024 the Composites segment will grow at an annual rate of 3.6%. The chart below shows the estimated annual growth for each product group: Global growth % p.a. by product group 2019−2024 3.7% 3-4% 3-4% 3.1% 3.2% UPR BMC/SMC Gelcoat Alkyd Epoxy Note: Excluding impact of Covid-19 pandemic Source: Company estimates based on market knowledge and third party industry information On a regional basis, Asia is expected to experience the highest growth in the composites sector, in particular in China where we believe a 4.5% p.a. growth is expected in the period 2019−2024. For the same period, we believe that the US market will grow at an annual rate of 3.2%. In Europe we believe that Composites will grow at a rate of 2.2% p.a. for the period 2019-2024, though opportunities for higher growth exist in Central and Eastern Europe. Growth in Composites is driven by several trends including the increasing need for light-weighting components and the use of UPR composites to replace legacy materials such as steel, the increasing need for renewable energy and wind turbines as well as the continued shift from solvent-borne to water-borne coatings due to VOCs emission in coatings. Composites demand is also driven by the growth in the underlying end applications where Composites are used such as infrastructure and construction, mobility, wind energy and house appliances. We believe that our growth rate by volume in specific segments in the Composites segment (in particular, wind, piping and artificial stone) has outpaced overall growth in the relevant end applications, mainly as a result of our focus on niche applications and specific substitution trends. In particular, in the period 2017−2020, EU market sales in the wind and artificial stone markets grew annually by 3% and 2% CAGR, respectively, while our sales grew annually by 21% and 6% CAGR in those end applications, respectively, and while EU market sales in the piping market decreased by 5% in the same period, we grew annually by 6% in that end applications. UPRs UPRs are our core products and are the most important polymer for the production of composites, mainly glass fiber-reinforced plastics. UPRs may be used in a wide variety of applications, as they are capable of being tailored to meet customers’ needs and thanks to the exceptional characteristics of the material, such as lightness, rigidity, strength. The products in this class are generally made to meet specific performance requirements such as heat-resistance, durability, processability, viscosity and other resistance requirements. UPRs are used, among others, in construction (tub- and shower units, cured-in-place pipes, synthetic marble), transportation (truck panels and sheets) and wind applications (turbine blades, nacelle), which are end applications that have demonstrated strong and resilient growth dynamics fuelled by macroeconomic trends in recent years. We expect these growth dynamics to remain going forward. Demand from the construction market is set to benefit from the substantial government spending on infrastructure in our key markets as well as the secular trend towards higher urbanization in emerging markets such as India. UPRs demand is expected to continue benefitting from the ongoing replacement of legacy materials such as steel and aluminium in applications requiring superior weight saving characteristics such as transportation, where fuel efficiency and emission savings are of paramount importance. Shift to renewable energy sources continues to drive demand for wind turbines where our UPRs products are increasingly used. The UPRs industry has experienced significant change in landscape, with significant benefits for players that are still active in the space. See “Business—History.” With respect to UPRs, we retain leading positions across both continents, with approximately 30% share in the US and approximately 40% share in Europe. We differentiate ourselves from our competition by having a vertically-integrated business model, utilizing our in-house production capabilities, and strong positions in attractive segments such as wind energy, with innovative products and high customer loyalty. Our proprietary technology enables forward integration into gelcoats and compounds. |Col1|Col2|3.1%| |---|---|---| ----- UPR industry evolution Source: Company estimates based on market knowledge and third party industry information UPRs capacity in Europe and America, as result of this evolution remained largely flat and marginally declined since 2005, accompanied by a reduction in total number of active players. This trends has led to an improvement in utilization rates in our plants and for the broader sector. Vinylester, Gelcoat and Coating Resins Vinylester and other coating resins are produced with a similar production process as that used for UPRs. Vinylester resins are resins produced by the esterification of an epoxy resin with acrylic or methacrylic acids. The end applications for vinylester include the construction (bath tubs, fencing manholes), marine (boat hulls and parts), piping and toy sectors. Growth driven by continued shift from solvent-borne to water borne coatings, as well as growth in demand from outdoor applications in the architectural segment (e.g. wood floors for decks and roof coatings). Gelcoat is a high-quality resin finish applied in a liquid state to the visible surface of a fiber-reinforced composite material mold to provide a glossy finish. The end applications for gelcoat include (i) marine (they are used in the exterior coating of boats and yatchs due to resistance properties), (ii) building and construction (such as building panels and façade appearance), (iii) transportation (such as exterior layer for buses, cars, trucks, trains and aircrafts), and (iv) others, such cosmetic nails and polishes. The individual composition of the gelcoat varies depending on the final intended application. Future growth in demand is anticipated to be driven by construction end applications (ranging from tub and shower to industrial linings) as well as marine applications, where it is used in boat coatings. Alkyds are made of a polybasic acid or anhydride, polyhydric alcohols and/or monobasic acids, mainly derived from natural oils. A variety of other resins and monomers can be used to modify the alkyd product, allowing for customization to meet specific performance requirements of customers. Alkyd resins are a major class of paints and coatings that are used in architectural applications, product finishes but can also be adapted to suit specific applications in other sectors. In many market segments alkyd technology offers a value proposition unmatched by other coating technologies, which addresses trends towards sustainability. Going forward, growth is expected to be driven by applications with strict performance requirements such as product finishes and special purpose coating segments. We are a leading Alkyd coating resins producer with 61% market share in the US. ----- Share % US overview based on capacity — Alkyd coating resins Source: Company estimates based on market knowledge and third party industry information _Compounds_ SMC and BMC are high volume thermoset composite materials made out of UPRs or vinylesters and reinforced with glass or carbon fiber. As is the case for UPRs, compounds can be used in a wide variety of applications thanks to the possibility of combining raw materials to vary the final product properties, thereby offering the opportunity to tailor such product to suit end applications needs (e.g. by altering its mechanical, chemical or electrical properties). The end applications for compounds include the transportation, electrical and construction sectors. We are a leading compounds producer with 32% market share in Europe. Share % EU overview based on capacity — Compounds (BMC, SMC) Source: Company estimates based on market knowledge and third party industry information

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Specialties include plasticizers and other specialty additives such as malic and fumaric acid as well as special anhydrides and special esters made using internally produced anhydrides that satisfy specific, highperformance requirements of the end applications in which they are used. Specialties accounted for 16.9% of our revenues in 2020. Specialties are produced in batches and can have a large number of formulations that are customized to specific customers or for specific end uses. Key products within Specialties business includes General and Special Purpose Plasticizers and Speciality Additives. We are a leading global producer of Specialties. The plasticizers segment worldwide was estimated to be worth approximately €12.4 billion in 2020, with the GPPs and the SPPs segment representing approximately €9.6 billion and €1.8 billion, respectively. We believe that for the period 2019−2024 the SPPs segment will grow at an annual rate of 4.6%, compared to an annual rate of 2.6% in the GPPs segment. Growth driven by demand from automotive applications and non-cyclical applications such as wiring, cable and medical devices. The chart below shows the estimated annual growth for each product group: Global growth % p.a. by product group 2019−2024 4.6% 2.6% GPP SPP Note: Excluding impact of Covid-19 pandemic Source: Company estimates based on market knowledge and third party industry information |2.6%|Col2|Col3| |---|---|---| ----- The specialty additives market was estimated to be worth approximately €640 million in 2020, with the fumaric acid, malic acid and special esters markets representing approximately €220 million, €185 million and €235 million, respectively. Future drivers of growth are anticipated to include strong demand from coating resins and the increased use in food, fragrance, and cosmetics. The chart below shows the estimated annual growth for each product group: Global growth % p.a. by product group 2019−2024 4.0% 2-4% 2.7% 2.2% Fumaric acid Malic acid Special esters Special anhydrides Note: Excluding impact of Covid-19 pandemic Source: Company estimates based on market knowledge and third party industry information General and Special Purpose Plasticizers Plasticizers are substances added to polymer resins to increase their flexibility, workability and distensility, improving handling during fabrication or enhancing the properties of end products. End users for plasticizers include the construction (outdoor constructions such as swimming pool linings, roofing membranes), electrical, appliances (liquid-contact medical devices) and consumer goods (food packaging), and transportation (automotive cable and wire insulation) and industrial end applications (high-exposure machine parts). In the plasticizers business, the Group focuses on SPPs, which benefit from ongoing substitution dynamics compared to GPPs, due to environmental and toxicity concerns relating to GPPs. For the year ended December 31, 2020, SPPs accounted for 7% of the Group’s revenue, compared to 2% for GPPs. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, SPPs accounted for 6% of our revenue, compared to 2% of our revenue for GPPs. GPPs are commodity products, applied in basic end uses such as flooring and cable sheathing, while SPPs are based on more specialized chemistries and are tailored to meet performance requirements, such as resistance to high temperatures, low fogging and volatility. Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) resin is the most important customer segment for plasticizer use, accounting for approximately 90% of plasticizers globally. Specialty Additives The specialty additives segment includes a collection of smaller scale, attractive products that are used in polymer resin curing, agrochemical and pharmaceutical intermediates, food additives and other uses such as varnish resins, foundry solvents, biodiesel additives, cosmetic lubricant additives and in cigarette manufacturing. Specialty anhydrides are mainly used for curing epoxy resins to create products with superior longevity and high mechanical, thermal and electrical resistance for usage in highly demanding end applications such as wind blades or large electrical transformers. Specialty esters are utilized in a wide variety of end uses, such as humectants in food and feed, intermediates in the production of active ingredients in pharma and cosmetic lubricant additives.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: The intermediates business is built on three products, being maleic anhydride (MA), phthalic anhydride (PA) and trimellitic anhydride (TMA), which are largely produced for the our own use and therefore have limited external sales. Intermediates accounted for 4% of our sales in 2020. Intermediates are mature products with no environmental or regulatory concerns which lack viable alternatives, meaning there is little substitution risk. See “Business—Our Products—Intermediates.” We are a leading producer of Maleic anhydride and Phthalic anhydride in Europe. As majority of our intermediate capacity is consumed internally, we anticipate future growth to be largely driven by developments |2.7% 2.2%|Col2|2-4%| |---|---|---| ----- and captive use in our downstream applications. Strategic opportunities for growth in these business segments are expected, particularly in Asia, where the market is very fragmented and includes a large number of players, and in North America, where backwards integration would help the Group secure supply as is the case in Europe. The intermediates market was estimated to be worth approximately €6.4 billion in 2020, with the Maleic anhydride, Phthalic anhydride and Trimellitic anhydride sectors representing approximately €2.5 billion, €3.7 billion and €270 million, respectively. We believe that for the period 2019−2024 Intermediates will grow at an annual rate of 2.2%. The chart below shows the estimated annual growth for each product group: Global growth % p.a. by product group 2019−2024 4.3% 3.0% 1.0% MA PA TA Note: Excluding impact of Covid-19 pandemic Source: Company estimates based on market knowledge and third party industry information Maleic anhydride is a key raw material for the production of UPRs, which accounts for the largest proportion of its end uses, and is also used in the production of lubricant oil additives and fumaric acid. Trade of Maleic anhydride remains regional, due to the high transportation costs as the product needs to remain heated during transport. Phthalic anhydride is a major industrial chemical used in the production of plasticizer and synthetic resins (e.g. UPR and alkyds), as well as for dyes and pharmaceuticals. Trimellitic anhydride is a key raw material for the production of SPP, which accounts for the largest proportion of its end uses, and is also used in the production of insulation enamels and powder coatings. The Trimellitic anhydride market is smaller than that for Maleic anhydride and Phthalic anhydride by volume, and there are six producers of Trimellitic anhydride globally.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Key Outlook for our End Applications
Subsubsection Text: Across our portfolio, key end applications for our products are the construction, transportation, marine and wind power industries. Additional end applications include the appliances and electrical sectors. Demand for our products is driven by consumption in the relevant end applications. |Col1|Col2|3.0% 1.0%| |---|---|---| -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Building and Construction (38%) - Residential - Kitchen sinks, shower base, - Commercial synthetic marble - Infrastructure                   - Pipes, electrical insulation, polymer concrete House Appliances (11%) - Small and major appliances - Toaster, electric blender, - Consumer electronics washing machine, freezer, dishwasher - Television, smartphones Transportation (13%) - Commercial vehicles - Truck panels and sheets, - Passenger vehicles interior panels - Front- and rear- end panels, hoods Electrical (10%) - Components - Switchers, transformators, - Wire & Cables electrical insulation - Electrical wire and cables Wind Energy (5%) - On shore - Turbine blades, engine house, - Off shore tower components Marine (5%) - Private yachts - Deck hardware, components - Professional yachts parts Other including Food & Feed - Food - Vessels, canisters & containers (18%) - Beverage for food ingredients - Agrochemicals                 - Barrels for beverage - Pharmaceuticals                 - Highly fragmented sectors, e.g. - Aerospace sports & leisure equipment, pharma equipment Note: Numbers in bracket refer to % of sales in 2020 Source: Company knowledge based on market knowledge and third party industry information Set forth below is a discussion of key trends in these sectors as relevant to our business. _Construction_ Favourable macroeconomic developments such as population growth, increasing standards of living and urbanization have fueled the overall growth of the construction industry in recent years. We believe, based on our market knowledge and third party sources that, the construction industry will grow at an annual rate of 2.1% in the Americas, 2.9% in Europe, Middle East and Africa (“EMEA”) and 5.2% in Asia for the periods 2022−2025, without taking into account disruptions and recovery in connection with the Covid-19 pandemic. Furthermore, government spending has encouraged large infrastructure projects, while environmental concerns will continue to stimulate the development of more environmentally-friendly solutions. The growth in the construction industry is expected to lead to an increased demand in products in our end applications, such as sanitary resins, gelcoats and artificial marble used in households, as well as pipes and metal surface coatings used in infrastructure products. _Transportation_ An increase in the use of public transportation in densely populated cities and regions, together with new railway infrastructure products in Asia and the Middle East is expected to continue to increase the demand for passenger wagons. Furthermore, rising logistic demands, led by macroeconomic developments and the growth of e-commerce, are expected to continue to drive the demand for trucks. We believe, based on our market knowledge and third party sources that, the transportation industry will grow at an annual rate of 3.8% in the Americas, 5.3% in EMEA and 6.2% in Asia for the periods 2022−2025, without taking into account disruptions and recovery in connection with the Covid-19 pandemic. The growth in the transportation industry is expected to lead to an increased demand in UPRs, for use in commercial vehicles and railways, as well as resins and gelcoats used in commercial vehicles and public transportation. ----- _Marine_ Growing wealth pools have led to an increasing number of potential buyers for yachts, especially in the Middle East and Asia, together with an increased demand for experiential luxury supported by new technologies making yachts easier to use. We believe, based on our market knowledge and third party sources that, the marine industry will grow at an annual rate of 2.0% in the Americas, 4.2% in EMEA and 5.8% in Asia for the periods 2022 – 2025, without taking into account disruptions and recovery in connection with the Covid-19 pandemic. Increased demands for yachts is expected to have a positive impact on the market for materials used in their production, such as UPRs and gelcoats used in the construction of yacht hulls. _Wind Power_ A global movement towards sustainability is expected to continue the transition towards wind energy and other renewables, with technology advancements enabling competitiveness against alternative renewables. Furthermore, there are additional opportunities for installing wind turbines outside of established regions, for example in Russia, Oman, Kazakhstan and South-East Asia. We believe, based on our market knowledge and third party sources that, the wind power industry will grow at an annual rate of 5.4% in the Americas, 6.3% in EMEA and 8.8% in Asia for the periods 2022 – 2025, without taking into account disruptions and recovery in connection with the Covid-19 pandemic. Demand for UPRs used in the production of wind blades and nacelle is proportional to the installed capacity of wind turbines, which is expected to continue growing. In addition UPR benefits from being more flexible and cheaper than alternative materials for the production of wind turbines, such as epoxy resins. _House Appliances_ Emerging markets remain the key growth drivers in this segment accounting for more than 60% of the middle-class population in 2020. Further, the Covid-19 pandemic has resulted in an increase of consumer purchases, in part due to a shift in working patterns and an increase in remote working. In 2020, approximately 11% of our revenue was derived from products used in this segment. We believe, based on our market knowledge and third party sources that, the house appliances segment will grow at an annual rate of approximately 2.6% in the Americas, approximately 2.3% in EMEA, and approximately 6.0% in Asia for the periods 2022–2025, without taking into account disruptions and recovery in connection with the Covid-19 pandemic. _Electrical_ The sudden increase in remote working, home schooling and global digitalization, mainly caused by the Covid-19 pandemic has resulted in an increased demand for products in the data center and telecom infrastructure segments. We expect future growth also in the medical devices market. In 2020 approximately 10% of our revenue was derived from products used in the electrical market. We believe, based on our market knowledge and third party sources, that the electrical industry will grow at an annual rate of approximately 2.9% in the Americas, approximately 4.5% in EMEA, and approximately 7.7% in Asia periods 2022−2025, without taking into account disruptions and recovery in connection with the Covid-19 pandemic. _Others_ We also sell products for use in other end applications such as toys, textiles, chemical, cigarette filters, food and feed industries, cosmetics and pharmaceuticals. We believe, based on our market knowledge and third party sources that, there may be potential expansion opportunities for Maleic and Specialty Esters in these sectors, particularly in Central Eastern Europe. We have also seen an increase in demand for interior materials to be used in the aerospace industry, given a recovery in the sector in recent years. -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We are a global specialty chemicals group headquartered in Italy. Our business began in the mid 1950s and through a series of acquisitions and corporate reorganizations we have grown into one of the leading global composites and coatings technology producer in the world, with unparalleled footprint and reach. We divide our products into three classes: Composites, Specialties and Intermediates. Each class comprises several individual products which, in turn, have multiple applications for various end applications. In addition, many of our products, particularly our Intermediates, rather than being sold straight to end-users, are used internally in the production of other, higher-margin products in different classes. We sell our products to over 5,000 customers worldwide, with whom we have built strong and stable relationships over the years, primarily through our experienced, international internal sales staff who market our products in over 100 countries. We have longstanding relationships with our customers, many of whom we have been supplying for over 20 years. We operate 36 production and distribution facilities and 13 R&D laboratories, spanning across Europe, the Americas and Asia. Our operations consist of: (i) research and development; (ii) sourcing and purchase of raw materials; (iii) production, energy sourcing and quality control; and (iv) product sales, technical assistance and distribution. As of June 30, 2021, we employed 3,148 employees. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we had total revenue, GVA and Average Unit Margin of €1,745.8 million, €585.0 million and €595 per ton, respectively, (€2,043.0 million, €584.5 million and €557 per ton in 2019, respectively), selling 983,966 tons of our products. Our profit for the same period and Adjusted EBITDA were €43.2 million and €261.1 million, respectively (€107.4 million and €241.4 million in 2019). For the year ended December 31, 2020, 44.5% of our total revenue were generated in the Americas, while 44.4% were generated in Europe, with the remaining 11.1% of our total revenue generated in Asia, respectively. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, we had total revenue, GVA and Average Unit Margin of €2,028 million,[5] €674.5 million and €640 per ton, respectively, selling 1,053,336 tons of our products with 42.2% of our total revenue generated in the Americas, 47.8% in Europe, with the remaining 10% of our total revenue generated in Asia. Our profit and Adjusted EBITDA for the same period were €125.8 million and €341.2 million, respectively.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: The Polynt business began in the mid-1950s under the name FTALITAL as a producer of phthalic anhydride and through a series of acquisitions and corporate reorganizations has grown into one of the leading chemical companies in the world. In the 1960s we were acquired by Alusuisse S.A., a large Swiss multinational which, in the 1970s consolidated our activities with newly-acquired chemical company Lonza AG. Throughout the 1960s and into the early 1970s we developed dibasic acids and their derivatives, in particular special polymers. We also produced certain new derivatives, including those derived from phthalic anhydride, such as fumaric acid, and those derived from maleic anhydride such as esters and special anhydrides. Beginning in the mid-1970s, demand for our products began to increase as a result of a rapid expansion of the polymer industry largely due to increased demand in the Italian construction and transportation sectors. To take advantage of the growing market, we undertook a number of bolt-on acquisitions of complementary businesses and production facilities in order to increase our production capacity. Initially, expansion occurred primarily through acquisitions of production facilities throughout Italy that produced UPRs, plasticizers made from phthalic anhydride and the phthalic anhydride used to produce the plasticizers. In the late 1980s, and again in the early 1990s, we expanded our product offerings by acquiring Italian businesses that produced compounds reinforced with UPRs. In the mid-1990s we constructed a new plant in Ravenna, Italy to bring production of the chemical intermediate, maleic anhydride, in-house. During the 2000s, after the spin-off of Lonza AG from the chemical division of Alusuisse S.A., we continued our international expansion by acquiring facilities in Germany, Poland and the UK, pursuing mergers and acquisitions with certain ex-Lonza companies, the purchase of the Chemial group and the acquisition of the anhydride business of a leading Chinese producer. We also expanded production capacities at a number of our already-existing and recently-acquired facilities with an aim toward both increasing output 5 This based on management accounts and excludes approximately € 5.3 million of income realized from March 2021 through the sales of the remaining stock on hand of Polynt Chemical (Changzhou) co. ltd., whose production was discontinued in February 2021 following the mandatory closure request received from the Chinese Government. ----- and diversifying our production in an attempt to efficiently maximize our production capacity. We also built a number of co-generation plants to supply our facilities with the electrical energy used in our production processes. In 2006, we completed a successful IPO on the Italian stock market, and in 2008 following a takeover bid, Polynt was taken over by Polimeri Speciali S.p.A., indirectly controlled by Investindustrial, a leading European private equity funds. In the same year, Polynt was delisted from the Milan Stock Exchange after its shares rose by 104%, compared to the initial price quotation. Since the entry of Investindustrial, we have continued the expansion becoming a European Leader in Specialty and Composites, by acquiring, in 2011 and 2014, PCCR, the composites and resins business of Momentive Specialty Chemicals Inc. and CCP, the composites business of the Total Group, respectively. The acquisitions of PCCR and CCP significantly increased our presence in the composites sector, especially in the production of UPRs and gelcoat, and expanded our geographic footprint in North America, South America, Asia and Australia. In 2017, we combined with Reichhold, owned by Black Diamond, to form a global group in the Intermediates, Composites and Specialties sectors. Reichhold was founded in 1927 and expanded its business through organic growth and acquisitions, completing an IPO one the New York Stock Exchange in 1955 and being named a Fortune 500 Company in 1985. Reichhold became part of Dainippon Ink and Chemicals in 1987, until a management buyout of the Reichhold business in 2005. Black Diamond acquired Reichhold in 2015. Following the combination, our management worked to maximize the synergies of the combined Group and to streamline the enlarged Group’s operations, to grow its market share, production volumes and profitability. Since the combination we have rationalized our manufacturing capacity and improved our product portfolio, optmizing our value-based pricing with a focus on innovation and our vertically integrated services model. his combination enhanced the Group’s leading position as a global vertically integrated specialty chemicals player, with significant global presence in Europe, North America and Asia, reinforcing our successful integration of PCCR and CCP with Reichhold’s global scale, extensive product portfolio and R&D competencies.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the following are our key competitive strengths: _Leading position in an industry with an improved structure_ We are a leading manufacturer of Composites in both Europe and the US according to our estimates based on 2019 data, with UPR market share by volume of approximately 40% and 30%, respectively. Furthermore, we are a leader by volumes for Compounds in Europe and in the US for Alkyd Coating Resins. The Composites industry has undertaken a significant process of consolidation over the past decade, which has resulted in the creation of a number of global players, e.g., AOC Aliancys, INEOS as well as ourselves. We have expanded our footprint and capabilities and contributed to such consolidation by acquiring PCCR, the composites and resins business of Momentive Specialty Chemicals Inc., and CCP, the composites business of the Total Group, in 2011 and 2014, respectively, and, more recently, by combining with Reichhold in 2017, as a result of which our market share in UPRs (representing capacity by producer) increased from 8% and 7% in Europe and America, respectively, in 2011 to 40% and 30%, respectively, based on 2019 data. ----- Traditionally, the Composite industry has pursued a volumes based approach to sales, which often contributed to a mismatch between offer and demand. In recent years, partly as a result of greater focus on value-added products (which carry greater margins), we have experienced a realignment between supply and demand. Competition within the industry remains strong, both on a global scale, among industry leaders, and in specific areas due to the presence of several, well established, regional manufacturers. A key measure of our profitability is GVA/ton. We have increased our GVA/ton profile through a continuous evolution of our portfolio towards higher-margin specialty applications and an improvement in the industry landscape. Our contractual framework both with suppliers and customers allows for price renegotiation on a monthly or quarterly basis or provides for automatic price adjustment based on the average price of the relevant commodity according to various price indices, which allows us to largely pass through volatility in raw materials, limiting the impact of raw material price movements on margins. The table below shows the increase in the GVA/ton profile of the Group from 2018. Source: Management data _Customer focused and innovation driven business model consisting of strong formulation know-how and development initiatives with customers_ Over the past decade, we have evolved from a local producer of Intermediates to a global composite specialty producer. Our strong focus on innovation has driven the transformation of our portfolio, with 79.8% of our revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 being attributable to Composites, from 43% in 2008. The Group is supported by its approximately 100-person technical sales team, which focuses on local customer requirements and specifications, tying in with the Group’s strong focus on direct sales to customers, which represented approximately 90% of the Group’s sales volume in the first six months of 2021. Moreover, the Group provides high quality, bespoke formulations and delivers products with identical specifications out of our different facilities to meet the needs of global customers which require consistency across their various locations. Our strong formulation know-how gained over the years has allowed the Group ----- to innovate in application development, delivering over 1,000 SKUs, and we estimate that approximately 15-20% of our product portfolio is renewed each year. The chart below shows the percentage of the Group's turnover from Composites new products by year of introduction for EMEA: Source: Management data Our business is innovation-driven, with R&D centers strategically located across our worldwide operations. We focus our R&D efforts on anticipating market developments and meeting our customers’ ever evolving needs. Our R&D activities are fully integrated into our business model thereby reducing time to market for new products and enhancements and improving our ability to respond promptly to customer demand, as well as reducing costs and risks relating to new products and increasing environmental safety, all of which have a positive input on margins. We have developed regulatory expertise in highly regulated markets such as the EU and the US, with approximately 350 specialists working in our Research centers, Development labs, Quality Control labs and Technical support teams worldwide. Our R&D centers collaborate closely with our customers to identify, develop and market innovative products that meet our customers’ evolving requirements and competitive challenges. In some instances, we collaborate with clients to go through regulatory approval processes and/or we undergo internal vetting and approval processes. One of the key factors to our success is our ability to provide high quality, bespoke formulations with identical specifications for global customers on a local basis. We have a strong formulation know-how, with a portfolio of over 2,200 formulations, developed over the years, which has allowed us to innovate in application development, delivering over 1,000+ SKUs in 2020. Recent successful innovations include a new formulation for engineering stone to obtain outstanding glossing and scratch resistant kitchen slabs, and new vinyl ester resins for carbon fiber reinforced spar caps for wind blades. The below chart shows a selection of our strategic R&D projects with successful end use applications. ----- We also collaborate with highly specialized universities for specific projects, such as the Universities of Bologna, Munich, the University of Ferrara, and the Politecnico of Milan. In 2020, our research and development expenses were €18.6 million. See “Business—Our Operations—Research and Development.” _Diversified customer base_ We have a diversified customer base that includes large multinational companies, with our top 10 customers representing 30.2% of our revenue for the twelve month period ended June 30, 2021, and our largest customer accounting for 8% of our revenue in the same period. Our customer relationships are based on our experience in offering bespoke technological solutions and ongoing local support. In 2020, our top 10 customers by revenue had been customers for more than 20 years on average. Our customer base is diversified across product categories, with our top ten customers by revenue operating across different industries, including distribution, wind energy, paint and coatings, artificial stone and cables and wires. The below table shows out top ten customers by revenue for the period ended June 30, 2021.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: 1 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 161,891 Wind energy 8% 2 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 156,043 Distribution 8% 3 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 79,386 Paints and coatings 4% 4 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 50,787 Distribution 3% 5 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 34,489 Artificial stone 2% 6 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 32,588 Paints and coatings 2% 7 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 25,652 Paints and coatings 1% 8 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 22,069 Distribution 1% 9 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 21,152 Paints and coatings 1% 10 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 18,210 Pools 1% We approach every customer relationship with the goal of partnering and adding value over a long time horizon, leveraging our technical and regulatory expertise together with our R&D efforts to fully understand our customers’ objectives, needs and limitations. Approximately 90% of our sales volumes are conducted directly by our internal sales force. Composites are often borne out of significant collective efforts with customers to develop the optimal product for their end and use applications. The customized solutions we provide vary depending on the characteristics and chemical composition of the end and use applications, logistical needs (for example, ease of transport and shelf-life) and specific regulatory requirements. Providing high-quality products with specificity, sensitivity and consistency, coupled with extensive product validation data are key to fostering customer retention. In addition, the quality and dependability of our products are sometimes critical to obtaining commercialization and marketing approval from regulatory agencies. _Global footprint allowing proximity to our customers base_ Marketing and distribution of UPRs is a complex process due to their limited shelf life (approximately 1 month) and the limited range available for transportation from the relevant production sites (approximately up to 2,000 km). Our manufacturing footprint is strategically located to ensure access to key logistic routes and manufacturing clusters. As a result, our global footprint and proximity to our clients is a key competitive strength as it allows us to service a larger number of clients in different geographies, with lower logistical costs and shorter lead times to provide just-in-time service. With 36 production sites and distribution facilities worldwide, we are typically close to our customers. This proximity to our customers, together with our highly experienced and well trained sales and support staff enables us to efficiently deliver our products to over 5,000 customers across more than 100 countries. Our geographical reach and penetration enables us to respond rapidly and effectively to our customers’ demands, and is a key factor in our ability to develop and maintain customer relationships. _Diverse product portfolio enables us to focus on attractive market niches, benefitting from strong organic growth trends in end industries_ Our diverse portfolio of products enables us to focus on a number of highly attractive and diverse end applications, most of which offer significant structural growth potential. The variety of end uses for our products enables us to mitigate the impact on our business of cyclicality or seasonality that some of these markets from time-to-time experience. ----- As a result of our diverse product portfolio, we are well positioned and equipped to take advantage of new trends in customer demand that may develop, naturally or in response to macro events such as the Covid-19 pandemic. For example, we have experienced growing demand for our products that are used in professional hygiene, home and personal care and wood protection market end uses both in the US and Europe, as customers have placed greater focus on health protection and well-being during the Covid-19 pandemic, which is a trend we believe will continue as a “new normal”. In addition, we have recorded greater demand for light weight products in the mobility sector as well as a greater demand for Composites, as opposed to traditional metals, in the wind energy market. Some of our products, such as resins and coatings, are subject to seasonal demand as they are used in market segments that have higher demand during spring and summer (e.g., paints for home maintenance and marine coatings). This seasonality helps us manage our volumes over the course of the year to maintain relatively stable production. We divide our diverse product portfolio into three classes: Composites, Specialties and Intermediates. These product classes expose us to a broad range of attractive customer market niches, which have benefitted from positive macroeconomic and societal trends (such as, population growth benefitting the infrastructure and construction industries, and the increased focus on sustainability benefitting the wind energy industry). See “Industry—Key Outlook for our End Applications” The below chart shows the application of our product portfolio in a selection of customers’ end applications. _Integrated platform with stable profitability_ Our production process is based on a vertically-integrated model, which allows us to leverage the in-house production and consumption of Intermediates (e.g. phthalic and maleic anhydrides), which tend to have more volatile prices, in the downstream production of higher-margin Composites and Specialties. In 2020, phthalic and maleic anhydrides, which we produce for captive use, represented 25% of the total raw materials cost of producing UPRs. Therefore, we benefit from low volatility in terms of input cost and supply, and we are capable of delivering to our customers a greater level of availability of our products and certainty in delivery. Further, having access to vertically integrated intermediate and low-cost inputs supports our margins and helps us capture a greater share of profit across the value chain, especially in Europe where we have experienced demand for Intermediates outpacing the offer establishing a trend, which we believe, is likely to continue in the foreseeable future. The vertically integrated nature of our business, together with our proprietary catalyst technology used to produce our higher-margin products gives us significant operational autonomy from the volatile raw material prices, in particular in the Intermediates market. This reduces our dependency on suppliers while ----- providing greater flexibility in timing price adjustments, as it allows us to foresee trends in advance, and an ability to respond quickly to changes in customer demand and test effectiveness of our products in-house. The Group is better able to predict trends in Intermediates pricing, as it purchases their main petrochemical raw materials. This allows the Group to be proactive in its price adjustment decisions compared to non-vertically integrated producers. Our proprietary catalyst technology has been developed through the years, allowing the Group to develop a leading technology for the oxidation catalysts for the production of maleic anhydride, phthalic anhydride and trimellitic anhydride, which can be used in conjunction with any of the processes currently used worldwide for the production of those molecules. Moreover, we license our technology to third parties, for example for the production of maleic anhydride from butane with fluid bed reactors, where the catalyst is a main part of its production. Our proprietary catalyst technology and know-how is currently used only by two other producers worldwide, which are not our end product competitors. _Strong free cash flow from customer base and maintenance capex-light business model_ We have achieved resilient performance over the years with strong and stable cash flow generation. During the last three years, we have increased our profit for the period and Adjusted EBITDA Margin from 34.8 million and 10.2% in 2018, respectively, and € 107.4 million and 11.8% in 2019, respectively, to €43.2 million and 15.0% in 2020, respectively. We have generated significant cash flows from operating activities and Free Cash Flow over the last three years, and in particular €115 million and €162 million, €169 million and €215 million, and €222 million and €255 million in 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively. Our business model, including our focus on directing our portfolio towards higher growth and higher margin products, has proven its resilience with strong performance in 2020 during the Covid-19 pandemic. During 2020 and the first half of 2021, there has been an increase in market demand for our products coupled with a market-wide decrease in supply, as a result of shortages of raw materials, logistics issues affecting the market, and competitors’factory closures. Combined with increased customer liquidity, these trends resulted in an increase in prices for our products which was greater than the increase in raw material prices. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, our revenue and Average Unit Margin were €2,028 million[6] and €640 per ton, compared to €1,746 million and €595 per ton, respectively and €2,043 million and €557 per ton, respectively, for the periods ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. Further, for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 our profit for the period and Adjusted EBITDA Margin were €125.8 million and 16.8%, compared to €43.2 million and 12.7%, respectively, and €107.4 million and 11.8%, respectively, for the period ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. Our robust margins are attributable to our vertical integration, our leadership position across the value chain, our strong relationships with our customers. Our contractual framework both with suppliers and customers allows for price renegotiation on a monthly or quarterly basis or provides for automatic price adjustment based on the average price of the commodity according to various price indices, which allows us to largely pass through volatility in raw materials, limiting the impact of raw material price movements on margins. We also strive to maintain stability through industry cycles by developing and maintaining relationships with customers that are industry leaders and relatively less vulnerable to economic downturns because of their financial strength and therefore maintain a stable demand for our products. Furthermore, we have a maintenance capital expenditure light operational structure, as our production processes rely on small scale reactors that operate at moderate temperatures and use batch production methods and, as a result, require limited maintenance and repair baseload capital expenditure. We also benefit from the cost advantages of operating large-scale, integrated facilities strategically located near major transportation facilities and customers locations. The combined result of our strong cash flow generation and asset light model has been that over time we consistently managed to achieve reductions in our net levels of indebtedness. In the period 2018-2020, we have incurred Total Capital Expenditure of €48.8 million, €50.2 million and €50.1 million per year, respectively, to maintain and enhance our facilities’ efficiency, representing 2-3% of our annual revenue in the same period, and we estimate capital expenditure of approximately €50 million per year in the coming years. We believe that this structure allows us to operate at lower cost and higher utilization rates and helps us maintain positive margins and solid cash flows even during industry downturns or periods of decreased customer demand. 6 This based on management accounts and excludes approximately € 5.3 million of income realized from March 2021 through the sales of the remaining stock on hand of Polynt Chemical (Changzhou) co. ltd., whose production was discontinued in February 2021 following the mandatory closure request received from the Chinese Government. ----- _Highly experienced management team, leading talented workforce_ Through acquisitions and organic growth, we have developed from a small regional European producer of Intermediates into a diversified global player in Composites, Intermediates and Specialties, with revenue of €1,745.8 million in 2020. Through this growth, we have established a strong know-how in the sectors in which we operate, particularly in understanding the profile of our customers and the dynamics of our business which has enabled us to sustain this global growth. This growth has been led, and enabled, by a team of highly qualified members of our senior management team that combined have over 45 years of experience in our industry. Our Chief Executive Officer, Rosario Valido joined Alusuisse (at the time a Group company) in 1982 and since then has held various management positions. Paolo Carugati joined the Group in 2006 as Chief Financial Officer, and had previously held other finance roles, including being CFO of another multinational group from 2000. Sergio Mario Conni joined the Group in 2009 following the acquisition of Chemial Group. Since then, Sergio has covered various operations and business management positions in the Group. From 2014 to 2017 Sergio covered the position of Senior Vice President Americas, reporting to the CEO. He then moved back to Italy and served as EVP Europe, until taking over as Group COO in July 2020. Our senior management team is supported by a lean and efficient organizational structure that relies on talent, expertise and passion to help us create value. We invest in the training and wellbeing of our work-force as a means to improve performance and foster retention, which in turn are key factors in our efforts to further our growth and future development. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we invested €613.4 thousand on welfare projects in Italy. We also benefit from the expertise and experience of Black Diamond Capital Management LLC (“Black

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Diamond”), which has significant expertise and a successful track record in the chemicals market, both in
Subsubsection Text: Europe and the U.S. Black Diamond acquired Reichhold in 2015, and has controlled, together with Investindustrial, the Polynt Group since 2017. In addition to its interest in the Polynt Group, Black Diamond currently controls TFL Ledertechnik GmbH (“TFL”), a Europe-focused, global specialty chemicals player with a focus on specialty chemicals for the leather industry, and, together with Investindustrial, Bakelite Synthetics, a European and US specialty chemicals player carved out from Hexion’s phenolic specialty business.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Our principal objectives are to continue operating as a global supplier of Composites, Intermediates, and Specialties and to increase the value of the business by generating strong, sustainable and growing cash flows across industry cycles. To achieve these objectives we focus on five main pillars: _Leverage positive underlying industry dynamics_ Our markets are growing, with strong pull-through demand from our customer base and attractive end industries dynamics. We plan to continue to focus on such highly attractive applications that offer significant and enduring growth potential with an aim to expand our operations. In Composites, we intend to take full advantage of recent trends in some of our key end-markets. These include increasing demand for light-weight UPRs in the transportation segment as well as increasing demand for the Composites used for wind turbines due to growing demand for wind turbines driven by the continuing shift to renewables. At the same time, we plan to exploit increasing demand for coating resins in the building market driven by the growing outdoor application sector, and increase our presence in the water-borne coatings segment as many emerging economies continue to switch from solvent-borne to water-borne coatings. In Specialties, we intend to further exploit the significant grow of plasticizers demand we recently recorded due to the increased use of plasticizers in the automotive markets, as well as the increased demand from non-cyclical applications such as wiring, cable and medical devices. We are focusing on developing sustainable solutions via special purposes plasticizers that are phthalate-free. Furthermore, we plan to continue benefitting from the increased use of malic acid and other specialties in multiple food and cosmetics applications. Our Specialties are widely used in high end applications and sectors, like cosmetics, food and feed, pharmaceutical, flavor and fragrancies, health care, and other luxury items. Most of these sectors are not cyclical and management expects to leverage on the Group’s breadth of experience and wide product portfolio to capture market growth. In Intermediates we intend to continue to benefit from our vertical integration to use our Intermediates and use our access to Intermediates production to manufacture higher margin products. ----- _Pursue initiatives to grow and create value_ We pursue high-return organic initiatives to grow and create value with selected projects. We seek growth through improvements of our product portfolio, in particular with respect to Specialties, and value-added downstream products, as well as by targeting new geographies. In Asia for example, we aim to increase UPR margins by expanding the production of UPRs and Gelcoat in China. In Eastern-Europe, we believe we can capture demand growth through capacity expansion of UPRs and Gelcoat in Poland. Through our plant in Spain, we hope to target the electrical and automotive markets in Europe. In the U.S., we intend to expand the range of products in our facilities to include Specialty Anhydrides, Specialty Plasticizers and Compounds to support growth of our global clients operating in the Americas and to strengthen our footprint in high value-add products. We are also aiming to improve our production flexibility across Europe, United Kingdom, and North Africa and to upgrade vinyl ester production technologies to serve clients in the growing wind energy markets. We are also pursuing other efficiency initiatives to target, among others, Intermediates with a view to improving operational efficiency, by seeking to achieve better selectivity and energy efficiency by carefully modifying the catalyst chemistry. For example, our new fluidized bed catalyst generation is intended to increase yield with a reduction in CO2 production per ton of maleic anhydride, as well as new phthalic anhydride reactor with additional capacity and reduced CO2 production. We will also continue to consider potential bolt-on acquisitions with focus on carefully selected assets. _Continue innovation to deliver successful new applications_ Our R&D operations are key to maintaining our innovation and ability to respond to market developments and customer needs, and are a core component of our customer offering. Our innovation projects are driven by market demand and customer needs for applications that meet evolving customer needs. This innovation is a key driver of revenue growth. We focus on continually improving our product offering through the introduction of tailor-made solutions and development of new applications to drive higher margins. Co-development initiatives are the predominant channel for developing new products that are demanded by customers for their new products, creating strong customer relationships and customer loyalty. Our main R&D objectives are to: (i) develop new formulations and cutting-edge technologies, such as environmentally friendly vapor-free coatings, (ii) lower the environmental impact of our production, (iii) improve process efficiency and productivity of MA, PA, and TMA, via proprietary catalyst technology, and by decreasing cost of production, and (iv) introduce new and better performing products aligned with segment needs. We intend to use, protect and further develop our intellectual property and unpatented proprietary knowhow by identifying the best practices and the most efficient technologies. We believe that technology innovation can help us achieve a sustainable cost position. We seek to optimize the overall effectiveness of our asset base by making appropriate investments in maintenance, turnaround times and capital equipment in conjunction with personnel training and site and plant benchmarking. _Grow an environmental and sustainability platform by focusing on sustainable products and manufacturing with a positive ESG market_ Our strategies and objectives are underpinned by a commitment to sustainability and ESG (environment, social and governance) values. We aim to operate and develop our business in a way that takes into account relevant economic, as well as environmental and social and governance factors. We also believe sustainability is a lever for growth and will enable us to tap into new and emerging business opportunities. To support this, we have recently appointed an ESG manager, who is responsible for internal auditing of ESG compliance. The below chart shows select ESG metrics for the year ended December 31, 2019. ----- For example, in order to reduce the environmental impact of Composites, we continue to identify new processes aimed at the recovery of chemicals in end-of-life Composites with the objective to re-use materials in polymer synthesis and to reduce the end-of-life environmental impact of Composites, and to improve their carbon footprint by favoring their use for multiple applications. We have a wide product portfolio and technology for recycled composites, such as recycling in cement production operations (full industrial examples available) and chemical recycling (under pilot scale development). For example, R-PET from bottles and other products is used to produce a type of UPR that is then used in piping and composite concrete material for buildings and infrastructures; and recycled carbon fiber from high-end automotive material is reused in producing SMC for transportation industry in structural applications. Moreover, on the R&D side, we are working with other industry partners and stakeholders on technology for chemical recycling of UPR, where the material is broken down into its original chemical components and re-reacted to produce new UPR molecules. In terms of CO2 emission, we continue to pursue a reduction in emissions and energy use optimization, in particular by focusing on the development of higher performing catalysts for maleic anhydride and phthalic anhydride production. We monitor our CO2 emissions globally and have implemented reduction plans in our production facilities with the higher emissions. Moreover, we purchase voluntary CO2 credits, to offset our CO2 emissions that are outside the scope of the EU ETS regulations. Furthermore, we continue to seek to reduce heat loss, increase electrical motor efficiency, improve lighting systems, and optimize natural gas burner systems. For example, some of our recently implemented projects are: (i) the creation of combined power and heat in Scanzorosciate (Italy), and (ii) the optimization of catalyst performance for selective oxidation processes to reduce CO2. Since 2017, we have reduced our CO2 emissions intensity (being emissions volume in proportion to our revenue) by 7.0% p.a. from 332 tons/€million in 2017 to 267 tons/€million in 2020. Although, our emissions intensity increased in 2020 compared to 2019 and 2018 due to a reduction in our revenue base in 2020 as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic, we continue to pursue a reduction in emissions. Based on an approximate internal calculation carried out by management on an interim basis, we estimate that our CO2 emissions for 2021 will be approximately 233 ton/€million. The following table shows our CO2 emissions intensity for the periods indicated. ----- Our portfolio includes various products with increasing use in renewables, such as UPRs, bonding paste, vinyl ester resins, and gelcoats for wind blades and nacelles. Recent trends for wind blades include the use of larger blades, higher throughput, and improved environmental controls. We are developing a new styrene-free Gelcoat to eliminate emissions of styrene. In addition, we continue to evaluate opportunities to minimize waste generation in our facilities, for example by reusing used/spent solvents both internally and externally. _Deleveraging_ On the Acquisition Closing Date and as a result of the Transactions, our net leverage ratio will be 3.8x. One of our primary goals is to continue to generate cash flow to facilitate deleveraging. Our management is strongly focused on deleveraging the Group’s balance sheet. See “Forward-Looking Statements”. To achieve this goal, we will place significant management emphasis on cash generation and efficient capital spending. Historically, we have been able to generate strong cash flow while meeting the capital requirement of our business, and we believe we are well positioned to generate strong free cash flow.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: The diagram below illustrates our downstream, vertically-integrated production model by representing how raw materials are transformed into Intermediates through reactions with our proprietary catalysts, and how those Intermediates are the building blocks for the production of our higher-margin Specialties and Composites. -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We divide our business lines into three classes: Composites, Specialties and Intermediates. Each line comprises several individual products which, in turn, have multiple applications for various industries, including building and construction (which accounted for 38% of the revenue in 2020), transportation (which accounted for 13% of the revenue in 2020), house appliances (which accounted for 11% of the revenue in 2020), electrical (which accounted for 10% of the revenue in 2020), marine (which accounted for 5% of the revenue in 2020), wind energy (which accounted for 5% of the revenue in 2020) and other, including food & feed (which accounted for the remaining 18% of the revenue in 2020). In addition, many of our products, particularly our Intermediates, rather than being sold straight to end-users, are used internally in the production of other, higher-margin products in different business lines. We have approximately 5,000 clients, comprising of a few multisite industrial groups, large single-site clients and many small clients operating in a single country. These are all specialized customers for whom we manufacture tailored products (with the exception of pure raw materials). Our facilities are placed in proximity to our customers, enabling us to meet client needs on a timely basis while minimizing logistics cost of transporting our raw materials and finished products.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Composites include resins and compound products. Composites, which are produced in batches, are made from two or more constituent materials with different physical or chemical properties which, when combined, produce a material with characteristics different from the individual components. Innovating to address specific customer needs is key in Composites production as Composites are generally made to meet specific performance requirements such as heat, durability, processability, viscosity and other resistance requirements and can be produced using a large number of formulations and specifications. Indeed, we focus on selected niche applications that provide attractive growth and breadth to our product portfolio and enable faster growth rate compared to growth rate of the relevant industry. The segments were we have focused are, in particular, (i) wind energy, where Composites are applied to long blade turbine and nacelle and for which ----- we have registered an annualized growth rate 21% (compared to a 3% growth rate of the European end market in the 2017-2020 period), (ii) piping, where Composites are used for water and gas transportation, piping for ships, duel and corrosion-resistant pipes and lines and for which we have registered an annualized growth rate of 6% (compared to a negative growth rate of 5% for the European end market in the 2017-2020 period), and (iii) articificial recycled marble stones, for which we have registered a 22% annualized growth rate (compared to a 2% growth rate of the European end market in the 2017-2020 period). Because of this high-degree of customization, our Composites customer base is highly-fragmented. As a result of being high-performance products, Composites typically demand higher prices and thus have higher profit margins as compared to Intermediates. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, we generated €1,619 million in revenue from Composites, representing 80% of our revenue for the same period. _Resins_ Resins comprise UPRs, vinylester and coating resins. UPRs are thermal hardener resins, which solidify rapidly and are structurally stable. Phthalic and maleic anhydrides, which we source from our own internal production, represent 25% of the total raw material cost of UPR production. We also use internally-sourced fumaric acid to produce UPRs. In addition, the production process uses styrene and glycol, which we purchase from our suppliers. UPRs undergo an irreversible chemical transformation during production making them impossible to dissolve or melt. Depending on the end application, UPRs can also be reinforced with fiberglass or other materials for added strength and resistance. We have over 1,200 formulations relating with UPRs. The end industries for UPRs include (i) building and construction (in particular swimming pools, concrete forming pans, gutters and downspouts, cooling towers, corrosion-resistant tanks, pipes, ducts and panels), (ii) furniture (in particular bathroom components and fixtures, such as bathtubs, spas, lavatories, etc), (iii) marine (in particular parts and exterior coatings of yachts and fishing boats), (iv) transportation (such as parts and exterior coatings of trucks, buses, mass-transit vehicles, motor homes RVs and cars), (v) electrical sectors (such as wind turbine applications), and (vi) others (such as synthetic marble, putty, button, electical components). We produce vinylester resins and gelcoat coating resins using a similar production process as that used for UPRs, and make similar use of our internally-produced anhydrides and esters. Vinylester resins are resins produced by the esterification of an epoxy resin with acrylic or methacrylic acids. Vinylester resins are more tolerant of stretching than UPRs making them better able to absorb impact without damage and less likely to show stress cracking. In addition, vinylester resins are more water resistant than UPRs. The end industries for vinylester include the construction (bath tubs, fencing manholes), marine (boat hulls and parts), pipe and toy sectors. Alkyd resins are a major class of paints and coatings, next to others such as epoxies and acrylics. Alkyds are made of a polybasic acid or anhydride, polyhydric alcohols and/or monobasic acids, mainly derived from natural oils. A variety of other resins and monomors can be used to modify the alkyd product, allowing for customization as per performance requirements by customers. Alkyd resin coating systems have relatively low cost, versatility, are easy to use and hence very popular and established with customer. Generally, UPRs and vinylester are highly more attractive compared to other composites materials like steel, aluminium, titanium, concrete or wood. In particular, this is due to the with reduction and the cost competitiveness of these materials when applied to high-end applications. Although, there are limited recyclability possibilities due to a lack of established technology, UPRs and vinylester offer significant recycling opportunities, which would likely be established once there is enough demand in the relevant markets from clients. End industries for coating resins, in particular alkyd are (i) architectural (such as architectural flat to noflat paints and coatings and for outdoors purposes), (ii) product finishes (used to finish products as machinery and equipment, furniture, but also in the automotive and transportation industry), and (iii) others as certain coatings are formulated for specific applications or environmental conditions (such as traffic paints, marine coatings, industrial maintenance or auto refinishing). Gelcoat is a high-quality resin finish applied in a liquid state to the visible surface of a fiber-reinforced composite material mold giving it a glossy finish. Gelcoat is designed to be water and ultraviolet resistant. Gelcoat are resin materials used to provide a high-quality finish on the visible surface of a fiber-reinforced composite. Gelcoat is thermoset resin based reactive coating which creates aesthetically appealing surfaces with enhanced durability, scratch resistance, and improved protection from environmental degradation. Gelcoat comes with an high range of pigmentationa and the possibility to be used in brush and spray applications and are generally applied to molds in a liquid (gel) state. We have over 500 formulations relating to gelcoat. Gelcoats are obtained by mixing the resin and heat it to the first curing stage, leading to the formation of a gel; the individual composition of the gelcoat depends on the final application. The end ----- industries for gelcoat include (i) marine (they are used in the exterior coating of boats and yatchs due to resistance properties), (ii) building and construction (such as building panels and façade appearance), (iii) transportation (such as exterior layer for buses, cars, trucks, trains and aircrafts), and (iv) others, such cosmetic nails and polishes. The following table illustrates the applications and some of the end industries of certain of our resins and gelcoat.

Subsubsection Text: _Compounds_ We produce compounds by mixing resins (predominantly UPRs) with carbon mineral fillers, glass and other reinforcing fibers and other additives to produce composite materials. Our customers use these compounds in compression molding (for large molded products having relatively simple shapes) or injection molding (for smaller, compact and intricate molded products). During the molding process, due to temperature and pressure, a crosslink reaction takes place, forcing the compound to take and maintain the shape defined by the mold. Our compounds are principally categorized as: - Sheet Molding Compounds (SMCs): SMCs are produced in rolls that are used subsequently for compression molding; or - Bulk Molding Compounds (BMCs): BMCs are produced in bulk and used in both injection and compression molding. Compounds are enjoying increased demand in a market that has become increasingly environmentally conscious because the environmental impact of producing and using compounds is significantly lower than that of more traditional materials such as steel, aluminum and concrete. To capitalize on the increased emphasis on sustainability, we produce Green Compounds which are SMC and BMC composites reinforced with organic, recycled fibers such as hemp, cotton and linen. The “sustainable” content of these composites can reach 60% of the reinforcement material. In addition, we have developed low density SMCs and BMCs, which are used in the automotive sector to reduce vehicle weight and increase fuel efficiency and in the production of solar panels. We have over 500 formulations with respect to Compounds. The end industries for our compounds include the transportation, automotive, electrical, marine, home appliance, building and construction and industrial sectors. The following table illustrates the applications and some of the end industries of our compounds:

Subsubsection Text: Specialties include plasticizers and other derivative products such as malic and fumaric acid as well as special anhydrides and special esters made using internally produced anhydrides that satisfy specific, highperformance requirements of the end applications in which they are used. Specialties are produced in batches ----- and can have a large number of formulations that are customized to specific customers or for specific end uses. As a consequence of the high added-value of these products, they typically demand higher prices and generate higher profit margins as compared to Intermediates. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, we generated €329 million in revenue from Specialties, representing 16% of our revenue for the same period. _General and Special Purpose Plasticizers_ General purpose plasticizers (“GPPs”) are organic compounds obtained by the reaction of internallyproduced phthalic anhydride and alcohol which we purchase from suppliers. GPPs are primarily used in the plasticization of polymers such as polyvinyl chloride (“PVC”) to make them more flexible and facilitate their workability and distensibility. Our GPPs have applications in many end-uses including coating for electrical cables, synthetic leather, flexible tubing, sports clothes, coating on textiles, automobile undercoating and coating for walls, floors and roofs. The end industries for our GPPs include the electrical, transportation, toy, home, industrial and medical appliance, coating and automotive industries. Special purpose plasticizers (“SPPs”) are produced by exposing internally-produced trimellitic and phthalic anhydride and other raw materials to alcohol in a process known as “esterification”. When added to PVC, SPPs create products that are resistant to high temperatures, remain flexible in low temperatures and resist solvents, oils and ultraviolet light. Our high-performance SPPs allow relatively fast and economic production of PVC used as coating for electrical cables, roof tiles, vinyl leather, dashboards and car interiors. The end industries for our SPPs include the electrical, transportation, medical appliance, building and construction and automotive sectors, as well as cable and wire insulation, and PVC film and sheets. The following table illustrates the applications and some of the end industries of our GPPs and SPPs.
