Subsubsection Text: _Malic Acid_ Malic acid is produced from internally-sourced maleic anhydride and is used to preserve food and drinks by controlling their pH factors. Malic acid can also be used to clean metals, to retard the curing of cement, for moisturizing and anti-wrinkle creams and other cosmetic products and in animal feed. To meet our customers’ varied needs, we produce malic acid in various forms (e.g., granulated, finely granulated, special-purpose finely granulated and powdered). The end industries for malic acid include the soft drink, sweets, processed meats, jellies, animal feed and building and construction sectors. The following table illustrates the applications and some of the end industries of malic acid.

Subsubsection Text: _Fumaric Acid_ We produce fumaric acid from internally sourced maleic anhydride or from solutions of maleic acid recovered during the production of phthalic anhydride (a process known as “isomerization”). Like malic acid, ----- fumaric acid is used to regulate the acidity of foods and as an acidulant for animal feed. Additionally, we use fumaric acid internally in the production of UPRs. The end industries for fumaric acid include the reinforced plastics and animal feed sectors. The following table illustrates the applications and some of the end industries of fumaric acid.

Subsubsection Text: _Special Anhydrides and Special Esters_ We produce special anhydrides by exposing internally-produced maleic anhydrides to highly-reactive chemical compounds (such as butadiene and isoprene). In certain cases, we then add hydrogen to make the special anhydrides more stable. Special anhydrides are performance chemicals used as hardeners for epoxy resins, in the electrical and electronic industries (including the production of molded circuits, light-emitting diodes (LEDs), transformers, insulators, electrical interrupter switches and high-performance compounds) and in the agro-chemical industry (for the production of fungicides). Specialty anhydrides are used for curing of polymer resins (especially epoxy) where superior longevity and high performance are required, in particular in terms of mechanical, thermal and electrical resistance. We produce specialty esters by exposing maleic anhydride to an alcohol such as methanol, ethanol, isopropanol or isobutanol. Specialty esters are used to produce pigments for paints and dyes, as stabilizing additives for plastic materials, in pharmaceuticals, the food industry and in the agro-chemical industry. The end industries for special esters include the soft drink, sweets, processed meat, jellies, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, cigarette, food additive, coating, textile, automotive and chemical sectors. The following table illustrates the applications and some of the end industries of Special Anhydrides and Special Esters.

Subsubsection Text: We have a distinct technology position in Intermediates, as we are the only Composites producer with our own catalyst technology[7]. We internally develop and produce the oxidation catalysts used in the catalytic oxidation processes that transform our raw materials into phthalic, maleic and trimellitic anhydride. These anhydrides are, in turn, used internally in the production of Specialties and Composites, which are sold to our customers. In this sense, catalysts are at the top of our vertically-integrated production model. We have been focusing on research and development projects relating to the oxidation processes since the 1970s and we have 7 There are currently only two other non-composites producers worldwide possessing similar catalysts. ----- improved the oxidation catalysts performance to (i) leverage on the latest technology to produce phthalic, maleic and trimellitic anhydride, as well as being ahead of the curve to develop new product and innovations, respond quickly to customers’ changing demand and test in-house the effectiveness of our products before releasing them in the market, (ii) enhance our business integration, by decreasing the variable costs relating to the production of phthalic, maleic and trimellitic anhydride and benefitting in the production value chain by reducing our dependency on suppliers and enabling operational autonomy, and (iii) decrease the CO2 emissions of our operations. During the past 50 years we have also gained a unique position in terms of know-how and technology advantage in this matter. We perform catalytic oxidation either in fixed-bed reactors (with hydrocarbons such as orthoxylene, benzene and butane) or in fluidized-bed reactors (with butane, using Alma technology). Catalysts produced for fixed-bed reactors have an average useful life of approximately three to four years while catalysts produced for fluidized-bed reactors have an average useful productive life of approximately seven to eight years. In addition to using these catalysts for internal production, we license their use to third parties and occasionally sell certain catalysts in favor of using more productive, new generation catalysts developed by our research and development team.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We have been producing Intermediates since our incorporation in 1955. Intermediates are produced on a continuous basis (i.e., not in batches) and include the anhydrides which we use internally to produce highermargin Composites and Specialties. Intermediates not used internally are sold to third parties for use in their own Specialty and Composite production. We have our own oxidation catalyst technology, which is both used in our own plants and licensed to third parties. Supplying our own Intermediates and selling Intermediates to third parties affords us heightened visibility on the specialty chemicals market, representing a significant competitive advantage. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, we generated €81 million in revenue from Intermediates, after infra-group eliminations, representing 4% of our revenue for the same period. _Maleic Anhydride_ Maleic anhydride is an organic compound that we produce by subjecting either benzene or normal butane (each a petroleum derivative) to the same catalytic oxidation process that produces phthalic anhydride. We developed a proprietary production process called Alma to produce maleic anhydride. Alma uses fluidizedbed reactors and catalysts that we have developed and patented. Fluidized-bed reactors are reactors containing catalysts in the form of a powder, suspended in a stream of reactants. We use Alma in our plants and license the technology to third parties. Maleic anhydride has a wide variety of uses ranging from being a raw material used in producing UPRs to being used as a copolymer for water treatment. We use maleic anhydride internally for the production of nearly all of our Specialties. The end industries for maleic anhydride include the building and construction, transportation, electrical, industrial, agrochemical, coating, solvents, home and industrial appliances and synthetic fibers sectors. ----- The table below sets forth the applications and end industries of maleic anhydride.

Subsubsection Text: _Phthalic Anhydride_ Phthalic anhydride is an organic compound that we produce by transforming orthoxylene (a petroleum derivative), using catalysts to combine it with oxygen efficiently through a process known as catalytic oxidation. We use phthalic anhydride internally in the production of GPPs and for various types of resins, including UPRs and alkyd polyesters for paints. The end industries for phthalic anhydride include the electrical, transportation, toy, home and industrial appliances and coating sectors. The following table illustrates the applications and some of the end industries of phtalic anhydride.

Subsubsection Text: _Trimellitic Anhydride_ Trimellitic anhydride is an organic anhydride that we produce by catalytic oxidation of pseudocumene, a petroleum derivative. Trimellitic anhydride is used internally to produce SPPs and sold to our customers to produce insulating enamels for electrical cables and powder paints. The end industries for trimellitic anhydride include the electrical, transportation, medical appliance and building and construction sectors. ----- The table below sets forth the applications and end industries of trimellitic anhydride.

Subsubsection Text: We are committed to the research and development of new and innovative products. R&D is completely integrated into our business model. Core competences for every product line are present in our dedicated R&D laboratories located in our main production sites around the world, with dedicated highly trained employees who work on our performance products and our production technologies using specialised instruments. We also collaborate with universities and certain key customers for customised products or projects of strategic importance. As of December 31, 2020, we employed more than 100 R&D specialists worldwide. We conduct research and development activities at 1 laboratories in our plants in Scanzorosciate (Italy), Brembate (Italy), Parma (Italy), San Giovanni Valdarno (Italy), Drocourt (France), Fredrikstad (Norway), Miehlen (Germany), Stallinghborough (UK), North Kansas City (U.S.), Carpentersville (U.S.), Atlacomulco (Mexico), Mogi das Cruzes (Brazil), Jeonju (South Korea) and Tianjin (China). Our consolidated research expenses were €22.8 million, €21.1 million and €18.6 million for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively. Our research and development operations are divided into two main areas: - Product research. We seek to develop new products and improve the performance of existing products, to improve our portfolio in line with market requirements and new trends. Through laboratory trials we are able to synthesize and test our products to ensure they perform as expected. In addition, our laboratory trials are also used to assess potential new uses and applications for our product families. - Technology research. We also work on our production processes to improve the efficiency of our technology and to implement new processes, to ensure that we are always technologically up to date. Our research focuses primarily on addressing specific customer requirements, cost optimization, risk reduction and environmental safety. We often initiate research and development activities both in response to specific requests from individual customers as well as in reaction to the market trends of our product classes. We rely on our research and development teams to stay updated on the relevant market trends affecting their product classes. We also collaborate with highly specialised universities for specific projects. For example, we collaborate with the Universities of Bologna and Munich in research on catalysts, with the University of Ferrara for Composites, with Politecnico of Milan for developing new technologies. Our research has also benefited from grants from the EU, U.S. and other governments, for example in Composites Recycling. The time and resources we devote researching and developing particular products depends on various factors. A significant factor is the degree to which the innovation requested is a departure from products that ----- use existing technology that has already been tested. Products requiring wholly new technologies can often take as long as three to five years to develop, while products that are minimally different from older technologies may be developed in as little as three to 12 months. Research and development activities at our 13 laboratories are characterized as follows: - all 13 of our laboratories are dedicated to specific product classes and use equipment and instruments dedicated to specific product lines, seeking to expand the range of products in each product line based on feedback from our customers; - our Scanzorosciate (Italy) laboratory specializes in research on catalysts for our internal use and for sale to third parties, where we test high-performance catalysts for use in the gaseous phase of the oxidation process by utilizing pilot plants, which are lab-scale model facilities for testing and experimenting on catalysts; and - our laboratories in Scanzorosciate (Italy), San Giovanni Valdarno (Italy), North Kansas City (U.S.) and Drocourt (France) are “pilot plants” that not only research and develop new products, but also test those new products and have the capacity to produce approved products on a semi-industrial scale thus reducing the time-to-market of newly developed products. Our research and development activities are supported, in terms of analytical control, by our analysis laboratories, which are located in each of our main plants. In addition to assisting the research and development process, our plants’ analysis laboratories perform quality control on raw materials and test our finished products. Our product line managers identify the targets, research and controls needed to support their product classes, and are in direct contact with the laboratory that conducts the research and testing for that line. We believe that by conducting our research and development internally and facilitating communication and feedback between the researchers and product line managers, we are able to (i) minimize the time to market of our new products, (ii) reduce our production costs, (iii) be more cost-efficient, (iv) maximize the responsiveness of our research to customer needs and market trends and (v) maintain the confidentiality of proprietary information. We have registered certain patents and trademarks for products and technologies arising out of our research and development activities. See “—Intellectual Property”.

Subsubsection Title: Sourcing and Purchase of Raw Materials
Subsubsection Text: To make our products we use raw materials derived from crude oil and then we chemically transform them into our products. The raw materials we consume most in production are Styrene, Maleic Anhydride and Propylene Glycol. The principal raw materials we use are: - Styrene: Styrene is a raw material used to produce polystyrene, other polymers and, to a lesser extent, UPRs. We use styrene in more than 30 plants. We have renewable annual supply agreements with a number of suppliers of styrene. In Europe our purchase price for styrene is related to the price of benzene (the main raw material for producing styrene) and the published market assessment. We use styrene in four plants in Asia with a total yearly usage of approximately 33 KMt historically. Price and volume requirements are mainly covered by contract, based on Asia ICIS index. In China price and volume requirements are based on monthly spot/market price, as is customary for most chemicals in China. In the Americas our prices are based on formulas linked to key drivers (Benzene, Ethylene and Natural Gas) and spot prices. In 2020, we purchased approximately 93,000 mt of styrene throughout 18 plants across the Americas. - Maleic Anhydride: Maleic Anhydride is a key raw material for UPR. In 2020 we purchased 38,800 mt of maleic anhydride in the Americas throughout our 14 plants. Majority of the supply is secured by long term contracts with price formulas. Maleic Anhydride in Asia is used in all the plants and sourced locally on a spot basis. - Propylene glycols: Propylene glycols are substances derived from propylene. They are used to produce UPRs. ----- We are one of the main consumers of propylene glycols in Europe. We use propylene glycols in 10 of our plants. In 2020 we used more than 39,000 tons of propylene glycols in Europe. We have entered into certain renewable annual supply agreements with our suppliers. The price we pay for propylene glycols is calculated according to a contractual formula providing for price adjustments based on the monthly market price of propylene glycols adjusted in respect of the price fluctuation over the previous month. The price provisions also provide a rebate in case purchases over certain quantities. In the Americas, the price we pay for propylene glycols is calculated according to a contractual formula providing for price adjustments based on propylene publication for Monopropylene Glycol (MPG) and Dipropylene Glycol (DPG). The price provisions also provide a rebate for purchases over certain quantities. In the Americas, Glycols are used in 16 locations. In 2020, we used 28,000 mt of MPG and DPG combined. Propylene Glycols are used in four plants in Asia. MPG is a main raw material for UPR, with a total usage of approximately 61,800 Mt in 2020 globally. We have global and local suppliers and volume requirements are covered by contracts with price based on market price, discussed on a monthly basis. DPG is an important raw material for our UPR, with a total usage in Asia total of approximately 9,500 mt in 2020. We have global and local suppliers and volume requirements are covered by contracts with price based on monthly market price. In China, price and volume requirements for both MPG and DPG are based on monthly spot/market price; as is customary for most chemicals in China. - Pseudocumene: Pseudocumene is an aromatic hydrocarbon derived from petroleum. We use pseudocumene to produce trimellitic anhydride. We use pseudocumene for production in our Scanzorosciate (Italy) plant. We have a sole contractual supplier of pseudocumene with whom the relevant supply agreement expires on May 31, 2025. We have had a very long relationship with this supplier and there are easily available alternative suppliers to which we could switch without incurring very high costs. The price we pay for pseudocumene varies determined by a contractual formula based on the industrial cost of pseudocumene providing for, inter alia, adjustments to inflation and discounts when we purchase increased volumes. In 2020, we purchased approximately 15.7 kton of pseudocumene across our facilities. - Orthoxylene: Orthoxylene is an aromatic product used almost exclusively to produce phthalic anhydride. We use orthoxylene in our Scanzorosciate (Italy) and San Giovanni Valdarno (Italy) plants. Aromatic products are products such as benzene that contain one or more six-carbon rings with double bonds. We have entered into multi-year requirement agreements with our orthoxylene suppliers, in the EU and Asia. We also periodically use spot suppliers in the U.S.. The purchase price we pay for orthoxylene is calculated according to a contractual formula. The key factors in the formula are (i) the fluctuation in the price of crude oil and other petroleum feedstocks on the international market, (ii) the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar against the euro and (iii) market demand for orthoxylene. In 2020, we purchased approximately 79.5 kton of orthoxylene across our facilities. - Normal Butane: Normal butane is a component of liquefied petroleum gas and is used most often as a heating or transport fuel. We use normal butane to produce maleic anhydride at our Ravenna (Italy) plant. The substantial majority of the normal butane used at our Ravenna (Italy) plant is supplied via a direct pipeline that is integrated into the production facility itself. The purchase price we pay for normal butane is determined according to a contractual formula. The key factor in the formula is the average price of normal butane during the month of delivery, calculated according to different price indices. Our normal butane supply via a pipeline is governed by a supply agreement with Ecofuel S.p.A. that is due to expire on December 31, 2021, but we expect will be renewed for a further term. We also have other minor supplier agreements in Europe for normal butane. In 2020, we purchased approximately 56.3 kton of normal butane across our facilities. - Dienes: Dienes are raw materials sourced from hydrocarbon molecules that have two double carbon bonds. The dienes we use most frequently are butadiene, a precursor to synthetic polymers, and isoprene, a precursor to synthetic rubber and dicyclopentadiene (DCPD), an alternative raw material for UPR. We use dienes to produce our anhydrides in our Scanzorosciate (Italy), Ravenna (Italy) plants. We use DCPD in about 25 plants worldwide for the production of UPR. We have renewable annual supply agreements with our suppliers for our supply of dienes. DCPD is typically sourced in China on a spot basis, while minor volumes are sourced locally in U.S. and Europe. In 2020 we purchased approximately 29.1 kton of dienes across our facilities. ----- - Phthalic Anhydride: Phthalic Anhydride is a key raw material for both UPR and Alkyds. In 2020, we purchased approximately 24,800 mt of phthalic anhydride in the Americas throughout 14 plants. The majority of the supply is secured by long term contracts with price formulas and through intragroup supplies from our Italian entities. Phthalic Anhydride in Asia is used in all the plants and sourced locally on a spot basis. - Epoxy: Epoxy resins are raw materials for vinyl ester resins and come indifferent grades. We used approximately 11.2 kt of epoxy globally in 2020. Epoxy are sourced from local producers. In addition, we buy some material in the U.S. and EU from Asian manufacturers. Price is formula-based for the U.S. and European producers, related to the published market assessments. In Asia, Epoxy is bought on a spot basis. In the second half of 2020 and the first half of 2021, epoxy resin production suffered from a reduction in production due to outages of epoxy and their feedstocks and to logistic constraints for materials. As a result, the price of epoxy resin in June 2021 was almost triple that of prices in June 2020. - DEG: Diethylene Glycol (DEG) is a glycol used for UPR. It is a byproduct of the production monoethylene glycol (MEG). We consume approximately about 40 kt per year of DEG globally, divided in proportion to the UPR production of each site. DEG is sourced from local producers in the U.S. and Asia. In Europe, approximately 75% of the volume is sourced from non-European producers, typically based in the Middle East and the U.S.. The price is spot-based in Asia, while in the U.S. and Europe is formula-based, related to published market assessments, through purchasing contracts. Regional managers are responsible for posting sales budgets into our information technology system and ensuring that the production facilities they oversee receive adequate supplies of raw materials. This data is subsequently reprocessed by our purchasing and logistics department. While our logistics staff is responsible for product handling, bagging and loading and unloading, our purchasing staff assesses the quantities of raw materials that are needed on an annual basis and draws up related purchasing budgets. Their assessment is based on our current inventories of each raw material and upon the amount of such material being consumed in our production processes. Once our needs are assessed, our purchasing and logistics office manager negotiates the relevant contract with the supplier and thereafter individual purchase orders are sent to our suppliers on a monthly basis. The majority of our raw materials are delivered “cost, insurance and freight” or “delivered at place”, meaning that shipping and delivery are arranged and paid for by the supplier. The majority of deliveries of raw materials are made by rail tanker, with a minority being delivered to our plants in tank trucks or isotanks. Additionally, at our Ravenna plant, we receive most of our normal butane by pipeline. We have relationships with almost 1,000 suppliers in approximately 30 different countries for our supply of raw materials. We, however, are dependent on relatively few key suppliers with whom we have strong, mutually-beneficial relationships for our strategic raw material. As part of our quality-management procedures, we seek to maintain long-term relationships with suppliers, which create a sense of cooperation and expectation of quality. Most of our purchases are made through purchase orders made either independently, or pursuant to long-term delivery/supply agreements which dictate minimum and maximum quantities of the specific raw material we must purchase in a given year and set price adjustment mechanisms usually keyed on the price of crude oil. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—The _raw materials we use in our production operations are derived from crude oil and other petroleum feedstocks, which are subject to supply shortages and price volatility”._ Our purchasing and logistics office performs an ongoing assessment of our suppliers’ competitiveness and reliability and places orders accordingly. We try to minimize the costs associated with the transport of raw materials by purchasing them from suppliers that are located near our production facilities. For the year ended December 31, 2020, total spend with our five largest and ten largest suppliers accounted for 24% and 33%, respectively, of our raw material costs. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our _Business and Industry—We rely on a limited number of suppliers of raw materials for our production requirements”._

Subsubsection Title: Production, Energy Sourcing and Quality Control
Subsubsection Text: _Production and Storage Facilities_ Our production processes vary according to the raw materials we use, the products we manufacture and the technology we employ. We operate 36 production and distribution facilities across the world. Our engineers ----- design and coordinate the building and operation of our plants. They also ensure that our plants are routinely modernized and comply with applicable laws. Each of our plants has one or more production units, each of which is dedicated to the production of one product. We invest in our plants, with €50.1 million, €50.2 million and €48.8 million in Total Capital Expenditures in the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively. Our primary capital expenditures in our plants for 2020, 2019 and 2018 were as follows: - 2020: In Europe we spent €5.7 million on the new maleic anhydride ALMA reactor installation at the Ravenna site (Italy); €1.5 million for the catalyst replacement of the maleic anhydride and phthalic anhydride plants; € 0.7 million for the trimellitic anhydride plant refurbishment and €1.3 million for product quality improvement of Malic acid plant at Scanzorosciate site (Italy); €2.3 million for the upgrading of SPP units and feeding and the demolition of an old building for safety reasons at San Giovanni Valdarno site (Italy); €3.0 million mainly for resin storage expansion and production debottlenecking at Niepolomice site (Poland); €1.4 million for the increase of storage capacity in raw material and upgrading of storage area to comply with the new governing safety rules at Drocourt site (France). In the Americas we spent €7.0 million mainly for the renovation of the Carpentersville (U.S.A.) and North Kansas City (U.S.A.) R&D facilities to incorporate labs from the transfer of R&D activities from Raleigh (U.S.A.); €4.9 million to upgrade the Orlando (U.S.A.) and Morris (U.S.A.) site capabilities following the closure of the North Kansas City manufacturing site; € 0.8 million for the reactor conversion implementation to expand UPR composite manufacturing capacity at the Atlacomulco (Mexico); €0.2 million for a SAP implementation in Canada to support future business growth and harmonize business processes. In Asia we spent €1.3 million to install a third reactor and on the bonding paste ongoing projects at the Pune (India) site; €1.0 million on a new warehouse, storage tank and office building in our Malaysia site; and €1.0 million for an ongoing bonding paste project in South Korea. - 2019: In Europe we spent €2.6 million in connection with the accident at the maleic anhydride reactor in Ravenna (Italy) and the related pre-engineering work for the replacement of the reactor; €0.8 million for the catalyst replacement in the maleic anhydride plant in Scanzorosciate (Italy) as well as €1.1 million for the refurbishement of the TMA plant in the same site; €0.6 million for the conversion of the boiler at the Cavaglia (Italy) site into natural gas as well as other improvements; €1.4 million for the expansion of the resin storage and production debottlenecking at the Niepolomice (Poland) site; €1.0 million to increase the raw material storage capacity in Drocourt (France). In the Americas we spent €11.8 million in connection with the reallocation of production from closed sites as well as the transfer of R&D facilities from Durham (U.S.A.) to Carpentersville (U.S.A.) and North Kansas City (U.S.A.). €2.9 million to upgrade the capabilities of the Pensacola (U.S.A.) and Morris (U.S.A.) sites; €2.9 million for the reactor conversion implementation to expand UPR manufacturing capacity in Atlacomulco (Mexico); €0.5 million for a SAP implementation in Canada to support future business growth and harmonize business processes. In Asia we spent €0.4 million to install a third reactor and on ongoing projects at the Pune (India) site; €1.4 million for new offices in Malaysia; €1.8 million for new open channel rainwater systems in Changzhou (China); and €0.8 million for a DCS system upgrade in South Korea. - 2018: In Europe we spent €2.1 million to upgrade the maleic anhydride plant in Ravenna (Italy) as well as €0.7 million to upgrade the steam turbine generator plant in the same site; €1.7 million to upgrade the TMA plant in Scanzorosciate (Italy) as well as €0.5 million to upgrade the malic and fumaric acid plant in the same site; €0.6 million for catalyst replacements for the phtalic anhydride plant in San Giovanni Valdarno (Italy) as well as €0.2 million to upgrade the special plasticizers plant in the same site. In the Americas we spent €7.0 million on expanding the capabilities of the Houston (U.S.A.) site to support production reallocations from a closed site as well as on upgrading the Carpentersville (U.S.A.) site to support customer’s strategic requirements; €2.5 million to upgrade the Azusa site to handle UPR and gel coat production following the Lynwood and Port Moody site closures; €1.1 million to upgrade the Mogi (Brazil) sites to handle UPR and gel coat production transferred from the Taboao and Piracicaba sites; and €0.6 million for SAP implementation in Mexico to support future business growth and harmonize business processes. In Asia we spent €3.2 million for a TMA new oxidation column and a new DCS system in Changzhou (China); €2.4 million for a new UPR plant in the Johor (Malaysia) site; and €0.3 million for a new Thermal Oxidizer in the Pune (India) site. The table below provides information regarding our production facilities as of December 31, 2020. In our plants where multi-purpose equipment is used to manufacture products with different production cycles, the production capacity will vary and the data indicated below is an average for the relevant product mix. -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Product** **Application** **End Industries Electrical, Transportation, Medical SPPs Appliances Electrical, Transportation, Building Trimellitic Anhydride** **Wire enamels and Construction Building and Construction, Powder coatings Transportation, Electrical Our Operations
Subsubsection Text: We manage our operations so as to achieve control over the quality of our products and efficiently coordinate the development, production and sale of our products. We believe this approach allows us to respond to market demands in a timely and flexible manner. Our operations consist of: (i) research and development; (ii) sourcing and purchase of raw materials; (iii) production, energy sourcing and quality control; and (iv) product sales, technical assistance and distribution.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Product Sales, Technical Assistance and Distribution
Subsubsection Text: We sell our products to over 5,000 customers worldwide, primarily through our experienced, international internal sales staff who market our products in over 100 countries. Our sales employees are divided into groups with each group specializing in a specific product. The sales staff for each of our product classes are supervised by a sales manager. Our pricing policies are set by the key management team, which includes the managers of our three product classes and our managing director. The key management team sets pricing guidelines based on input on market demand they receive from our sales staff. These guidelines are then implemented by each product line manager for their specific product line. Given the technical and specialized nature of our business, we train our sales staff to have detailed knowledge of our customers’ needs. Our strategy is that our sales staff be able to anticipate customer demands for new performance chemicals and technologies. This type of customer relationship and market awareness enable us to expand the types of products we offer by developing high-demand, new products quickly. Our internal sales staff also manages our business relationships with our most significant customers. We also work with smaller external sales agents who operate in specific geographic areas where we have business relationships with customers with whom we presently engage in smaller volumes of sale, primarily in Asia and South America. The majority of our Intermediates sales contracts have pricing mechanisms whereby pricing is set on a monthly or quarterly basis based on the Platt’s price index, an index that provides market data and commodities pricing specifically for the energy sector. We, therefore, analyze our pricing for each individual product on a monthly basis, as applicable, when setting contract prices so we can pass on changes in raw material costs to customers each month or quarter when the contract price is reset. In addition, the majority ----- of our contracts contain minimum and maximum volume clauses, which limit fluctuations in order size from month-to-month or quarter-to-quarter. We seek to protect our market share by entering into long-term sales contracts. The payment terms under these contracts are set in accordance with typical chemicals industry standards, on a country-by-country basis. The majority of our Composites and Specialties sales contracts are spot contracts renegotiated on a monthly basis. The prices of these contracts are set by negotiations between us and our customers. We believe that our positioning as a market leader in these two classes helps us maintain high margins in Composites and Specialties. Once a sale is made, our internal team of specialists provides our customers with after-sale technical assistance, particularly with regard to UPRs and plasticizers. We believe that combining an internal sales team that anticipates customer needs with post-sale customer support from product specialists fosters customer loyalty to our products and our brand and establishes long-term customer relationships. We have been supplying our top customers for the past 20 years. The majority of our products are shipped to customers directly from our manufacturing plants. In some cases, we also ship our products to distribution centers worldwide where they are held before being distributed to their final destination. We also use professional distributors to distribute malic acid and UPRs to certain of our smaller volume customers. As of June 30, 2021, distribution relationships amounted to approximately 10% of our total sales volume, with the remaining 90% being from our internal sales force. Our agreements with these distributors generally grant the distributors the exclusive right to distribute our products in specified territories, subject to certain exceptions, including our right to directly sell to any customers in the defined areas. Our distributor agreements are generally short-term agreements that renew automatically and can be terminated by either party after giving the appropriate notice, which varies depending on the jurisdiction but is usually not more than approximately 90 days’-notice.
