production facilities are strategically located to enable us to efficiently organize production in response to peak demand and exploit economies of scale. A high volume of strategically-located production facilities also allows us to be close to both our suppliers and customers so we can receive materials quickly and meet client needs on a timely basis. In addition, being close to suppliers and customers allows us to transport our raw materials and products at a lower cost to us. For example, some Intermediates, specifically liquid phthalic and maleic anhydride, are expensive to transport because they must be transported at temperatures between 70 and 180 degrees Celsius; moving them over shorter distances saves us on transportation costs. ----- _Tolling Agreements_ Following our combination with the Reichhold group, the Group put in place a series of intragroup agreements for the supply of goods between Group entities. Under these tolling agreements, entities formerly belonging to the Reichhold group make available to certain Polynt entities the entire production capacity of their plants. _Energy Sourcing_ Our key sources of energy and main utilities for our production activities are electricity, natural gas, nitrogen purchased from third parties, as well as internally-produced steam. Our energy costs, including CO2 costs related to the ETS, represented 4.4%, 4.5% and 5.2% of our total material and process energy costs for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively. _Quality Control and Certification of Plants and Products_ Our analysis laboratories analyze and inspect the quality of raw materials received from our suppliers. Specifically these laboratories verify that the raw materials we receive contain the appropriate chemical properties and the other characteristics specified in our supply agreements. We typically require that raw materials are delivered to us by rail tank or tanker trucks to reduce the risk of contamination. Raw materials transported by sea are subject to a higher risk of contamination due to shipboard humidity and the routine washing of vessels. Given the higher risk of sea transportation, we retain inspection companies who perform initial inspections of ship-borne raw materials before and after they are loaded onto the ship as well after they are unloaded from the vessel. We perform a third inspection of shipborne raw materials once they arrive at our plant. We store raw materials that meet our quality specifications in dedicated storage tanks and warehouses specially designed to keep them free from contamination. Our analysis laboratories also perform quality control inspections of our finished products before sale to our customers. We have implemented required product quality and safety regulations and guidelines. These include regulations promulgated by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) in Europe, the hazard analysis and critical control points (HACCP) regulations of the Food and Drug Administration in the U.S. and guidelines issued by the insurer Lloyds of London for gelcoat used in marine products worldwide. In order to maintain certifications under these and other regulations and guidelines, our plants and products are subject to periodic inspection.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We hold patents for our catalysts as well as for our production processes. We hold 354 patents, and have an additional 107 pending patent applications. Generally, patents benefit from 20 years of protection. Our currently-issued patents will expire during the period from 2022 to 2040, with 32 patents due to expire by 2025. We do not believe the expiry of any patents in the medium term will have a material adverse effect on our business operations. We are not aware of any legal proceedings started by any parties concerning the validity of any of our patents.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We have registered 778 active trademark applications and 3 pending applications. For our UPRs we have registered the trademarks “Diplast” (for plasticizers), “Distifoam” (for expanded resins), “Distimod”, “Distigel”, “Distitron”, and “Distipol”. We use our trademark “Diplast” for our GPPs and our trademark “Polimix” for our SPPs. In addition, we have registered various trademarks for “Polynt”. We intend to continue to renew registration of the trademarks that we use.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We have registered 21 domain names.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Where appropriate, we take action to protect our proprietary rights in our innovative products, catalysts and our production processes, including through registration of trademarks and application for patents.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We rely on a number of information technology systems to support our business operations. Our core critical business systems are standard products from market leading vendors such as SAP and Microsoft. SAP infrastructure is managed in outsourcing in the IBM cloud by Kyndryl (IBM spin-off). Microsoft cloud is used for basic users service provisioning (through Office 365 service portfolio), while all the other systems are located in two data centers managed internally: the most important in Scanzorosciate and the other one in Carpentersville. These systems and software are used for our commercial activities, including sales and ----- marketing, finance, purchasing, plant maintenance and reporting. We have also implemented applicationspecific measures such as stable and redundant information technology systems, backup processes, virus and access protection and encryption systems, using standard products from market leading providers such as VMware, Veeam and Kaspersky/McAfee. We regularly test, patch and update our information technology systems. With regards to our IT security, we use products from leading producers such as ForcePoint and Varonis; there is also a C-SOC service to monitor event H24 and identify malicious activities on group IT systems through correlation analysis and classification of event and logs coming from all the IT security instruments already in place. In addition, our employees receive regular training on information and data protection. We have not had any significant information technology problems in the past.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We have insurance on our plants and equipment that we believe is in line with customary industry practices for similarly situated companies. These policies include: - Multi-risk insurance, Property Damage and Business Interruption, which provides coverage for damages caused to buildings, machinery, equipment, furnishings, mechanical failures, business interruption; - Civil liability insurance, which provides cover for certain claims involving (i) third-party liability, (ii) employee liability, (iii) personal liability of employees, and (iv) product liability; - Insurance for transportation, which provides cover for certain risks associated with the transport of raw materials and/or finished products; and - Insurance for environmental risks. These policies are subject to certain exceptions, limits and deductibles. We believe that our level of insurance is appropriate for the risks of our business. In 2021, we changed our all risks property insurer from FM Global to HDI Global, as the latter offered higher cover with a lower premium. See “Risk Factors—Risks _Related to Our Business and Industry—The high-risk nature of our production activities may result in accidents which could cause uninsured losses or losses in excess of our insurance coverage. Additionally, there may be unanticipated changes in our insurance costs”._

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: As of June 30, 2021, we employed a global workforce of 3,148 people in 17 countries. As a result of the technical nature of our business, there is a high level of technical and professional qualifications among the management, and we place a high priority on technical training and personal and professional development for all staff. Historically, we have had a generally low turnover, although recently, a shortage in factory workers across the U.S. has resulted in a high turnover as workers move employers as they are offered higher wages. In some of our locations non-management personnel are represented by local trade unions and are covered by collective bargaining agreements. In such locations, we work with trade unions in line with that country’s laws and regulations. In addition, we have employee works councils in France and Germany. Over the years, we have enjoyed a positive working relationship with our labor force and unions, and we are committed to maintaining these relationships going forward. We do not believe we have any ongoing labor disputes. We operate pension plans and other employee benefit and incentive plans in the various jurisdictions where we operate. In particular, SCIL has adopted in the exercise of its activity of direction and coordination and in the interest of the Group, two separate management incentive plans, in order to retain and reward certain managers and/or employees having a key role in the Group, which may be triggered by the Transactions (the “Management Bonuses”): - a phantom stock option plan, adopted on February 15, 2018, pursuant to which certain managers and employees of the Group are entitled to receive an extraordinary bonus upon fulfilment of the following conditions: (i) the occurrence of one of the following events within December 31, 2026: a change in ownership of the Target Group, the listing on a regulated market or distribution of an extraordinary maxi dividend; and (ii) the revaluation above a certain threshold of SCIL’s shares with respect to the reference value per share indicated in the underlying agreements; and - a separate “deal bonus plan”, entered into on December 15, 2020 with certain beneficiaries of the phantom stock option plan, pursuant to which the beneficiaries are entitled to receive an additional extraordinary bonus upon verification of additional conditions. ----- SCIL has entrusted Polynt S.p.A. with the implementation of the above management incentive plans. The Group companies have entered into a cost-sharing agreement concerning the allocation of the relevant costs, in order to uniformly distribute among the various Group companies the cost of the incentive plans of the managers and/or employees. We have defined benefit plans in the United Kingdom, Norway and Germany, all of which are no longer opened to new participants.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Environmental and Health and Safety Matters
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to manufacturing safe products and achieving an incident-free workplace. To protect employees, we have established health and safety policies, programs and processes at all our sites. We employ a variety of safety programs throughout our sites. External audits are regularly performed at each of our plants in accordance with local health and safety standards. In addition, we have an internal audit system. These efforts have resulted in a significant improvement in injury statistics in recent years. No recent work accidents have occurred that caused serious long-term disability. With specific reference to Italy, as a response to the Covid-19 pandemic, the Italian government has implemented Italian Legislative Decree No. 127/2021, pursuant to which, as of October 15, 2021, in order to allow access to workplaces, employers will be required to verify the possession by employees and visitors of the COVID-19 vaccination “green pass”(“Green Pass”) (which is a digital, printable certification that contains a two-dimensional barcode (QR Code) and a qualified electronic seal, issued through the Italian Ministry of Health’s national platform, attesting the vaccination against Covid-19 or a negative result from a Covid-19 test carried out in the prior 48 or 72 hours, depending on the type of test). In this respect, we have introduced ----- for the Italian Group companies, appropriate measures to verify possession of the Green Pass by employees and visitors accessing our workplaces in Italy, in compliance with applicable laws.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Environmental and Health and Safety Matters
Subsubsection Title: Clean-up of Polluted Soil and Groundwater
Subsubsection Text: As is customary with many companies in our industry, we are currently undertaking, and may from time to time be required to undertake, soil and groundwater clean-up efforts at our production facilities as a result of pollution caused by our, or the facilities’ previous owners’, production activities. As of June 30, 2021, we had made provisions of €23.0 million for ecological clean-up efforts. Except as detailed below, we do not believe that any of our current or prospective soil and groundwater clean-up activities are expected to have a material adverse effect on our business or operations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and _Industry—We may be subject to ongoing costs and regulations related to contamination or exposure impacts from our operations or products”._ We are currently undertaking groundwater clean-up efforts at our Scanzorosciate (Italy) and San Giovanni Valdarno (Italy) plants, soil and groundwater clean-up efforts at our Drocourt (France) plant. We are performing the clean-up works at these sites in compliance with applicable laws and regulations. All required local and national authorities have been timely informed of our efforts and have duly authorized them, as required by applicable law and regulations. The groundwater clean-up at our Scanzorosciate (Italy) plant started in 2012, and at San Giovanni Valdarno (Italy) in 2008. At both of these sites we are cleaning the contaminated water using the “pump and treat”method whereby contaminated groundwater is pumped from the site and treated to remove the contaminants. The soil clean-up at our Drocourt (France) plant started in 2014 and was first conducted by means of air sparging techniques. The outcome of this treatment was not fully satisfactory. Therefore, we expect that a new project combining air sparging and hydraulic barrier methods will be implemented to clean-up the contaminated areas. In addition, soil and groundwater remediation is ongoing at several U.S. facilities acquired from Momentive in 2011. The Lynwood, California (United States) facility is undergoing remediation efforts to address environmental contamination in the site’s soil and groundwater resulting from the operation of chemical manufacturing facilities on the site since 1950. The ongoing remediation activities include groundwater extraction wells and soil vapor extraction wells. The Carpentersville, Illinois (United Sates) facility has ongoing soil vapor extraction to recover volatile organic compounds in the soil and groundwater monitoring. Under the terms of the purchase agreement pursuant to which we acquired these facilities, Momentive has the obligation to indemnify us for environmental contamination remediation costs in a manner that caps our liability for such costs at $2.75 million. Specifically, we are liable for the first $2.0 million of any remediation costs. After this $2.0 million deductible is reached, Momentive is liable for seventy-five percent (75%) of any remediation costs between $2.0 million and $5.0 million. Momentive is also liable for all remediation costs in excess of $5.0 million. Our North Kansas City, Missouri (United States) facility, acquired in the CCP Acquisition, is undergoing ongoing long term groundwater monitoring of the identified environmental contamination in the facility’s soil and groundwater. The facility has known onsite contamination that is being addressed under an ongoing Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (“RCRA”) cleanup action. A Risked Based Closure Plan, based on current site conditions, is currently being developed for submission to the State agency. Financial reserve have been established to address the anticipated liabilities identified at this facility. Studies to date have indicated various impacted areas of soil and groundwater at the site in Burlington, Ontario, Canada, that exceed the thresholds under Canadian law. No active remediation is currently ongoing, but may be required in the future. At the Brampton, Ontario, Canada site, studies to date have indicated various impacted areas of soil and groundwater above Canadian criteria for chlorinated solvents. Remedial activities have included excavation of impacted soil with localized in situ chemical oxidation (“ISCO”) employed. The site is fully delineated with respect to identified source areas; we have biannual monitoring procedures in place, which are also used to document the fact that no further mitigation measures are required. The last groundwater sampling event occurred in June 2021.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Environmental and Health and Safety Matters
Subsubsection Text: Our Group companies do not use asbestos or its derivatives in their production activities. This material is, however, present in the roofing of certain of our warehouses and in the insulation of certain equipment and tubes. In accordance with applicable law, we have initiated clean-up efforts at our Scanzorosciate (Italy), Cavaglià (Italy) and Parma (Italy) plants. The clean-up activities in our Italian plants began in 2006 and we ----- expect they will be completed within the deadlines set by applicable local regulations. There are also a limited number of sites in Europe where asbestos is present in the roofing or in the insulation of certain equipment (i.e. Miranda (Spain), Drocourt (France), Leek (UK), Mitcham (UK), and Stallingborough(UK)). The presence of asbestos at these sites is documented and carefully monitored according to the local regulations. Even if no removal is required by local regulation, clean-up activities are periodically carried out at these sites by licensed contractors. In addition, asbestos has been located at a few of our U.S. facilities, but in those cases due to the amount and location of the asbestos, local laws and regulations do not require that we undertake clean-up or removal efforts. We monitor all of our sites to make sure we remain in compliance with laws and regulations and to provide a safe work environment for our employees. Due to the age of many of our facilities in the Americas, many of these have been documented to have some form of asbestos containing materials present in the building material and/or process equipment (thermal insulation). However, the presence of asbestos is documented and closely managed through site specific plans. Abatement is performed in conjunction with facility maintenance/expansion activities by licensed contractors and is budgeted as an annual operations expense item.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Environmental and Health and Safety Matters
Subsubsection Title: Classification of Certain Products as Substances of Very High Concern by ECHA
Subsubsection Text: The European Chemical Agency (“ECHA”) has classified five of our products as Substances of Very High Concern under REACH. Although DOP/DEHP and DINP have already been included in the Authorization List, the first is only used in the production of medical devices (a business sector to which the authorization requirements under REACH do not currently apply) and the second is an intermediate which is exempted from authorization. In addition, while TMA, HHPA and MHHPA, are classified as Substances of Very High Concern, they are not currently on the Authorization List. However, since TMA and HHPA are mostly used as intermediate or monomer we expect that the impact to the related businesses will be minimal should these substances being placed in authorization list. The fifth, MHHPA, is a special anhydride whose classification could potentially lead to it being placed on the Authorization List which could result in increased future regulation, product controls and/or procedures that could make producing or using such products in our downstream production operations uneconomical, unmanageable or otherwise commercially inefficient. We joined with a number of other major European chemical companies in appealing the ECHA’s classification of both HHPA and MHHPA as Substances of Very High Concern. Final arguments were made before the EU Court of Justice in Luxembourg on November 20, 2014, and on April 30, 2015, the EU Court of Justice issued a ruling denying our application to de-classify HHPA and MHHPA as Substances of Very High Concern. Despite the denial, they have still not been placed on the Authorization List. As of yet, classification of these special anhydrides as Substances of Very High Concern neither precludes their use by us nor does it impose increased regulation, product controls and/or procedures related to their production or use. We are pursuing other avenues to obtain an exemption from the authorization requirement and believe that the decision will not materially affect our business operations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business _and Industry—We must comply with extensive and constantly changing health, safety and environmental laws and regulations” and “Regulation—EU Regulations—Industry and Product Related Regulations—The Registration, Evaluation and Authorization of Chemicals Regulation (REACH)”._

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Environmental and Health and Safety Matters
Subsubsection Text: Our facilities and operations are subject to a wide range of health, safety, and environmental (“HSE”) laws and regulations in all of the jurisdictions in which we operate. The most relevant of these laws and regulations to our business are described in “Regulation”. These requirements govern, among other things, the manufacture, storage, handling, treatment, transportation and disposal of hazardous substances and wastes, wastewater discharges, air emissions (including GHG emissions), noise emissions, operation and closure of landfills, human health and safety, process safety and risk management and the clean-up of contaminated sites. Many of our operations require permits and controls to monitor or prevent pollution. We have incurred, and will continue to incur, capital and operating expenditures to ensure compliance with current and future HSE laws, regulations and permits or the more stringent enforcement of such requirements. Environmental regulations generally govern emissions into the atmosphere, water and soil, as well as the treatment, storage and elimination of residues from industrial production. The limits set forth in the applicable regulations often limit the quantity of raw materials and other substances that we can use in our products. Some of the raw materials we process are regulated as substances capable of causing an accident potentially dangerous for human health and the environment, such as a fire or explosion during plant operations. The Group has in place a sustainability policy that is executed by the chief executive officer of the Group. The Group continually works to reduce operational energy consumption through facility renovation and equipment upgrades. We also continue to evaluate opportunities to minimize waste generation at all of our facilities. Our efforts to reduce industrial wastes include the beneficial reuse of used/spent solvents both internally and externally. We have also recently appointed an ESG manager, who will be responsible for internal auditing of ESG-related matters. With respect to risks related to our supply chain, this is managed and monitored at a corporate level as far as primary raw materials are concerned, whereas other raw materials are generally purchased locally under corporate supervision. We hold regular business meetings to coordinate our efforts and initiatives to reduce our supply chain risks. Additionally, we screen our suppliers against sanctions and embargo lists and we perform supply chain risk assessments and audits. We believe that our operations are currently in material compliance with all HSE laws, regulations and permits. We actively address compliance issues in connection with our operations and properties and we believe that we have systems in place to mitigate our environmental costs and liabilities. See “Risk Factors— _Risks Related to Our Business—The high-risk nature of our production activities may result in accidents which could cause uninsured losses or losses in excess of our insurance coverage. Additionally, there may be unanticipated changes in our insurance costs”._

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: As is customary with many companies in our industry, we are and may from time to time become a party to claims and legal actions that arise in the ordinary course of business. We are not currently involved in any material legal, governmental or arbitration proceedings which could, individually or in the aggregate, adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition, and, we are not aware of any material governmental, legal or arbitration proceedings (including any such proceedings which are pending or threatened of which we are aware), during the past three years, which may have, or have had in the recent past, adverse effects on our financial position or profitability. However, we note that: - Polynt Composites Brazil Ltda. (“PC Brazil”) and Reichhold do Brasil Ltda. (“Reichhold Brazil”) are involved in approximately 65 pending litigations in Brazil relating to civil, environmental, tax and labour disputes as defendants and approximately 110 pending litigations relating to civil disputes as plaintiffs. None of the proceedings is material. - PC Brazil and Reichhold Brazil are involved in administrative proceedings relating to an alleged cartel investigated by the Brazilian antitrust authority (“CADE”), which has not yet been subject to a final judgment. Although Reichhold Brazil signed a leniency agreement (granting Reichhold Brazil full administrative immunity, and criminal immunity to the individuals who signed the leniency agreement) and PC Brazil has entered into a settlement agreement (granting PC Brazil a discount on the applicable ----- fine), both agreements and full compliance with the obligations set out therein must be confirmed by CADE in its final decision regarding the case, which as of the date of this Offering Memorandum has not yet been issued. - On December 14, 2018, the Italian Tax Police (Guardia di Finanza) issued a notice of dispute (processo _verbale di contestazione, the “PVC”) against Polynt S.p.A. following a tax audit for the 2014, 2015,_ 2016 and 2017 fiscal years, and containing certain allegations in relation to which the Italian Tax Authority (Agenzia delle Entrate) identified additional tax payments allegedly due by Polynt S.p.A. in an aggregate amount of €13,683,274 plus interest and penalties. In December 2019, the Italian Tax Authority issued tax assessments for fiscal year 2014 against Polynt S.p.A. with respect to the matters identified in the PVC, claiming additional tax payments in an aggregate amount of €1,156,000 plus interest and penalties. The main allegations were with respect to (i) the royalty rate charged by Polynt S.p.A. to related parties in connection with the trademark “Polynt”, and (ii) a portion of certain costs borne by Polynt S.p.A. and allegendly not recharged or rebilled to the proper related party, being such expenses allegedly for the benefit of the whole Target Group. In order to prove the groundlessness of the Italian tax authorities’ allegations, in July 2020 Polynt S.p.A. started a tax litigation before the competent Tax Court. Further, in June 2021 the Italian Tax Authority issued two tax assessments against Polynt S.p.A. in relation to fiscal year 2015, claiming additional tax payments in an aggregate amount of €4,789,000 plus interest and penalties. In respect to these latter tax claims, in July 2021 Polynt S.p.A. filed a tax assessment settlement with the Italian tax authorities which is currently ongoing. Currently, the Group has allocated €6.2 million as provision for this matter. - Polynt Composites USA Inc. (“PC USA”) is a defendant (among others) in an alleged toxic injury case, in which the plaintiff is alleging that he developed cancer from his exposure to toxic chemicals he used throughout the course of his career as a mannequin manufacturer and seeking damages in excess of US$ 13,000,000. In addition, in April 2021, PC USA entered into a settlement for a non-material amount in a separate toxic injury case, in which it was alleged that the deceased had been exposed to chemicals produced by PC USA’s predecessor, Cook Composites Co., while the deceased was employed at a waste disposal company. - We are involved in a small number of claims in the United States for product liability, which we expect to resolve or settle for non-material amounts. The outcome of legal proceedings, however, can be extremely difficult to predict with certainty, and we can offer no assurances in this regard. -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: _In this section, we rely on and refer to information regarding the global chemical additives market as well as the key markets in which our business operates and competes. The market data and industry data and forecasts provided below are based on our beliefs and estimates, as well as internal company reports as well as reports prepared by third parties. This section also contains estimates of market data and information derived from such data that cannot be obtained from independent sources. Such information, including data relating to our market share, is partly based on our own market observations, our evaluation of industry information (such as from conferences and sector events) or internal assessments. We believe that our estimates of market data and the information we have derived from such data helps investors to better understand the industry in which we operate and our position within it. Our own estimates have not been checked or verified externally. While we assume that our own market observations are reliable, we give no warranty for the accuracy of our own estimates and the information derived from them. They may differ from estimates made by our competitors or from other independent sources.Furthermore, certain information set forth in this section has been derived from external sources, and the accuracy and completeness of such information is not guaranteed. While we believe that the data is reliable, neither we, the Group, nor the Initial Purchasers have independently verified such data and cannot guarantee their accuracy or completeness. Forward-looking statements in this section are not guarantees of future performance and actual events and circumstances could differ materially from current expectations. Numerous factors could cause or contribute to such differences. See “Risk Factors” and “Forward-Looking Statements”._

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsubsection Text: Our business is highly regulated in all of the jurisdictions in which we operate. Our production facilities and operations are subject to both national and international regulatory regimes. In the Member States, the regulatory environment of our business activities is shaped by EU directives and regulations, which are either implemented in the individual Member States through national legislation or have direct application to the states or individuals. In the U.S., the regulatory environment is shaped by federal and state laws and regulations. Regulations that affect our operations mostly relate to areas of environmental protection, product safety and quality, occupational health and safety, industrial hygiene and plant safety. HSE laws and regulations govern our facilities and our operations, including: (i) the storage, handling, treatment and disposal of hazardous substances and waste; (ii) water intake, wastewater and sewage discharges; (iii) air emissions; (iv) human health and safety; (v) the clean-up and remediation of contaminated sites; and (vi) the sale and use of the products we manufacture. Many of our operations require permits and controls to monitor or prevent pollution. We have incurred, and will continue to incur, substantial on-going capital and operating expenditures to ensure compliance with current and future HSE laws and regulations, which tend to become more stringent over time, and the more stringent enforcement of these laws and regulations. Our environmental management systems are intended to ensure that we both comply with applicable environmental requirements and minimize environmental risk by promoting environmental protection activities and initiatives. We actively address legal compliance issues in connection with our operations and properties, and we believe that we have systems in place to ensure that environmental costs and liabilities will not have a material adverse impact on us. Nevertheless, estimates of future environmental costs and liabilities are inherently imprecise, and the imposition of new or unanticipated costs or obligations could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsubsection Text: _The Registration, Evaluation and Authorization of Chemicals Regulation (“REACH Regulation”)_ The use, manufacture and importing of chemicals is highly regulated in the European Union. On June 1, 2007, Regulation 1907/2006 concerning REACH entered into force. The REACH Regulation, as subsequently amended, requires that chemical substances or preparations manufactured, imported or otherwise placed within the European Union in quantities exceeding one ton per year, be registered with the European Chemicals Agency (“ECHA”). Full registration requires the provision of comprehensive data on the identification, properties, uses, classification and labeling of the relevant substance, exposure scenarios and, for substances which meet the requirements of Article 31(1) of REACH, for example because they are substances which are classified as persistent, bioaccumulative and toxic, a detailed chemical Safety Data Sheet. The registration process is aimed at generating data on chemicals and enhancing the safety of chemicals in their various uses within the European Union. Producers and importers of substances in the European Union must obtain information on the substances they manufacture or import to assess the risks arising from their use and to ensure that risks are properly managed. REACH, which came into force in 2007, provides for a registration process for the use or sale of substances deemed particularly hazardous and specified in Annex XIV of the regulation, an Authorization ----- will be required. The list of substances on this “Authorization List” is regularly reviewed and new substances can be added to the list. before they can be manufactured, imported or sold in the European Union. The manufacture and placing on the market of certain dangerous substances in the European Union is also restricted by REACH. The manufacture, importation or use of certain substances may be restricted or banned in the European Union under REACH. Annex XVII of the REACH Regulation lists these restricted substances and further substances may be added to this annex by the Commission. REACH also requires that certain information concerning chemical substances is made publicly available unless it is specifically marked as confidential. There are also additional legislative provisions in Europe, such as the Aarhus Convention, which grants public rights regarding access to information held by EU bodies and which could result in groups such as environmental pressure groups requesting and obtaining additional information on our products. Our spending on compliance with the REACH regulation amounted to approximately €10 million, including registration costs from the first REACH registration deadline in 2010 until June 30, 2021. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we cannot estimate an amount for future REACH compliance spending, but we believe that the expenses will be approximately €1 million per year over the next few years. _Classification, Labeling and Packaging of Substances and Mixtures—CLP_ CLP works in connection with REACH to regulate and standardize these areas in the European Union. Obligations under CLP apply to manufacturers, importers, downstream users, distributors and persons who use substances caught by the CLP Regulation as a component to a larger product. The obligations under CLP depend on the role of the party in this supply chain. For example, manufactures and importers are obliged to ensure that their substances are classified, labeled and packaged in accordance with CLP before they are placed on the market. These classification and notification elements should be notified to the classification and labeling inventory established by the ECHA. The manufacturer and importer is also required to take all reasonable steps available to it to make it aware of any new scientific or technical information that may affect the classification of the substance and if required by this information undertake a new evaluation of the classification and labeling of the substance. The manufacturer and importer also have an ongoing obligation to update the classification and labeling of a substance if required. _Food Contact Controls_ Our European facilities produce substances which may come into contact with food. European Regulation 1935/2004, as subsequently amended, on materials and articles intended to come into contact with food (the “Regulation 1935”) entered into force on December 3, 2004, and is directly applicable in Member States. It seeks to ensure the protection of human health and the interests of consumers with regard to materials and articles intended to come into contact with food, either directly or indirectly. Regulation 1935 applies to all materials and articles, including active and intelligent food contact materials and articles which in their finished state are already in contact, are intended to be brought into contact, or can reasonably be expected to be brought into contact, with food. Regulation 1935 requires materials and articles to be manufactured in accordance with good manufacturing practice. The materials and articles must not transfer substances to the food with which they are in contact in quantities likely to endanger human health or which could bring about an unacceptable change in the composition of the food or deterioration in certain characteristics of the food. If active or intelligent materials and articles intentionally change the composition, or certain characteristics, of food, they must comply with additional provisions in Directive 89/107/EEC as implemented. For certain materials and articles listed in Regulation 1935, the Commission may also adopt specific measures. In the absence of Community level specific measures, Member States may maintain or adopt national provisions provided they comply with the rules of the EC Treaty. The list of specific measures which may be adopted for the materials and articles listed in Annex I to the Regulation include, for example, limits on the migration of certain constituents into or onto food and specific procedural rules for the authorization of a substance, process, material or article. Where a list of authorized substances is adopted for a certain material or article as a specific measure (at a Community or national level), the relevant substances have to undergo a safety assessment prior to their authorization. Any new applications for the authorization of a substance used in the manufacture of materials or articles intended to come into contact with food must be made to the competent authority of the Member ----- State where the substance is to be placed on the market and also to the European Food Safety Authority. The authorization of a new substance will be made in the form of a Community level specific measure. Materials and articles must be labeled appropriately and the traceability of a material or article (and, where appropriate, the substances used in their manufacture) must be ensured at all times. Additionally, Regulation 10/2011 applies. This is a specific measure within the meaning of Article 5(1) of Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004. This Regulation should establish the specific rules for plastic materials and articles to be applied for their safe use and repeals Commission Directive 2002/72/EC of August 6, 2002 on plastic materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs.

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsubsection Text: Our manufacturing sites in Europe are subject to significant regulation regarding the operation of chemical plants both at EU-wide level and also at the level of individual Member States, who, as well as having individual legislation implementing applicable European environmental directives may have state specific legislation which may impose stricter controls or requirements than the EU-wide level legislation. Regulation of environmental and health and safety issues is considerable. Legislation has been adopted in diverse areas, including but not limited to, waste prevention and control, fire safety, protection against explosive hazards, storage, transport and use of hazardous substances, air emissions, wastewater management and discharges, environmental liability, integrated permitting, noise and groundwater protection. Member States typically have a certain degree of national authority to choose means of implementing an EU Directive, though its timing and main purpose and objectives are binding upon Member States. EU Regulations are binding on individual Member States without requiring national legislation. These EU Directives and Regulations set a common EU-wide standard of operation that, in some cases, may be made stricter by Member States’ authorities. Other areas of law, especially contaminated land regulations, are largely a matter of domestic Member State law, with limited EU-wide harmonization, regarding permit granting procedures or enforcement. Fines and penalties for non-compliance with environmental and health and safety issues vary across Member States, but most Member States impose some sort of penalty on such noncompliance. _Industrial Emissions Directive_ The Industrial Emissions Directive (2010/75/EU), as subsequently amended, amends, consolidates and replaces seven pieces of EU legislation controlling industrial emissions (the “IED”). It came into force on January 6, 2011 and most installations will be required to comply with the IED from January 7, 2014. It covers a wide range of industrial installations which operate above certain thresholds in a variety of industry sectors, including the chemicals industry. The IED’s aims are to prevent or reduce emissions from industrial installations to air, land and water. It requires, among other things, that installations which fall within its scope to operate under a permit and such permits are to be conditional on “BAT conclusions”. Best Available Techniques (“BAT”) conclusions are documents which set out what constitutes the BAT for a particular activity, including emissions levels, monitoring and remediation. When an installation is closed the IED also requires that permitting authorities must ensure that steps are taken to avoid any pollution caused by the closure of the site and that measures are taken to return the site to a satisfactory state. Operators of sites which use hazardous substances are required to prepare a baseline report setting out information that will enable the state of contamination of soil and ground water at the site to be compared when the site is closed. Through Legislative Decree no. 46/2014 (which amended the existing Legislative Decree no. 152/2006 (also called the Italian Environmental Code)) Italy implemented the IED. Our European facilities are subject to Member States’ laws implementing Directive 89/391, as subsequently amended, on measures to encourage improvements in the safety and health of workers (the “HSW Directive”). The HSW Directive, as subsequently amended, aims to eliminate the risk factors for occupational diseases and accidents by establishing rules on protecting the health and safety of workers. Its provisions relate to all sectors of activity, both public and private. An employer under the HSW Directive has a duty to ensure the health and safety of workers in every aspect of their work, including if they enlist external companies or persons. While workers are required to take care of their own safety and health in accordance with their training, the obligations on an employer require it to take the measures necessary for the safety and health protection of workers based on a system of adaptable risk prevention and management, the provision of information to workers, common protective measures and training, and the provision of the necessary organization and means for the protection of workers. ----- Employers must also adapt first aid, fire-fighting and evacuation procedures to the activities and size of the relevant activity. Again, protective and preventative services must be established, including the appointment of trained workers, to enable the employer to react to serious danger. Workers must be consulted regarding health and safety issues in the workplace and employers are required to ensure that they monitor the health of workers in accordance with national legislation, including regular health checks if requested. The HSW Directive, as subsequently amended, was implemented in Italy by Legislative Decree no. 81/2008 as subsequently amended, inter alia, by the Legislative Degree no. 32/2013. _Contest of Major Accident Hazards Involving Dangerous Substances_ Our European facilities are subject to Member States’ implementation of Directive 96/82/EC relating to the prevention and management of incidents in relation to the use, manufacture and storage of hazardous substances, as amended by Directive 2003/105/EC (the “SEVESO II Directive”). The SEVESO II Directive has been amended by Directive 2012/18/EU (the “SEVESO III Directive”) which came into force on August 13, 2012 and repeals and replaces the SEVESO II Directive from June 1, 2015. The SEVESO III Directive aims are the prevention of major accident hazards involving dangerous substances and the limitation of the consequences of any such accidents if they do occur. The SEVESO III Directive provides for three levels of proportionate controls which in practice means that operations storing larger quantities of dangerous substances are under more controls. “Upper tier establishments”companies are establishments in which dangerous substances are present in quantities which exceed threshold value determined in the SEVESO III Directive. These installations are subject to all of the requirements of the SEVESO III Directive, including submitting a notification to the relevant authority, establishing a major accident prevention policy and a safety management system, submitting a safety report and emergency plan to the relevant local authorities and prepare external emergency plans, which are subject to public consultation. Upper tier establishments are also required to regularly test their internal and external emergency plans. The SEVESO III Directive was implemented in Italy through Italian Legislative Decree No. 105/2015. _Fire Security and Explosion Hazard Rules_ Since July 2003 organizations in the European Union are required to follow the ATEX Directives. ATEX 95 (Directive 94/9/EC) regulated safety devices and equipment intended for use in potentially explosive atmospheres. On April 20, 2016, a new ATEX 114 (Directive 2014/34/EU) came into force, repealing ATEX 95. The essential parts of the directive relating to scope and classification have not changed, while new definitions, new requirements for notified bodies and a common template for the EU declaration of conformity have been introduced. Under ATEX114, equipment and protective devices and systems intended for use in potentially explosive atmospheres have to meet essential safety and health requirements; as a result, all protective equipment at our facilities must conform with these requirements. ATEX 114 was implemented in Italy through Legislative Decree no. 85/2016 (while ATEX 95 was implemented through Presidential Decree no. 126/1998). In addition ATEX 137 (Directive 99/92/EC, as subsequently amended) established minim requirements for improving the safety and health protection of workers potentially at risk from flammable atmospheres. ATEX 137 was implemented in Italy through Legislative Decree no. 233/03. Under ATEX 137 rules Under ATEX 137 rules, employers must ensure the health and safety of workers by taking all organizational and/or technical measures to prevent the formation of an explosive environment or, where the nature of the activity precludes this, to remove sources of ignition, and mitigate the detrimental effects of an explosion. Where necessary, these measures shall be combined and/or supplemented with measures to prevent the propagation of explosions. Essentially, employers are required to classify areas where hazardous explosive atmospheres may occur at their installation into zones. The classification given to an area relates to the chances of an explosive atmosphere occurring and being maintained. The employer is also required to produce an “Explosion Protection Document” which, among other things, is required to demonstrate that explosion risks have been determined and assessed, hazardous areas have been classified into zones and appropriate signs displayed, workplace and work equipment designed, operated and maintained with due regard for safety, and that procedures are in place for the safe use of equipment. Ensuring that these ATEX Directives are complied with can include the performance of modification work, such as screening and/or the ventilating certain particular areas. _Pressure Equipment Directive_ The Pressure Equipment Directive (Directive 2014/68/EU) (the “PED”) sets out the standards for the design, manufacture, testing and conformity assessment of pressure equipment and assemblies of pressure ----- equipment constituting an integrated whole. Pressure equipment means steam boilers, pressure vessels, piping, safety valves and other components and assemblies subject to pressure loading, generally over 25 liters in volume and subject to a maximum allowable pressure greater than 0.5 bar (i.e., 0.5 bar above atmospheric pressure) that pose a hazard due to pressure. All pressure equipment and assemblies within the scope of the PED must be safe when placed on the market and put into service. Member States must take steps to ensure that pressure equipment cannot be placed on the market if, when installed, maintained or used, risks are adequately controlled, the design and the manufacture of pressure equipment are subject to essential safety requirements. This new approach means that Member States cannot prohibit, restrict or impede the placing on the market or putting into service of pressure equipment complying with the provisions of the Directive. Directive 97/93/EC has been implemented in Italy through Legislative Decree 25 February 2000 no. 93, while Directive 2014/68/EU has been implemented through Legislative Decree no. 26/2016. _International Transport of Dangerous Goods_ The international transport of dangerous goods is regulated by international agreements concerning the International Carriage of Dangerous Goods by Road (“ADR”) and by Rail (“RID”). Moreover, it is regulated by the International Maritime Dangerous Goods Code (the “IMDG”), developed by the International Maritime Organization as a uniform international code for the transport of dangerous goods by sea covering such matters as packing, container traffic and stowage, with particular reference to the segregation of incompatible substances. The ADR and RID have drawn up a list of dangerous goods, indicating whether their transport is prohibited or not and defining the requirements for their transport if it is authorized. Moreover, these agreements, which are regularly amended and updated since their entry into force, establish, inter alia, provisions regarding packaging and labeling of the goods, and construction, equipment and operation of the vehicle carrying the goods in question. At the EU level, Directive 2008/68/EC establishes a common regime for all aspects of the inland transport of dangerous goods, by road, rail and inland waterways within the European Union, making reference to the texts of the mentioned international agreements. Directive 2008/68/EC, as subsequently amended, has been implemented in Italy through Legislative Decree 27 January 2010 no. 35. _Carbon Dioxide Reduction and Emissions Trading Rules_ The European Union’s implementation of the Kyoto Protocol’s requirements regarding greenhouse gas emission reductions consists of a wide variety of rules and regulations to reduce the European Union’s carbon footprint in the areas of energy efficiency regulations, carbon dioxide emissions allowances trading, renewable energy requirements and construction requirements for the energy efficiency of buildings. It also imposes certain energy efficiency requirements for energy-using end products. The European Union’s emission trading scheme (“EU ETS”) establishes a scheme for greenhouse gas emission allowance trading within the EU. The EU ETS and the related legislation covers many installations in the chemicals sector by virtue of operating large combustion installations (20MW or over) such as boiler houses and generators. Operators of such an installation are required to monitor all emissions of carbon dioxide from the installation and to surrender allowances in respect of them. In particular, such installations receive a certain number of allowances to emit carbon dioxide or other greenhouse gases (European Union Allowances -“EUA”) and must surrender one allowance for each ton of a greenhouse gas emitted. Sites that emit fewer tons of greenhouse gases than their allowances cover are able to sell the excess allowances in the open market, whereas those that emit more must buy additional allowances through the EU ETS. Allocation of EUA has been largely for free, with each Member State receiving an allocation of EUAs and then subsequently allocating them to installations caught by the EU ETS through a National Allocations Plan. The EU ETS mechanism is split into different phases, Phase I of the EU ETS ran from 2005 to 2007, Phase II ran from 2008 to 2012, coinciding with the commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, and Phase III ran from 2013 to 2020. The EU ETS is now in its fourth phase (“Phase IV”), running from 2021 to 2030. The European Union has set an overall environmental target of a 20% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2020 and a 30% reduction if an international agreement is reached under which other developed countries commit to comparable efforts. The changes to the EU ETS for Phase III are part of the European Union’s climate and energy package, which is designed to help achieve these targets. Phase III covered, inter alia, the releases of carbon dioxide from the production of bulk organic chemicals and the releases of nitrous oxide from the production of nitric, adipic, glyoxal and glyoxylic acid. During Phase III, a single EU-wide cap on emissions applied in place of the previous system of national caps, therefore Member States received and allocated fewer EUAs and certain types of installations received no free EUA ----- allocation. Moreover, auctioning, not free allocation, is the new default method for allocating allowances. As a result, since free allocations are far more severely restricted, a large number of EU installations are required to purchase their EUAs through an auction or through the emissions trading markets instead. Even if an installation does qualify to receive free allocations of EUAs, the proportion of free EUAs will decrease over time. The amount of EUAs a qualifying installation received during Phase III was linked to a “benchmark” emissions level calculated, as a starting point, on the basis of the top 10% of the most GHG efficient EU installations in the sector or subsector for a product. Installations which were not as efficient as these top 10% plants were required to purchase additional EUAs to cover their higher level emissions or invest in new technology to bring their emission levels in line with these top 10% installations. To achieve the EU’s overall greenhouse gas emissions reduction target for 2030, the sectors covered by the EU ETS must reduce their emissions by 43% compared to 2005 levels. The revised EU ETS Directive (Phase IV), which will apply for the period 2021-2030, will enable this through a mix of interlinked measures. The changes introduced by Phase IV mainly include strengthening the role of the ETS as an investment driver by increasing the rate of annual allowance reduction to 2.2% (linear reduction factor) from 2021 and strengthening the Market Stability Reserve (a mechanism established by the EU in 2015 to reduce surplus allowances in the carbon market and increase the resilience of the EU ETS to future shocks), continuing to allocate free allowances as a safeguard for the international competitiveness of industrial sectors at risk of carbon leakage, while ensuring that the rules for determining free allocation are targeted and take into account technological progress and supporting industry and the energy sector to enable them to meet the innovation and investment challenges of the transition to a low-carbon economy through various low-carbon financing mechanisms. The number of free allowances allocated also depends on whether an installation falls within a sector which is deemed to be vulnerable to “carbon leakage,” a phenomenon by which tighter regulation drives production out of Europe to countries where emissions of greenhouse gases are not constrained and production is therefore cheaper. Decision 2010/2/EU and, more recently, Decision 2014/746/EU designated the (sub) sectors which are deemed to be exposed to a significant risk of carbon leakage. The manufacture of bulk organic chemicals has been included in this list. Those sectors deemed to be exposed to such risk will be eligible to receive a greater proportion of free allowances. The EU ETS was implemented in Italy through Legislative Decree no. 216/2006. At the international level, in December 2009, more than 27 nations, including the United States and China, agreed to support the Copenhagen Accord, which endorsed the continuation of the Kyoto Protocol and includes a nonbinding commitment on several countries to reduce their GHG emissions. The international community in December 2015 adopted the Paris Agreement, a global climate change agreement aimed at limiting global warming to below 2 degrees Celsius compared to pre-industrial levels. The agreement called for nations to submit nationally determined contributions that set forth the actions individual countries will take to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions to meet the goals of the Paris Agreement by 2020. These plans are then to be strengthened in the years to come. The Paris Agreement also requires countries to report regularly on their emissions and implementation efforts. There will also be a global review every 5 years to assess progess towards meeting the agreement’s goals. _Environmental Liability and Waste Framework Directives_ Our European facilities will be subject to a range of national laws concerning contaminated land and water. The Environmental Liability Directive (Directive 2004/35/EC) (the “ELD”) came into force on April 30, 2004 and aims to prevent and remedy environmental damage by establishing a framework for environmental liability based on the “polluter pays” principle. Environmental damage includes direct or indirect damage to protected species and natural habitats, water damage and land damage creating a significant risk to human health. Its fundamental aim is to hold operators whose activities have caused environmental damage financially liable for remedying the damage. In addition, the directive holds those whose activities caused an imminent threat of environmental damage liable to taking preventative actions. The ELD establishes a principle of liability where it is possible to demonstrate a causal link between environmental damage, or the imminent threat of damage, and certain occupational activities. The ELD lists those activities which include installations producing dangerous chemical substances. In certain circumstances the operator of a listed activity may be held liable for environmental damage on a strict liability basis. Liability for damage or the imminent threat of damage will be fault based where it arises from an activity outside those specifically listed in the ELD. Where there is an imminent threat of environmental damage, a Member State’s competent authority may require an operator to take preventive measures or the authority can take the necessary preventive measures ----- itself and recover any costs incurred. Where environmental damage has already occurred, the competent authority has the power to require the operator responsible to take the necessary restorative measures or, again, the authority can take those measures itself and recover any costs incurred. The ELD was implemented in Italy through Legislative Decree no. 152/2006, as subsequently amended. In addition, our European business is subject to a wider range of waste laws. The Waste Framework Directive (2008/98) (the “WFD”), as subsequently amended, aims to protect the environment and human health through the prevention of the harmful effects of waste generation and management. Member States are required to take measures for the treatment of waste in line with the waste hierarchy (set out below) which prioritizes how waste in Europe should be managed: prevention; preparing for reuse; recycling; other recovery, notably energy recovery; and disposal. In accordance with the “polluter pays” principle, the costs of waste management are to be borne by the original waste producer or by the current or previous waste holders. Any producer or holder of waste is required to carry out its own waste treatment or have treatment carried out by another establishment. Hazardous waste is prohibited from being mixed, requires appropriate labeling and packaging, and also requires storage and treatment in conditions that ensure the protection of health and the environment. Under the WFD, an establishment which intends to carry out waste treatment is obligated to obtain a permit from the relevant competent authority which will determine the quantity and type of treated waste, the method used, and monitoring and control operations allowed under the permit. The competent authorities of each Member State must establish waste management plans and prevention programs. These plans contain, notably, the type, quantity and source of waste, existing collection systems and location criteria. The prevention programs had to be established no later than December 12, 2013. Italy adopted the “National Program of Waste Prevention” on October 7, 2013. _European Feed Regulation: Regulation (EC) No 1831/2003_ Preservatives and other such substances produced in our European facilities will, if used in animal nutrition, be subject to Regulation 1831/2003 (the “Feed Additives Regulation”), as subsequently amended, which sets out rules for the authorization, supervision and labeling of feed additives. These rules aim to establish a community-wide procedure for authorizing the placing on the market and use of feed additives. Under the Feed Additives Regulation, no additive can be placed on the market, processed or used unless it is covered by an authorization granted under the Feed Additives Regulation and various conditions, including appropriate labeling (by, among others, the producer of the substance), have been met. Applications for the authorizations of feed additives are sent via the European Commission to the European Food Safety Authority (the “EFSA”). The EFSA conducts an evaluation of the relevant data and provides the Commission with a decision within six months. The Commission is then responsible for drafting a Regulation to either grant or deny authorization following a procedure that involves the Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health—Animal Nutrition (established by Regulation 178/2002). Under the Feed Additives Regulation, the Commission is responsible for establishing a register of authorized feed additives. In this respect, certain transitional measures exist within the Feed Additives Regulation to cover applications for the re-evaluation of certain feed additives on the register whereby the application for re-evaluation must be made by a certain date or the additive must be withdrawn from the market. _European Green Deal_ The European Green Deal is a set of policy initiatives of the European Commission with the overarching aim of making Europe carbon neutral by 2050. In the context of the European Green Deal, the National Emissions reduction Commitments (NEC) Directive (2016/2284/EU) sets more ambitious reduction commitments for 2030 in order to reduce the health impacts of air pollution by half compared with 2005. The NEC Directive introduces a number of reporting requirements for Member States, highlighting the importance of such reports for assessing the progress in the reduction of air pollution in the EU and for ascertaining whether Member States are in compliance with their commitments. Moreover, the revised Renewal Energy Directive (COM(2021) 557 final)—tabled by the European Commission on 14 July 2021—introduces amendments to the Renewable Energy Directive (REDII— ----- Directive (EU) 2018/2001), Regulation (EU) 2018/1999 and Directive 98/70/EC as regards the promotion of energy from renewable sources, repealing Council Directive (EU) 2015/652. Such amendments aim to introduce an increased target to produce 40% of energy from renewable sources by 2030, proposing specific targets for renewable energy use and strengthening sustainability criteria for the use of bioenergy. The implementation of the aforementioned measures may lead to an increase in carbon pricing, which would affect our industry, given the relatively high amount of carbon emitted at some of our facilities.

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsubsection Title: Toxic Substances Control Act and Green Chemistry Initiatives
Subsubsection Text: The TSCA imposes requirements on persons and companies that manufacture, process, distribute, use or dispose of regulated chemicals. Among other things, under TSCA the EPA has the authority to: (i) require testing of chemicals; (ii) undertake pre-market review and impose restrictions upon new chemicals; (iii) limit or prohibit the manufacture, use, distribution and disposal of chemical substances; (iv) impose reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and (v) regulate the export and import of chemical substances. In recent years, the EPA has also undertaken efforts to more stringently and comprehensively enforce TSCA. For example, the EPA has issued “chemical action plans” and has identified a work plan for further review and risk assessment of additional chemicals over the next several years. The EPA may impose civil and criminal liability for TSCA violations. In recent years there have been a number of proposals to significantly amend or reform TSCA, including through federal legislative proposals that have repeatedly been introduced in the U.S. Congress. On June 22, 2016, the Frank R. Lautenberg Chemical Safety For the 21[st] Century Act was signed into law, which amended TSCA in significant ways. The law includes a mandatory requirement for EPA to evaluate existing chemicals within established deadlines, provides for risk-based chemical assessments, creates more public transparency on chemical information, and provides funding for the EPA to carry out its responsibilities under TSCA. We perform regular TSCA reviews and to confirm that all chemicals manufactured (and/or imported) are listed on the active TSCA chemical list and otherwise comply with all TSCA requirements. Our products in the U.S. are TSCA (active) listed, as required by TSCA regulations. Currently, phthalic anhydride is the only one of our products that is a high priority risk-based substance currently under risk assessment review by USEPA under TSCA. As the EPA intends to add more chemicals to their priority list, we cannot predict the long term impact of TSCA to our product portfolio and economic conditions will be. In addition, numerous state, local and industry groups have implemented so-called green chemistry or similar chemicals focused initiatives to identify, prioritize, and restrict existing chemicals. The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (“OSHA”) is also currently phasing in a hazard communication regulation intended to harmonize the U.S. system of Material Safety Data sheet hazard information with the United Nation’s Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals. These or other similar future changes to chemicals regulation in the U.S. could place additional substantial regulatory burdens on the industry.

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsubsection Text: The CAA and its implementing regulations, as well as corresponding state laws and regulations governing emissions of pollutants into the air, impose permitting and emission control requirements. Standards promulgated pursuant to the CAA may require that we install controls at or make other changes to our facilities. If new controls or changes to operations are needed, the costs could be significant. In addition, failure to comply with the requirements of the CAA and its implementing regulations could result in substantial fines, civil or criminal penalties, or other sanctions. The regulation of air emissions under the CAA requires that we obtain permits for the construction, modification, and operation of our equipment, comply with permit requirements, and incur capital expenditures for the installation of certain air pollution control devices at our facilities. Measures have been taken to comply with various regulations specific to our operations, such as: National Ambient Air Quality Standards applicable to emissions of criteria pollutants including particulate matter, ozone, carbon monoxide and lead; the New Source Review Program requiring that new or modified sources install stringent control technology; National Emission Standard for Hazardous Air Pollutants; and, New Source Performance ----- Standards. We have incurred, and expect to continue to incur, substantial capital expenditures to maintain compliance with these and other air emission regulations that have been promulgated or may be promulgated or revised in the future.

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsubsection Title: Climate Change and Greenhouse Gas Emissions Rules
Subsubsection Text: Regulation of greenhouse gases in the United States is currently subject to complicated domestic and international political, policy and economic dynamics, and the regulatory landscape is rapidly changing. We are monitoring GHG emissions from our operations in accordance with the GHG emissions reporting rule and believe that our monitoring activities are in substantial compliance with applicable reporting obligations. These EPA rulemakings could adversely affect our operations and restrict or delay our ability to obtain air permits for new or modified sources. Given that the EPA is engaged in ongoing GHG rulemaking, and in light of legislative and judicial challenges to the EPA action, significant uncertainty currently exists as to how GHG regulations will in the future impact our facilities in the United States, and what costs or operational changes these regulations may require. In addition, Congress has from time to time considered legislation to reduce emissions of GHGs. In the absence of such federal climate legislation, a number of state and regional efforts have emerged that are aimed at tracking and/or reducing GHG emissions by means of cap and trade programs, including the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative and California’s AB32 cap-and-trade program. The proposed and existing programs typically require major sources of GHG emissions, such as electric power plants, to acquire and surrender emission allowances in return for emitting those GHGs. Additional future regulation of GHGs in the United States could occur pursuant to future international treaty obligations, regulatory changes under the CAA or other existing legislation, or federal, state or regional adoption of GHG regulatory schemes. This could cause us to incur additional costs in complying with any new regulations, which may adversely impact our operations and financial condition.

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsubsection Title: Management of Hazardous Substances and Contamination
Subsubsection Text: Under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (“CERCLA”) and related state laws, certain persons may be liable at sites where or from release or threatened release of hazardous substances has occurred or is threatened. These persons can include the current owner or operator of property where a release or threatened release occurred, any persons who owned or operated the property when the release occurred, and any persons who disposed of, or arranged for the transportation or disposal of, hazardous substances at a contaminated property. Liability under the CERCLA is strict, retroactive and, under certain circumstances, joint and several, so that any responsible party may be held liable for the entire cost of investigating and remediating the release of hazardous substances. The RCRA regulates the generation, treatment, storage, handling, transportation and disposal of solid waste and requires states to develop programs to ensure the safe disposal of solid waste. Under the RCRA, persons may be liable at sites where the past or present storage, handling, treatment, transportation, or disposal of any solid or hazardous waste may present an imminent and substantial endangerment to health or the environment. These persons can include the current owner or operator of property where disposal occurred, any persons who owned or operated the property when the disposal occurred, and any persons who disposed of, or arranged for the transportation or disposal of, hazardous substances at a contaminated property. Liability under the RCRA is strict and, under certain circumstances, joint and several, so that any responsible party may be held liable for the entire cost of investigating and remediating the release of hazardous substances. As is the case with all companies engaged in similar industries, depending on the underlying facts and circumstances we face potential exposure from future claims and lawsuits involving environmental matters, including soil and water contamination, personal injury or property damage allegedly caused by hazardous substances that we manufactured, handled, used, stored, transported, spilled, disposed of or released. We cannot assure you that we will not become involved in future proceedings related to our release of hazardous or extremely hazardous substances or that, if we were held responsible for damages in any existing or future proceedings, such costs would be covered by insurance or would not be material.

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsubsection Title: Process Safety and Prevention of Major Accidents
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to OSHA and comparable state laws that regulate the protection of the health and safety of employees. In addition, OSHA’s hazard communication standard, the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act (“EPCRA”) and implementing regulations and similar state statutes and ----- regulations require that information be maintained about hazardous materials used or produced in our operations and that this information be provided to employees, state and local government authorities and citizens. Of particular relevance to our operations, OSHA’s standard on Process Safety Management (“PSM”) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals contains requirements for the management of hazards associated with processes using highly hazardous chemicals. OSHA’s PSM regulations are designed to prevent or minimize the consequences of unexpected releases of toxic, reactive, flammable or explosive liquids and gases in chemical processes. The PSM covers facilities that deal with any of certain listed toxic and reactive chemicals and flammable liquids and gases in amounts over specified threshold quantities. The PSM requires process hazard analysis, a systematic study of events that could cause hazardous substance releases and the safeguards to prevent them. Employers must perform an initial hazard analysis on all processes covered by the standard and update the analysis at least every five years. Among other things, the PSM also mandates written operating procedures, employee training, pre-startup safety reviews, evaluation of mechanical integrity of equipment, written procedures for managing change, investigation of incidents involving releases or near misses of covered chemicals, emergency action plans and compliance audits. A few of our manufacturing facilities are also subject to the EPA’s CAA Risk Management Program (“RMP”), which requires facilities that produce, handle, process, distribute or store certain highly hazardous chemicals to develop a risk management plan and program in the event of an accidental release of such chemicals. The RMP also requires facilities to assess potential impacts to off-site populations in the event of a credible worst-case release and to document the policies, procedures, equipment and work practices in place to mitigate identified risks. Similar risk management requirements are imposed upon our facilities under the EPCRA, which contains chemical emergency response planning, accident release and other reporting and notification requirements applicable to our U.S. manufacturing facilities.

Section Title: REGULATION
Subsubsection Text: The Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972 and subsequent amendments, commonly referred to as the Clean Water Act (“CWA”), and comparable state laws impose restrictions and strict controls regarding the discharge of pollutants into federal and state waters. The discharge of pollutants into regulated waters is prohibited, except in accordance with the terms of a CWA permit. The CWA also requires many facilities to develop and maintain plans for preventing and responding to spills of hazardous substances, called Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure Plans, and certain high volume hazardous substance handling/storage facilities are required to prepare and maintain a more extensive plan called a Facility Response Plan. Breaches of the CWA can result in administrative, civil or criminal sanctions. -----
